Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 16 April 1969

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Hon. W. J. Aston) took

Speaker: NA
Text: the chair at 2.33 p.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BENSON presented a petition from

Speaker: NA
Text: certain citizens of the Commonwealth show-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that the National Service Act 1968 is

Speaker: NA
Text: unduly harsh in that it (i) makes provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for the use of conscripted young men for

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas service; (ii) makes no allowance for

Speaker: NA
Text: conscientious objection to a particular war;

Speaker: NA
Text: (iii) provides an unduly harsh penalty of 2

Speaker: NA
Text: years gaol for those young men whose con-

Speaker: NA
Text: science compels them not to comply with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petitioners pray that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled

Speaker: NA
Text: should respond to our plea for the early

Speaker: NA
Text: repeal of the Act, and the immediate release

Speaker: NA
Text: of any young men who are now in prison

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of their conscientious refusal to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: - Petition received and read.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr HANSEN presented a petition

Speaker: NA
Text: from certain citizens of Australia showing

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a crisis in education in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia; that a transformation of the class-

Speaker: NA
Text: room situation is necessary, where children

Speaker: NA
Text: will have reasonable freedom to develop as

Speaker: NA
Text: self-reliant, independent individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: where they can learn to function as

Speaker: NA
Text: members of a democratic community;

Speaker: NA
Text: that proper preparation for school and

Speaker: NA
Text: thorough guidance there by qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers are crucial to a proper education

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia's children; that the present

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of teacher training is far below

Speaker: NA
Text: the requirement determined by the Martin

Speaker: NA
Text: Report which shows that 75% additional

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers in government schools alone will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required by 1975 compared with those in

Speaker: NA
Text: service in 1963; that to obtain maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit from the education system pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: school facilities should be available to all

Speaker: NA
Text: children; that insufficient State or Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance has been made available to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: these requirements; that adequatefinanceto

Speaker: NA
Text: meet these requirements can only be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the Commonwealth Government;

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is an urgent need for a national

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into all aspects of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petitioners pray that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled will

Speaker: NA
Text: give earnest consideration, during Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights Year, to this most vital matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received and read.

Speaker: NA
Text: Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr HULME presented a petition

Speaker: NA
Text: from certain citizens of Australia showing

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a crisis in education in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia; that a transformation of the class-

Speaker: NA
Text: room situation is necessary, where children

Speaker: NA
Text: will have reasonable freedom to develop as

Speaker: NA
Text: self-reliant, independent individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: where they can learn to function as

Speaker: NA
Text: members of a democratic community;

Speaker: NA
Text: that proper preparation for school and

Speaker: NA
Text: thorough guidance there by qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers are crucial to a proper education

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia's children; that the present

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of teacher training is far below

Speaker: NA
Text: the requirement determined by the Martin

Speaker: NA
Text: Report which shows that 75% additional

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers in government schools alone will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required by 1.975 compared with those in

Speaker: NA
Text: service in 1963; that to obtain maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit from the education system pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: school facilities should be available to all

Speaker: NA
Text: children; that insufficient State or Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance has been made available to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: these requirements; that adequate finance to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet these requirements can only be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the Commonwealth Government;

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is an urgent need for a national

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into all aspects of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petitioners pray that the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled will

Speaker: NA
Text: give earnest consideration, during Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights Year, to this most vital matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Export of Merino Sheep

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MUNRO presented a petition from

Speaker: NA
Text: certain electors of the Eden-Monaro Divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion showing that the decision of the Gov-

Speaker: NA
Text: ernment to lift the 40-year old ban on the

Speaker: NA
Text: export of merino rams will do irreparable

Speaker: NA
Text: harm to the present and future merino wool

Speaker: NA
Text: industry of Australia; that the initial quota

Speaker: NA
Text: of 300 rams will be suflicient to make any

Speaker: NA
Text: future protest worthless; and that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of fine medium quality merino wool

Speaker: NA
Text: in cheap labour countries will put the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian merino wool grower and all con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nected with this industry out of business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petitioners pray that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will cause to be held a referendum of wool

Speaker: NA
Text: growers to determine this issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: EDUCATION

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: M y question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science. 1 refer to the Minister's public

Speaker: NA
Text: support of colleges of advanced education

Speaker: NA
Text: and his claims that they should offer courses

Speaker: NA
Text: in no way inferior to those available at

Speaker: NA
Text: universities. As these colleges have been

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged because they have originated

Speaker: NA
Text: from a depressed technical college system

Speaker: NA
Text: and as they will continue to be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: advantaged because of limited contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: from the States owing to the financial diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties of the States, will the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: offer a generous and extensive programme

Speaker: NA
Text: of unmatched grants fo colleges for all

Speaker: NA
Text: development purposes in the next triennium

Speaker: NA
Text: and increase the Commonwealth contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to current expenditure of colleges to a

Speaker: NA
Text: $1 for $1 basis for that triennium?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: and sympathise with the thoughts behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honourable member's question and

Speaker: NA
Text: his desire to support the colleges of

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced education to a maximum extent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference was made to the fact that before

Speaker: NA
Text: the joint Commonwealth-State programmes

Speaker: NA
Text: resulted in greater support in this area of

Speaker: NA
Text: education these colleges were not getting

Speaker: NA
Text: thc proportion of funds that should have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone to them. That is quite correct. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: joint Commonwealth-State programmes

Speaker: NA
Text: have been designed to remedy the defects

Speaker: NA
Text: of the past. I believe that when we see the

Speaker: NA
Text: results of not only this triennium but also

Speaker: NA
Text: the ones that wfll follow we will see that

Speaker: NA
Text: the programmes are successful. The nature

Speaker: NA
Text: of the right honourable member's question

Speaker: NA
Text: suggests in part at least that the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to these colleges are purely financial

Speaker: NA
Text: ones. This is certainly not so. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: other problems as well, many of which

Speaker: NA
Text: stem from the background and origin of

Speaker: NA
Text: the colleges.

Speaker: NA
Text: A great deal of advocacy and work needs

Speaker: NA
Text: to be done to help build the status and

Speaker: NA
Text: prestige of the colleges so that they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded not by a few but by a large pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of the population as genuine and

Speaker: NA
Text: viable alternatives to universities. The view

Speaker: NA
Text: of parents and students is something that

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be effective. The Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: has appointed two committees which 1

Speaker: NA
Text: believe will play a significant part in helping

Speaker: NA
Text: to achieve these objectives. One is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wiltshire Committee, which I hope will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reporting soon on the nomenclature and

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of awards in the different colleges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members are no doubt aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that the standards vary greatly from one

Speaker: NA
Text: college to another. Mr Justice Sweeney is

Speaker: NA
Text: conducting an inquiry into the scale of

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries that should prevail in the colleges.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that this will add to the status of

Speaker: NA
Text: the professional staff at the colleges.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things that needs to be over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come, and I think the right honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question refers to it, is the 3-acre

Speaker: NA
Text: or 5-acre inner suburban concept of the

Speaker: NA
Text: colleges, with a large number of students

Speaker: NA
Text: housed on a small piece of ground. The

Speaker: NA
Text: plans encompassed in the first triennium

Speaker: NA
Text: envisage the relocation of these colleges

Speaker: NA
Text: over a period on much more adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds and better sites so that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: expand and develop in a proper manner-

Speaker: NA
Text: much the same as universities-ove r a long

Speaker: NA
Text: period of time. But there is a limit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of expansion that can be encompassed

Speaker: NA
Text: in a short period of time. There is not only

Speaker: NA
Text: a limit to the rate at which buildings can

Speaker: NA
Text: be constructed but also a limit to the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: at which well qualified staff can be recruited.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to foreshadow what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's Advisory Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Advanced Education might recommend or

Speaker: NA
Text: predict what the Commonwealth's decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: might be in relation to this matter, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: firmly believe that the joint programmes,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be supported by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and the States for the next triennium,

Speaker: NA
Text: will take the colleges of advanced education

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant further step in the advance-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of education in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: MILITARY DISCIPLINE

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: M y question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Defence. It refers to a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement he made in this House that an

Speaker: NA
Text: inter-dcpartmental committee would look

Speaker: NA
Text: into certain aspects of military detention. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask: Has the Minister any progress report

Speaker: NA
Text: from this committee or any information to

Speaker: NA
Text: give to the House?

Speaker: Mr FAIRHALL
Text: l t is true that in 1968

Speaker: NA
Text: some complaints were made and questions

Speaker: NA
Text: were raised in the House concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of members of the armed forces

Speaker: NA
Text: undergoing detention at Holsworthy. J

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook then, on a promise given by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Government who was

Speaker: NA
Text: then Acting Prime Minister, to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter looked into. The result was that in

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1968, I set up a committee of inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was chaired by Mr F. J. Mahony,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Sydney. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: members were Mr J. A. Morony, the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Comptroller-General of Prisons in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, Mr G. P. Temme of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Defence, and Brigadier O. H.

Speaker: NA
Text: Isaksson, who was Deputy Adjutant-General

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Department of the Army. In fact, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee has now finished its delibera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. It has produced a very detailed report

Speaker: NA
Text: on the question of Army detention and 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have already circulated the report to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers of the three Services authorising

Speaker: NA
Text: tbem to put into operation immediately such

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations as are easily manageable.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be clearly understood, I am sure,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be recommendations in the

Speaker: NA
Text: report that will call for some planning and

Speaker: NA
Text: for some expenditure which will, in turn,

Speaker: NA
Text: become a Budget matter. These matters, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, will have to be studied in a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more depth. I take the opportunity, firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: of saying how much we appreciate the

Speaker: NA
Text: services of the Committee in providing this

Speaker: NA
Text: very detailed report. For the benefit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and those who were critical at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time, I am bound to say that the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee in its deliberations and investigations

Speaker: NA
Text: found no evidence of harsh treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the regulations in any of the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: detention camps. This was not a report to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament; it was a report to me as

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence, but for the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of honourable members I propose to lay

Speaker: NA
Text: a copy of the report on the table of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Library.

Speaker: NA
Text: RHODESIA

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Th e Prime Minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: have noticed the visit of Air Vice-Marshal

Speaker: NA
Text: Hawkins to Australia. The Air Viceon

Speaker: NA
Text: Marshal is pictured on the front page

Speaker: NA
Text: the 'Australian' and elsewhere in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Sydney Morning Herald' and the Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne 'Sun'. He was formerly Commander

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Rhodesian Air Force and he is to

Speaker: NA
Text: become Rhodesia's diplomatic representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive to South Africa. I recall the informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which tbe Minister for Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: gave me last August that an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: passport had been issued to the Air Vice-

Speaker: NA
Text: Marshal as he had established that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: never lost his Australian citizenship. I now

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the right honourable gentleman whether

Speaker: NA
Text: he will make it plain that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government does not approve of an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian citizen taking a position described

Speaker: NA
Text: as 'Rhodesia's diplomatic representative'.

Speaker: Mr GORTON
Text: I did notice the picture

Speaker: NA
Text: to which the Leader of the Opposition refers

Speaker: NA
Text: - a picture of an Australian who had had

Speaker: NA
Text: a most distinguished career fighting for the

Speaker: NA
Text: free world against Fascism as a pilot with

Speaker: NA
Text: great distinction and finishing up as the

Speaker: NA
Text: head of the air force of a country which

Speaker: NA
Text: was then joined, I think with the approba-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of all of us, in opposing Hitler,

Speaker: NA
Text: Fascism and Fascist rule.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCEwen-I t was a country in which

Speaker: NA
Text: some of our pilots were trained.

Speaker: Mr GORTON
Text: Indeed , it was a coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, I am reminded, in which many of our

Speaker: NA
Text: pilots, who then went to fight against thi.s

Speaker: NA
Text: aggressive Fascism, trained, just as they

Speaker: NA
Text: trained in Canada, since we were all in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire Air Training Scheme together for

Speaker: NA
Text: the one objective. Having noticed that pic-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture, I felt that that man bad had a career

Speaker: NA
Text: which was distinguished and which had

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly helped the freedom of thc world

Speaker: NA
Text: and the relief of Europe from conquest

Speaker: NA
Text: from abroad. I understand- I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: this for certain-tha t he still is an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian citizen, and if he is an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: citizen then he has a perfect right to visit

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. For the rest, I would ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Immigration for any further

Speaker: NA
Text: information.

Speaker: NA
Text: METRIC SYSTEM

Speaker: Mr DRURY
Text: I s the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that the New Zealand Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has decided to adopt the metric system of

Speaker: NA
Text: weights and measures? Has the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment considered the unanimous recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations of the Senate Select Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: the Metric System of Weights and

Speaker: NA
Text: of Measures regarding the desirability of

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing this system into Australia? If so,

Speaker: NA
Text: can the Prime Minister give the House any

Speaker: NA
Text: indication as to when an announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: might be expected?

Speaker: Mr GORTON
Text: 1 was not aware that the

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand Governnient had decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt the metric system of weights and

Speaker: NA
Text: measures nor am I aware-althoug h perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member can later enlighten

Speaker: NA
Text: me-whethe r it has determined any time-

Speaker: NA
Text: table for such adoption. For all I know,

Speaker: NA
Text: it may be 10, 15 or 20 years ahead. 1 do

Speaker: NA
Text: not know. I would be surprised if the sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestion were that it was to be rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted, although that might be so. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report from tbe Senate Select Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: has not yet been considered in detail by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet, although it has been looked at by

Speaker: NA
Text: various public servants who wili make

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations to the Government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: involves very great expense. It involves

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable disruption. It could well lead in

Speaker: NA
Text: the long run to advantages to Australia. But

Speaker: NA
Text: that, 1 think, is all I can say in response

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member's question at this

Speaker: NA
Text: moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAXATION

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: I ask the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is a fact that recently the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner of Taxation gave a ruling that

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses incurred in the removal of night-

Speaker: NA
Text: soil and effluent from dwellings in un-

Speaker: NA
Text: sewered areas by councils and shires was not

Speaker: NA
Text: an allowable deduction under section 72(1)

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Does

Speaker: NA
Text: this mean that thousands of taxpayers who

Speaker: NA
Text: own properties in' unsewered areas arc to

Speaker: NA
Text: be deprived of thc opportunity to deduct,

Speaker: NA
Text: for tax purposes, sanitary expenses which

Speaker: NA
Text: are charged each year by councils and

Speaker: NA
Text: shires, simply because section 72(1) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act does not specifically include the words

Speaker: NA
Text: 'sanitary expenses'? In view of the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance of the Commissioner's ruling,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially to low income earners, will he

Speaker: NA
Text: have seciion 72 (I) of the Act reviewed and,

Speaker: NA
Text: if necessary, amended so that all rate-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers will enjoy equality in taxation con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions in respect of rates?

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: I was not aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling by the Commissioner of Taxation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will have a review made of the decision, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member suggests, if in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: it was made. Later on I will see what is

Speaker: NA
Text: be done in a budget context.

Speaker: NA
Text: TELEVISION

Speaker: Mr CALDER
Text: M y question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Postmaster-General. I refer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: recent announcement by the Chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: that Darwin would receive television trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission-a n amenity whkh I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: constantly advocating for the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. I ask the Postmaster-General

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he can advise me of the approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate date when the television station will be

Speaker: NA
Text: established. Could he also inform me

Speaker: NA
Text: whether consideration is also being given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the establishment of an ABC television

Speaker: NA
Text: station at Alice Springs?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr HULME;-Member s of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: will recollect that some months ago i

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that approval had been given for

Speaker: NA
Text: the erection of national television stations

Speaker: NA
Text: at Kalgoorlie, Geraldton, the Upper

Speaker: NA
Text: conMurray, Mount Isa and Darwin. The instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentalities responsible for this-th e Post

Speaker: NA
Text: Oflice, the ABC and the Australian Broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casting Control Board-ar e at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: designing the transmitter siies and buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: and making preparations for the calling of

Speaker: NA
Text: tenders for the construction of these instal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations. I understand that it is expected that

Speaker: NA
Text: Ihe Darwin station will be brought on air

Speaker: NA
Text: in the early part of 1971. Recently the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Control Board

Speaker: NA
Text: made recommendations to me in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: other smaller centres. By the time the five

Speaker: NA
Text: stations I have already mentioned come on

Speaker: NA
Text: air no less than 96% of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: population will have television available to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. The other 4% of the population,

Speaker: NA
Text: roughly 500,000 people, are distributed

Speaker: NA
Text: over a large number of different areas. A

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for further extensions of television

Speaker: NA
Text: services has been put before me and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governnient. The centres covered by this

Speaker: NA
Text: plan include Alice Springs, which is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the larger of the centres at present not

Speaker: NA
Text: provided with television services. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt the plan as far as it affects Alice

Speaker: NA
Text: Springs and certain other areas, and I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the not too distant future I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to make a more definite statement on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: MEAT AND DAIRY EXPORTS

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Text: I s the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry aware that the American

Speaker: NA
Text: to Department of Agriculture has placed a ban

Speaker: NA
Text: on the import of meat and dairy products

Speaker: NA
Text: from certain areas ef Australia because

Speaker: NA
Text: pesticide poison has been found in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts? One Tasmanian firm has been affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by this prohibition, and exporters from other

Speaker: NA
Text: States have had certain of their shipments of

Speaker: NA
Text: foodstuffs condemned in America because

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been affected by pesticide poison.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the dangers, isolated and rare

Speaker: NA
Text: as they are at present, of foodstuffs being

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by pesticides used for spraying pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures, with the resultant impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: American market

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: niember will ask his question.

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Text: Wil l the Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ban altogether the use of pesticides

Speaker: NA
Text: that have a DDT component?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I t is true that the

Speaker: NA
Text: American Administration bans any meat

Speaker: NA
Text: which contains certain insecticidal residues,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly DDT, and certain organic phos-

Speaker: NA
Text: phates. The Commonwealth Government,

Speaker: NA

Text: towards security In the area

Text: of the Minister for Trade and Industry been

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: member will not quote from a newspaper.

Text: He can refer to it sufficiently to make his

Text: question understandable.

Text: states that Australia has greatly con-

Text: tributed to the collapse of the minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: price regulations of the International Grains

Text: Arrangement. Is this statement correct?

Text: I have not personally

Text: read the statement, but officers of my

Text: Department have informed me of it. To the

Text: extent that it is an allegation that Australian

Text: has contributed to a likely break-

Speaker: NA
Text: down of the International Grains Arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, this is utterly untrue and utterly

Speaker: NA
Text: incorrect. The present International Grains

Speaker: NA
Text: Arrangement, unlike previous ones, has a

Speaker: NA
Text: rather complex basis for pricing. It not only

Speaker: NA
Text: takes into account the various grades and

Speaker: NA
Text: qualities of wheat, but it is based upon a

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed price for a number of grades of wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: at American gulf ports. From that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: of freight to certain destinations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the wheat from America, and a complex

Speaker: NA
Text: formula of calculations of freight for any

Speaker: NA
Text: exporter from any other port to any

Speaker: NA
Text: other country. An argument has prevailed

Speaker: NA
Text: as to whether Australia has been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: freights other than those which might be

Speaker: NA
Text: quesaccepted as the normal freight. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only basis of any allegation about

Speaker: NA
Text: I think there have been allegations against

Speaker: NA
Text: the other countries-perhap s not Canada; I

Speaker: NA
Text: would not make any allegations about

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada. In the United States the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment enters into an international contract in

Speaker: NA
Text: of wheat and then permits the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national trading of wheat to be in private

Speaker: NA
Text: bands, and there have been strong allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: that the trading of wheat by Americans has

Speaker: NA
Text: been contrived privately in a manner to

Speaker: NA
Text: avoid the minimum price specifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been allegations, in respect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: export of wheat by the European Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Community, concerning the avoidance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the obligation. There have been allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of the export of wheat from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Argentine. I regard these matters as teeth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing troubles in a great and complex inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement covering one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: major internationally traded commodities.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it was brought to my notice that

Speaker: NA
Text: this controversy was proceeding I imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately said that T did not intend to have

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia suspected, let alone breaking the

Speaker: NA
Text: rides, and that what we sbould do should

Speaker: NA
Text: be to have the major trading nations gather

Speaker: NA
Text: together, discuss the problems which were

Speaker: NA
Text: tormenting each of them and arrive at an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed solution. That discussion, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: held at the level of very senior public ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vants, in the presence of members or repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of the Australian Wheat Board

Speaker: NA
Text: in the case of Australia, took place in

Speaker: NA
Text: Washington, 1 think, while the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter himself was over there. This is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: complex ...alter and it has not involved Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia alone. As a result of the discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 have mentioned, all the nations agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: that Ihey were determined to sustain the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Grains Arrangement. They

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed that they would individually study

Speaker: NA
Text: very carefully the operation of their own

Speaker: NA
Text: trading arrangements to ensure that none

Speaker: NA
Text: of them as individuals could properly be

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged to be impairing the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Grains Arrangement. 1 do not think there

Speaker: NA
Text: could be a better outcome than that for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arrangement and for Australia's interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that the writer of the article to

Speaker: NA
Text: which thc honourable member referred is

Text: Mr Donath, who is a lecturer at the Univer-

Text: sity of Melbourne. All the articles I have

Text: read by Mr Donath have been adverse to

Text: the interests of Ihe Australian wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. He does noi believe that the Aus-

Text: tralian wheat industry should be supported

Text: or that the Australian wheat industry should

Text: be allowed to expand. He is living in the

Text: world of Adam Smilh of .150 years ago

Text: when it was assumed as pure economic

Text: theory that items should be produced only

Text: this age, this century or this generation at

Text: all. I just take no notice of Mr Donalh's

Text: writing.

Text: Primary Industry to tell the Parliament and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian wheat growers the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's grain production targets for the

Speaker: NA
Text: current season. WiJI he say what decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made in respect of production

Speaker: NA
Text: control and to what extent production is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be restricted? Does the Minister realise that

Speaker: NA
Text: to delay clear-cut decisions now may result

Speaker: NA
Text: in chaotic conditions at harvest time? Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister able to indicate any substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: storage plans for this year's surplus wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: or whether there will be new marketing pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals or any other propositions to dispose

Speaker: NA
Text: of all of our surplus production?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I t is not the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's policy to determine production

Speaker: NA
Text: targets or the extent of production

Speaker: NA
Text: of this commodity or that commodity.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are matters for the primary indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries themselves to determine, lt is a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: even for the individual grower to decide

Speaker: NA
Text: what he should produce and how much of

Speaker: NA
Text: it he should produce. Even if this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment wished to make such decision;., it

Speaker: NA
Text: would have no authority under the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitution to do so, because such matters lie

Speaker: NA
Text: within the jurisdiction of the States. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, I have been warning the wheat indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try for some time that there will be great

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties in delivery and disposal of this

Speaker: NA
Text: season's crop if it attains anything like the

Speaker: NA
Text: dimensions of last year's crop and if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are unable to dispose of it at any greater

Speaker: NA
Text: rate than we have been able to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past 2 or 3 years. As a result of my

Speaker: NA
Text: warnings the Australian Wheatgrowers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation has studied the matter in great

Speaker: NA
Text: detail and brought forward a proposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply a quota system in respect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery of wheat lo the terminals. This pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal is contingent upon the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: providing a first advance of $1.10 a bushel

Speaker: NA
Text: for a certain quantity of wheat and on the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments implementing such a

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal.

Speaker: NA
Text: At tbis point of lime it appears that there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a carry-over of 250 million bushels

Speaker: NA
Text: in the silos when this year's crop is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: harvested. The total storage space in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country is sufficient for about 517 million

Speaker: NA
Text: bushels. This means that only about 270

Speaker: NA
Text: million bushels can be accepted at the ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: minals. When we realise that last year's

Speaker: NA
Text: production was about 530 million bushels,

Speaker: NA
Text: of which 505 million bushels was delivered,

Speaker: NA
Text: we can appreciate that this year there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be an awful lot of wheat left on the farms

Speaker: NA
Text: because it will be impossible to deliver it

Speaker: NA
Text: to the terminals. Without some orderly

Speaker: NA
Text: system of deliveries there would be ulter

Speaker: NA
Text: chaos and the proposal that the Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: has put forward is designed to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: some orderly delivery system. But even

Speaker: NA
Text: under that proposal it will be necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: build additional storages for approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 90 million bushels. The responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: storage of wheat is that of the bulk handling

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities and tbe Australian Wheat Board,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will be up to these bodies to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: additional space. But additional space means

Speaker: NA
Text: additional money, and the people who will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide this money are the wheat growers.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, it is a decision they will have to take.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will have to meet their obligations. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the Wheat Board and the bulk

Speaker: NA
Text: handling authorities are examining this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. No doubt they will take into account

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts that I have revealed to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: INTERNATIONAL LABOUR

Speaker: NA
Text: ORGANISATION CONVENTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion of matter of Public Importance

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have received a letter

Speaker: NA
Text: from the honourable member for Stirling

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Webb) proposing that a definite matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of public importance be submitted to

Speaker: NA
Text: House for discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's disappointing record on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ratification and appUcation of International Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation Conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: (More than the number of members

Speaker: NA
Text: required by the Standing Orders having risen

Speaker: NA
Text: in their places)

Speaker: Mr WEBB
Text: Stirling) [3.27]-I n raising

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter of public importance I draw

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of honourable members to the

Speaker: NA
Text: chart of International Labour Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: ratifications dated lst June 1968. The chart

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing record in regard to the rati-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication and application of ILO conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The International Labour Organisation was

Speaker: NA
Text: es abiished in 1919. So, this is the fiftieth

Speaker: NA
Text: year of its existence. During that half

Speaker: NA
Text: century the ILO bas been able to formulate

Speaker: NA
Text: over 128 separate conventions on labour national

Speaker: NA
Text: and social questions. These international

Speaker: NA
Text: labour standards have been ratified on such

Speaker: NA
Text: a scale that the total number of ratifications

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Slst Session in 1967 had reached fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: 3,356. The question of actual performance

Speaker: NA
Text: is being raised with increasing insistence.

Speaker: NA
Text: The adoption of international legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: its formal acceptance by an increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: number of countries does not add to the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing stability of relations between states

Speaker: NA
Text: unless the contracting parties comply with

Speaker: NA
Text: their obligations. Under the ILO's constitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion annual reports are required on the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect given to the ILO instruments. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1964 Conference the Director-General of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ILO said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We must scrupulously safeguard lhe rigorous

Speaker: NA
Text: supervision over the application of ILO standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is essential to the integrity of the Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the self-respect of the member-states

Speaker: NA
Text: which have through it undertaken international

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: What has been the impact of ILO super-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision on governments which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: found to infringe their treaty obligations?

Speaker: NA
Text: Breaches of obligations are not deemed to

Speaker: NA
Text: have been eliminated when a government

Speaker: NA
Text: has merely voiced its intention to initiate

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary measures or has introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: draft legislation. They are only deemed to

Speaker: NA
Text: have been eliminated when concrete action

Speaker: NA
Text: has been taken. The ILO's constitution

Speaker: NA
Text: devotes twenty-four of its forty articles

Speaker: NA
Text: the to the preparation, adoption and imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentation of ILO standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Adoption of a decision in the form of

Speaker: NA
Text: a convention or a recommendation requires

Speaker: NA
Text: a majority of two-thirds bf the votes cast

Speaker: NA
Text: by the delegates. This indicates that decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: are not taken lightly. This is further borne

Speaker: NA
Text: out by the fact that each member country

Speaker: NA
Text: has a delegation of four persons-tw o

Speaker: NA
Text: government delegates, one employers' dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gate and one workers' delegate. I bad the

Speaker: NA
Text: honour of representing Australia at the 1.959

Speaker: NA
Text: the ILO Conference as a workers' delegate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the past 49 years-th e fiftieth annual

Speaker: NA
Text: session has not yet been held-th e ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference, as I have already mentioned,

Speaker: NA
Text: has a has formulated 128 conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We come now to the attitude of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to its obligations to ILO. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: previous debate I stated that as at 3rd June

Speaker: NA
Text: 1963 the International Labour Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: had made 118 conventions of which Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia had ratified only 25. The inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: chart of ratifications, which is dated

Speaker: NA
Text: lst June 1968- 5 years later-show s that

Speaker: NA
Text: the ILO has ratified 128 conventions but

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has ratified only 26, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: than one-fifth of the total ratifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to note that the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom has ratified 60, France 79, Italy

Speaker: NA
Text: and 67, The Netherlands 63 and New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: 44. Australia's sorry record is revealed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that although it has been a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ILO since its inception in 1919 it

Speaker: NA
Text: bas ratified only 26 of the 128 conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Time does not permit me to deal with all

Speaker: NA
Text: the conventions that have not been ratified

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Australian Government. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them will be dealt with by other speakers

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Opposition, but I refer to just

Speaker: NA
Text: a few: Convention 105, Abolition of

Speaker: NA
Text: Forced Labour; 107, Indigenous and Tribal

Speaker: NA
Text: Populations; 115, Radiation Protection; 101,

Speaker: NA
Text: Holidays with Pay (Agriculture); and 99,

Speaker: NA
Text: Minimum Wage Fixing (Agriculture). So I

Speaker: NA
Text: could go on. But let me say something about

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention 100, Equal Remuneration, and

Speaker: NA
Text: 111, Discrimination (Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Occupation). The Government has failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: honour its obligations under the 1951

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO conventions and recommendations con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning equal remuneration for the sexes

Speaker: NA
Text: for work of equal value. It has failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: ratify convention 111 and recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 1 concerning discrimination between the

Speaker: NA
Text: sexes. And it has failed to implement the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the vocational recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of 1962 with respect to girls and

Speaker: NA
Text: women. The Government has not ratified

Speaker: NA
Text: convention 100 which provides for equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for equal work for the sexes, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: quote the pertinent part of it:

Speaker: NA
Text: Each Member shall, by means appropriate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the methods in operation for determining rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of remuneration, promote and, insofar as is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistent with such methods, ensure the application

Speaker: NA
Text: to all workers of the principle of equal remunera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for men and women workers for work of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal value.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has done nothing about

Speaker: NA
Text: the ratification of that convention. The ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: now has 125 members and, of these, 62

Speaker: NA
Text: countries have ratified Convention 100 to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred. Unfortunately Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is not one of the 62 countries thai

Speaker: NA
Text: have ratified that convention. Over 56

Speaker: NA
Text: countries have implemented recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 90 which states that wage differentials

Speaker: NA
Text: based on sex should be removed pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressively and that as the first step the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of equal pay for work of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: value should be applied in government

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chipp- Mr Speaker, I rise to order.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not want to be discourteous to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member but he well knows

Speaker: NA
Text: that the question of equal pay is presently

Speaker: NA
Text: before a conciliation commissioner. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a long standing practice of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: that such matters as are before a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner are not debated per se in tbis

Speaker: NA
Text: House. I suggest that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is about to do this.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: substance in the point of order. This matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is before the Commonwealth Conciliation

Speaker: NA
Text: and Arbitration Commission, not before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Industrial Court.

Speaker: Mr WEBB
Text: I continue. The first para-

Speaker: NA
Text: graph of the recommendation reads as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Appropriate action should be taken, after con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultation with the workers' organisations con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned or, where such organisations do not exist,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the workers concerned-

Speaker: NA
Text: a. to ensure the application of the principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal remuneration for men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: workers for work of equal value to all

Speaker: NA
Text: employees of central Government departments

Speaker: NA
Text: or agencies.

Speaker: NA
Text: That applies to tbe employees of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The recommendation con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues:

Speaker: NA
Text: b. to encourage the application of the principle

Speaker: NA
Text: to employees of State, provincial or local

Speaker: NA
Text: government departments or agencies where

Speaker: NA
Text: these have jurisdiction over rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have referred to this as a responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: more of State governments and other bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with that section of the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation. State governments have done

Speaker: NA
Text: more to ensure the application of the prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple of equal remuneration than has the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Western Australian State Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, for instance, decided in October 1967

Speaker: NA
Text: to give to its female employees equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for work of equal value. This great reform

Speaker: NA
Text: will be fully implemented by January 1972.

Speaker: NA
Text: lt has also clarified the powers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Industrial Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: to write the principle into State awards. The

Speaker: NA
Text: decision of the Western Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment means that five out of the six States

Speaker: NA
Text: have granted equal pay and it leaves Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria and the Commonwealth to come into

Speaker: NA
Text: line. It is necessary that there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: national uniformity on the issue of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for equal work. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service ( Mr Bury)

Speaker: NA
Text: has always argued that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Conciliation and Arbitration Commisson

Speaker: NA
Text: has power to grant equal pay. True enough,

Speaker: NA
Text: but when equal pay was awarded in the

Speaker: NA
Text: malter involving Commonwealth Hostels

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited he appealed against the decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a social reform and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should give a lead not only in the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial tribunals but by granting this great

Speaker: NA
Text: social reform to its own employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would then fall in line with five of the

Speaker: NA
Text: six States. Government members often lend

Speaker: NA
Text: lip service to this much needed reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: They adopt a two-faced attitude. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: a section of the Liberal Party's platform

Speaker: NA
Text: which states, as one of its objectives:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . acceptance of the principle of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration for men and women for work of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal value.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is as far as it goes. Members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about it but when it comes to a vote

Speaker: NA
Text: on the implementation of the policy they

Speaker: NA
Text: do nothing about it. The Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: done nothing to give its own employees

Speaker: NA
Text: equal pay for equal work, ft gives equal

Speaker: NA
Text: margins, but that is as far as it goes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations under thc Public Service Act

Speaker: NA
Text: discriminate against women officers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service. Regulations 104, 105 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 106, under section 30 of the Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. pinpoint the inequalities that exist

Speaker: NA
Text: between the rates of male and female

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, many of whom are performing

Speaker: NA
Text: the same type of work and have the same

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications. Regulation 104 (1.) sets out

Speaker: NA
Text: the salaries payable to officers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Second and Third Divisions. Paragraphs

Speaker: NA
Text: (2.) and (3.) of the regulation provide that

Speaker: NA
Text: where a female officer occupies an office

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Second or Third Division the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: salary per annum payable to such female

Speaker: NA
Text: officer shall be $308 less than the male rate to men.

Speaker: NA
Text: for that office. This placing of women in a

Speaker: NA
Text: lower status to men doing the same work

Speaker: NA
Text: is revealed also in regulations 105 and 106.

Speaker: NA
Text: This discrimination should be removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government rejects all claims by

Speaker: NA
Text: white collar unions for equal pay to women

Speaker: NA
Text: employees in the Public Service. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of this Government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with its ILO obligations, to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply the principle of equal pay for work

Speaker: NA
Text: of equal value to its own employees, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not do so. In the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service we have men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: working alongside one another, doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: same work but receiving different rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: pay. Among the countries that have imple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mented recommendation 90 are the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, the United States of America,

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada and New Zealand. These countries

Speaker: NA
Text: have applied to civil servants the principle

Speaker: NA
Text: of equal pay for work of equal value.

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain did so some years ago. New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced legislation to provide for equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for equal work in 1960. lt was designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to be implemented over a period of 3 years

Speaker: NA
Text: and, of course, New Zealand's economy is

Speaker: NA
Text: not as sound as Australia's economy. A

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government in New Zealand intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced this reform and it was not opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Nationalist Opposition at that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sixty-two member states of the ILO have

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified Convention 100. Several other States

Speaker: NA
Text: have ratified convention 111 which opposes

Speaker: NA
Text: discrimination against women in employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Member states have a moral obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to ratify decisions of ILO. For many

Speaker: NA
Text: centuries a woman suffered social neglect

Speaker: NA
Text: and political inferiority. She now has

Speaker: NA
Text: equality of civil rights, political rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: educational opportunity. She has equality

Speaker: NA
Text: of entry to most occupations, yet in Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth employment in this country she

Speaker: NA
Text: is paid at a lower rate than men doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: same work. In fact, women have social and

Speaker: NA
Text: political equality but not economic equality.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the interests of social justice a woman

Speaker: NA
Text: should be paid the same rate as a man for

Speaker: NA
Text: doing the same job. Many women workers

Speaker: NA
Text: have dependants to support or to assist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Women often give help to aged parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: and divorcees, widows and deserted wives

Speaker: NA
Text: may have children to bring up. Why should

Speaker: NA
Text: a woman school teacher or public servant

Speaker: NA
Text: receive less than her male counterpart? A

Speaker: NA
Text: government that allows this situation to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue is treating women as socially inferior

Speaker: NA
Text: Unequal pay creates a feeling of

Speaker: NA
Text: inferiority and a rankling sense of injustice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Equal pay would remove this. Thi.s is recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised by ILO Conventions 100 and 111 and

Speaker: NA
Text: other conventions dealing with the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of equality between the sexes which have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been ratified by this Government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the so-called weaker sex who

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Government, whether in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House or in another place, have not shown

Speaker: NA
Text: much enthusiasm for the principle of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for the sexes for equal work. When an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue has been raised before thi.s House or

Speaker: NA
Text: in another place, they have not supported

Speaker: NA
Text: the people who have raised it. whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: be on this side of the House or on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side. They have not the fight of the women

Speaker: NA
Text: of 50 years ago wno showed great courage

Speaker: NA
Text: when they were fighting for another form

Speaker: NA
Text: of equality-th e right to vote. The suff-

Speaker: NA
Text: ragettes chained themselves to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commons railings in those days. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: politician who was not in favour of votes

Speaker: NA
Text: for women was fair game for a lashing-

Speaker: NA
Text: and not just a tongue lashing but a horse

Speaker: NA
Text: whipping.

Speaker: NA
Text: In these days of demonstrations there is

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of scope for women workers who

Speaker: NA
Text: are treated as inferiors by this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to demonstrate in support of the great prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple of equal pay. Sir Winston Churchill,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was Home Secretary, was lashed

Speaker: NA
Text: by a suffragette in a Bristol railway station

Speaker: NA
Text: for his opposition to the principle of votes

Speaker: NA
Text: for women. I do not believe in capital

Speaker: NA
Text: punishment, but I think that women today

Speaker: NA
Text: lack some of the sting that was possessed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the women of the old days. They should

Speaker: NA
Text: go out and fight a government that gives

Speaker: NA
Text: lip service to the principle of equal pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: equal work, but which fails to adopt the

Speaker: NA
Text: system or to ratify ILO conventions on the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Stewart)

Speaker: NA
Text: -Order ! The honourable member's time

Speaker: NA
Text: has expired.

Speaker: Mr BURY
Text: Wentworth-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service) [3.42]-A s

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated very properly by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Higinbotham ( Mr Chipp), it is

Speaker: NA
Text: deplorable that matters which are before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Conciliation and Abri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration Commission should be the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of detailed debate in this House. I agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with the ruling of Mr Speaker that tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nically, since the Act has been changed,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission is not a court, but our fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: bears in this Parliament have always

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted that it is sensible and wise to leave

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of wages, working hours and condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to be established by the arbitral auth-

Speaker: NA
Text: orities especially set up for the purpose, and

Speaker: NA
Text: not to debate them on the floor of either

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Parliament or the State

Speaker: NA
Text: parliaments. But since this convention has

Speaker: NA
Text: been ignored and the subject of equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: has been thrust forward, 1 feel obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: utter a few words in reply.

Speaker: NA
Text: Il is true that there are International

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Organisation conventions on this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject. Convention 100 is Ihe basic one on

Speaker: NA
Text: equal remuneration. Convention 111 deals

Speaker: NA
Text: with discrimination. What the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Stirling ( Mr Webb) did not

Speaker: NA
Text: say was that other countries, like Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: have not ratified this Convention because

Speaker: NA
Text: il does present a good many technical dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficulties and is somewhat evasive and

Speaker: NA
Text: diffuse. Reading some of the words of these

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions, the layman does not realise

Speaker: NA
Text: what legal traps there are in them. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to put the Government's record straight.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point has been made many times that

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government has not been opposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: equal pay. What we have said consistently,

Speaker: NA
Text: and what we wiil continue to say, is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision on this matter is one that

Speaker: NA
Text: should be made by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Conciliation and Arbitration Commission,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has the prime function of determin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: The equal pay case is presently before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission and the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: has stated its attitude quite clearly. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: counsel in this case has said that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: make clear that the Commonwealth accepls

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of equal pay for equal work,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, equal pay for women who are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: the same work as men, or like work, and

Speaker: NA
Text: who are doing the same range and volume

Speaker: NA
Text: of work under the same conditions. So our

Speaker: NA
Text: position is quite clear. When the matter has

Speaker: NA
Text: come before the Commission, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that we accept the principle. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: noi made decisions ahead of the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: tribunal. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Stirling referred in passing to the applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion recently lo the Commission by Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Hostels Ltd. In such matters

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Hostels Ltd does not act

Speaker: NA
Text: under my instructions. It is a company, not

Speaker: NA
Text: a Commonwealth department. It opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in a particular award for a num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of technical reasons. I realise that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has tried to blow this up as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth stand on the whole prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple. This is not so. It is a relatively minor

Speaker: NA
Text: and technical case. Our overall position on

Speaker: NA
Text: equal pay has been made clear in the words

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed by our counsel to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Stirling did

Speaker: NA
Text: not mention the fundamental difference

Speaker: NA
Text: between federal states, particularly indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial federal states, and unitary states, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very fundamental difference. When we

Speaker: NA
Text: look at advanced countries whose labour

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions are in fact in most cases fur

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead of those set out in ILO conventions

Speaker: NA
Text: -an d this applies to Australia-th e record

Speaker: NA
Text: looks somewhat different. As the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Stirling mentioned, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have ratified 26 conventions out of 128.

Speaker: NA
Text: OI course, of these 128 conventions some

Speaker: NA
Text: were quite inapplicable to Australian con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions. Some have been replaced by sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequent conventions covering the same

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. Canada on tbe whole certainly has

Speaker: NA
Text: working conditions which are in no way

Speaker: NA
Text: inferior to those in Australia, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: country has ratified twenty-four conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. Canada is a progressive country with

Speaker: NA
Text: an enlightened government, and in many

Speaker: NA
Text: fields it is ahead of most other countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another large federal industrial state is the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States. The United States has

Speaker: NA
Text: always, or certainly has for many years

Speaker: NA
Text: past, taken a very close interest in a helpful

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude towards the ILO. The United States

Speaker: NA
Text: has ratified seven conventions. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has ratified twenty-six, so our record com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pares favourably. Of course the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States has more individual States to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with. But conditions do vary widely between

Speaker: NA
Text: these countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are following these conventions conhave been signed.

Speaker: NA
Text: tinually, and we discuss them with the

Speaker: NA
Text: States where relevant. Each year a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of conventions are discussed by a body

Speaker: NA
Text: up by the Department of Labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service. This body is known as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Labour Advisory inspections

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee, and it happens to be

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting in Sydney at this moment

Speaker: NA
Text: This year as a special project for the

Speaker: NA
Text: 50th anniversary of ILO we are underdrafting

Speaker: NA
Text: taking a review of all ILO conventions and

Speaker: NA
Text: as soon as this review, which I am presentbeing

Speaker: NA
Text: ing stage by stage to the National Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Advisory Council, is complete I will table

Speaker: NA
Text: it in the Parliament. I hope that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: completed later in the year. The fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: a country supports a particular convention

Speaker: NA
Text: during ILO meeting does not mean that that

Speaker: NA
Text: country is necessarily obliged to ratify

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of these conventions when referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian State authorities are

Speaker: NA
Text: applicable or there is some peculiar diffito

Speaker: NA
Text: culty because of which one State or anwith

Speaker: NA
Text: other cannot adopt them. Perhaps one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reasons why our numbers lag a little is in.

Speaker: NA
Text: the scrupulous good faith in which we apply

Speaker: NA
Text: all these conventions. Unless we are sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that a convention is applicable throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-i t takes a lot of time to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with six governments on every minor

Speaker: NA
Text: which arises-w e do not feel we can ratify

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Up to 1946, I think, it was accepted in

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO circles and at its meetings that federal

Speaker: NA
Text: countries could ratify these conventions in-

Speaker: NA
Text: sofar as they were applicable to their own

Speaker: NA
Text: federal jurisdiction. This would not be parti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cularly difficult for Australia in most cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: although it would correspond with reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: But since the revised constitution of 1946

Speaker: NA
Text: when a convention which is appropriate in

Speaker: NA
Text: whole or in part for State action is ratified

Speaker: NA
Text: by a federal government, the ratification

Speaker: NA
Text: extends to all the constituent states, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vinces, etc. Therefore it would not

Speaker: NA
Text: now be appropriate for us to try to ratify

Speaker: NA
Text: any convention which was not being fully

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to all State governments. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: back of this motion which seeks ratification

Speaker: NA
Text: of International Labour Organisation con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions-whic h we certainly press on with

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as opportunity permits and as early

Speaker: NA
Text: as practicable-i s a rather theoretical,

Speaker: NA
Text: unreal approach to real problems which lie

Speaker: NA
Text: behind ILO conventions. What matters is

Speaker: NA
Text: what happens in fact, not what bits of paper

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's practice is well in advance of

Speaker: NA
Text: set many of these ILO conventions. The ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is: What standards does one apply?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite evident from the reports and the

Speaker: NA
Text: that a large number of countries

Speaker: NA
Text: who have subscribed and signed and

Speaker: NA
Text: adhered to conventions apply them in a

Speaker: NA
Text: very simple and inadequate fashion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: of them in many cases is rather

Speaker: NA
Text: vague, and this leads to loose interpretations

Speaker: NA
Text: applied. Many countries ratify lightly

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas countries such as Australia have

Speaker: NA
Text: been completely scrupulous in keeping every

Speaker: NA
Text: be convention they have signed. The purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of these conventions is, firstly, to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: uplift and improve labour conditions in the

Speaker: NA
Text: member countries. In early days in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: it. ticular much stress was placed on inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national competition and on the view that

Speaker: NA
Text: an industry of one country should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: not handicapped by applying higher standards

Speaker: NA
Text: its work force than in other countries

Speaker: NA
Text: consequent higher costs. It was argued

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore that all countries ought to come

Speaker: NA
Text: It should be recognised, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, that in the past the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Organisation has addressed itself

Speaker: NA
Text: point very largely to the requirements of

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced industrial countries. The kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions which might apply in western

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe and which have occupied so much

Speaker: NA
Text: time in thc past in many cases are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: inapplicable to newly developing countries

Speaker: NA
Text: which constitute a large part of ILO mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bership. We regard ourselves effectively as

Speaker: NA
Text: being part of the Asian group of ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. We meet as part of the Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: group. 1 attended a conference in Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: in September of last year. From our col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leagues in this field we do get the reaction

Speaker: NA
Text: that ILO is wrapped up in the conventions,

Speaker: NA
Text: which apply to western Europe and does

Speaker: NA
Text: not pay sufficient attention to the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: practical uplift and improvement in working

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions which is needed in this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: We now have an Asian manpower plan

Speaker: NA
Text: for Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand. It

Speaker: NA
Text: much more important for these countries

Speaker: NA
Text: to get practical aid in improving conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: than it is to concentrate on ILO conventions

Speaker: NA
Text: which are often designed just for western

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. Recently I visited Kuala Lumpur

Speaker: NA
Text: at the invitation of Mr Manickauasagan,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Labour in Malaysia, and

Speaker: NA
Text: also Singapore. The aid which wc are

Speaker: NA
Text: this area receives good support from both

Speaker: NA
Text: the trade unions and the employer groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the part of the world in which

Speaker: NA
Text: live and we should concentrate very heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: in ILO in protecting their interests

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Oxley) [3.58]-Th e con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions of the International Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation feature a number of relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: moderate recommendations concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: the material and also the spiritual welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: of nations and their people. When 1 speak

Speaker: NA
Text: about spiritual welfare, I do not speak in

Speaker: NA
Text: the narrow theological sense but rather in

Speaker: NA
Text: the very broad sense of the quality of life

Speaker: NA
Text: and values which people accept and are

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged to develop. They are very

Speaker: NA
Text: important recommendations. I stress that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are quite moderate recommendations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having studied the recommendations, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is nothing extremely radical about them and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly nothing which would be inappro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate to the Australian community. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: to indicate witb a few pointers that the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations are quite appropriate to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's needs. Therefore I am some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what surprised at the attitude of the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Labour and Industry ( Mr Bury).

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two things I want to speak Minister for Labour and National Service

Speaker: NA
Text: about in relation to the Minister's speech-

Speaker: NA
Text: two pretexts which he put forward as

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for the Government not involving

Speaker: NA
Text: itself in a greater number of ratifications of

Speaker: NA
Text: JLO conventions. Firstly, he said we are

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Asian area and he spoke about poor,

Speaker: NA
Text: humble, underdeveloped little Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the implication of what he says in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to conferences, discussions, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on of the ILO. Then he spoke about the

Speaker: NA
Text: huge developed industrial societies which

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk large and overshadow os. With the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest respect for the Minister- I do have

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal of respect for him personally

Speaker: NA
Text: - I think that the views, political ones on

Speaker: NA
Text: this occasion, which he has put in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House are a lot of humbug. They remind

Speaker: NA
Text: me of the occasion a couple of years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Minister for Trade and Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: is ( Mr MCEwen) went to Geneva to speak on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of Australia and represented Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia as a struggling, backward, under-

Speaker: NA
Text: developed country. Petty, in one ol" his

Speaker: NA
Text: pungent, satirical cartoons, defined the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister as receiving the award lor

Speaker: NA
Text: the actor of the year. Surely this year we

Speaker: NA
Text: could give the award for the actor of the

Speaker: NA
Text: giving year to the Minisler for Labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service for trying to picture our

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in handling ILO conventions as

Speaker: NA
Text: we being related to our backwardness as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the overall backward Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: and ours. bloc of countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 come now to the passing of the buck

Speaker: NA
Text: syndrome-th e Commonwealth and State

Speaker: NA
Text: financial relations. He spoke about this at

Speaker: NA
Text: some length in relation to the problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal pay for women in the work force.

Speaker: NA
Text: What he ought to appreciate is that very

Speaker: NA
Text: largely the problems of the States in

Speaker: NA
Text: financing their various ventures arise from

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that increasingly they are being

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to amass a greater debt while at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time the Commonwealth is writing off

Speaker: NA
Text: its debt. So per capita the indebtedness of

Speaker: NA
Text: people under State administration is rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: enlarging whilst at the Commonwealth level

Speaker: NA
Text: it is decreasing and before long may be

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminated. The Commonwealth is the

Speaker: NA
Text: organ which has the authority to regulate

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. It is a clever but unconvincing pretext

Speaker: NA
Text: that he has put forward to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only 26 of the 128 conventions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO have been ratified by Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: compared this with the performance of

Speaker: NA
Text: countries with advanced economies. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is a contradiction here. Towards the latter

Speaker: NA
Text: part of bis speech he spoke about Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's problems as a member of the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: developed Asian bloc, but earlier he talked

Speaker: NA
Text: about Australia as compared with countries

Speaker: NA
Text: with advanced economies, with which he

Speaker: NA
Text: identified Australia. But let us neglect this

Speaker: NA
Text: unhappy contradiction. Comparing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia with other countries with advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies he said that the record was not

Speaker: NA
Text: a bad one. Let us look at the record more

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate to his Government's term of

Speaker: NA
Text: office. Only two conventions have been

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified since his Government came into

Speaker: NA
Text: office in 1949-Conventio n No. 105. relat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the abolition of forced labour, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention No. 116, relating to the revision

Speaker: NA
Text: of final articles. These were ratified in 1957

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1961 respectively. We have been a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Organisation since 1919 yet

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been two ratifications in the

Speaker: NA
Text: period of nearly 20 years during which this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government bas been in office. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: he is not satisfied.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to speak about Convention No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 107, which is an extremely appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: convention for Australians to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned to ratify a long time ago. It

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to tribal and semi-tribal populations

Speaker: NA
Text: and thc need to promote continued action

Speaker: NA
Text: to improve the living and working condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of these people by various forms of

Speaker: NA
Text: action. The appropriateness of this is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: current. Part If of this Convention relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to land rights and Article 11 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The right of ownership, collective or individual,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the members of the populations concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: the lands which these populations traditionally

Speaker: NA
Text: occupy shall be recognised.

Speaker: NA
Text: Article 13 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Procedures for the transmission of rights

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership and use of land which are established

Speaker: NA
Text: by the customs of the population concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: be respected. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a vitally important convention for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Australians must feel embarrassed,

Speaker: NA
Text: first of all, to find that only 26 out of

Speaker: NA
Text: 100-odd conventions bave been ratified by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. They must be more embarrassed

Speaker: NA
Text: to find that in the period of nearly 20 years

Speaker: NA
Text: during which this Government has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: office only 2 have been ratified. They must

Speaker: NA
Text: feci quite humble to discover that amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: those which bave not been ratified is this

Speaker: NA
Text: convention relating to the protection and

Speaker: NA
Text: integration of indigenous and other tribal

Speaker: NA
Text: and semi-tribal populations in independent

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. Al tbe present time the Yirrkala

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals at Gove are expressing their

Speaker: NA
Text: concern-the y have taken the issue to court

Speaker: NA
Text: -a t the way in which the Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has aided and abetted an outside

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation- a private enterprise organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which has gone roughshod into their

Speaker: NA
Text: sacred tribal lands and exploited these lands

Speaker: NA
Text: for private profit.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth) put the rights of the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people very clearly in this House a few

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago when he said that we as a Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean advanced society would be appalled

Speaker: NA
Text: if someone said that a Catholic priest had

Speaker: NA
Text: to disclose Ihe details of a confession or

Speaker: NA
Text: that a Mason had to disclose details of
