Speaker: NA
Text: the private procedures at a Masonic meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, yet we feel no revulsion and no alarm

Speaker: NA
Text: when a private organisation is able to move

Speaker: NA
Text: into traditional Aboriginal grounds and

Speaker: NA
Text: desecrate those grounds. Clearly there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a complete disregard for tbe rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of these people and it is in conflict with

Speaker: NA
Text: the undertakings which we would have had

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept if we had ratified Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: No. 107. So it becomes obvious that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have not ratified Convention No. 107 not

Speaker: NA
Text: because, as tbe Minister suggests, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: problems in obtaining the agreement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: various State governments throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth but because his Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is one of the main offenders against

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of tribal and semi-tribal people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Australian community. I am certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: not expunging any criticism or guilt of the

Speaker: NA
Text: over State governments. They are certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for a great deal of this kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of treatment of these people. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Government itself has to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: of standards here and has not done so. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is the main reason why the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: shall has not ratified Convention No. 107.

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention No. 100, with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Stirling dealt, relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to equal remuneration for female workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely it is a society based on discrimina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which allows a discrimination to exist

Speaker: NA
Text: against women in their pay rates, merely

Speaker: NA
Text: because they are women. Frankly, my feel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on the equal remuneration case is that

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not women are doing the same

Speaker: NA
Text: work as men, the fact is that they are in

Speaker: NA
Text: the work force and are entitled to the same

Speaker: NA
Text: level of wages as males are receiving. I see

Speaker: NA
Text: no problem in providing them witb these

Speaker: NA
Text: wages. If in fact there would be immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: economic problems in providing the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk of these wages in one movement, why

Speaker: NA
Text: not stagger it over 2 or 3 years? A case

Speaker: NA
Text: against this has yet to be established and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am yet to be convinced. Finally, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned in any event as to whether, if

Speaker: NA
Text: we had signed or ratified this Convention,

Speaker: NA
Text: we would have fulfilled our obligations,

Speaker: NA
Text: because in Article 23 (2) of the Universal

Speaker: NA
Text: Declaration of Human Rights of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations we ourselves have to provide equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for females in the work force. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have never fulfilled this obligation, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: wc voted in support of this recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Under the International Covenant on

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic, Social and Cultural Rights there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a clear obligation in Article II of Fart 1

Speaker: NA
Text: to eliminate poverty in our community and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have not done this at the present time.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Parkes) [4.8]- I have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened with interest to the contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: so far made in this debate by the two

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition speakers, the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Stirling ( Mr Webb) and the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Oxley ( Mr Hayden). The

Speaker: NA
Text: impression with which I am left is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: attack which the Opposition has sought to

Speaker: NA
Text: mount against the Government is based

Speaker: NA
Text: firstly-here I refer particularly to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Stirling-o n

Speaker: NA
Text: selective and therefore misleading quotation

Speaker: NA
Text: of statistics. The second impression that 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have is that the Opposition just failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the basic problem involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: ratifying International Labour Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions, particularly in the case of a

Speaker: NA
Text: country with a federal system of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. First let me deal with the selective

Speaker: NA
Text: quotation of random statistics by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Stirling. He sought

Speaker: NA
Text: to suggest, by reference to the record in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to ratifications by other countries,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are countries with unitary systems

Speaker: NA
Text: of government and not federal systems of

Speaker: NA
Text: government, that Australia has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: laggard.

Speaker: NA
Text: The matter was placed in its correct

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective by the Minister for Labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service ( Mr Bury), because he

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out that Australia's record, by com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parison with other countries with a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: and not a unitary system of government, is

Speaker: NA
Text: one with which Australia can well a/ford to

Speaker: NA
Text: be satisfied. We have ratified 26 of the ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions.. Canada has ratified 24, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States has ratified 7. So it is

Speaker: NA
Text: hardly to the point for my honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: friend from Stirling to make some criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's performance by reference

Speaker: NA
Text: solely to the record in relation to ratifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions by such countries as be mentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of these was Italy which, as we all

Speaker: NA
Text: know, has a unitary system of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me come next to the other point I

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned by way of criticism of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's attack, if one can call it an attack.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition's approach reflects a b;;sic

Speaker: NA
Text: failure to understand the essential problems

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the ratification by a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government of ILO conventions. J can make

Speaker: NA
Text: the point by reference to the very mailer

Speaker: NA
Text: which was argued by tbe honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Oxley in relation to Convention 107

Speaker: NA
Text: which deals with land rights and other rights

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to tribal and semi-tribal people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would venture a passing criticism of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Oxley's contribu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to this debate. He referred to tbe Gove

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute in which we all know there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine legal problem as to the rights of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals at Gove in relation to land said

Speaker: NA
Text: to be tribal land. He referred to that dispute.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: l t is not a legal problem, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a problem of ethics.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Th e honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Wills is always interrupting stud

Speaker: NA
Text: always blowing forth a lot of air but never

Speaker: NA
Text: saying very much, and be is running true

Speaker: NA
Text: to form this afternoon. T am trying to make

Speaker: NA
Text: a serious contribution to this debate and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman might listen to me in

Speaker: NA
Text: silence for once. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Oxley referred to this question of the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights in respect of lands at Gove as though

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter was already concluded in favour

Speaker: NA
Text: of the tribal Aboriginals there. The point

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make is that the dispute is dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinctly sub judice. The case is presently

Speaker: NA
Text: pending in the Supreme Court of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory and it is therefore not

Speaker: NA
Text: a fit subject to raise at this stage on the floor

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House. But be that as it may. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member in his argument has

Speaker: NA
Text: glossed over a basicflaw.He must know-o r

Speaker: NA
Text: if he does not know he ought to know and

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps I can enlighten him if he needs

Speaker: NA
Text: enlightening or will take enlightenment-

Speaker: NA
Text: that questions of laws relating to land

Speaker: NA
Text: tenure are essentially matters within Stale

Speaker: NA
Text: jurisdiction except, of course, in Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the position-an d this I would

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the honourable member for Oxley to

Speaker: NA
Text: think about-i n the case of the Federal Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment? Is the Government lo ratify a

Speaker: NA
Text: convention just because it is prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply a convention so far as application

Speaker: NA
Text: depends upon federal jurisdiction and

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation upon federal laws? Or

Speaker: NA
Text: should the Government- I suggest it should

Speaker: NA
Text: -tak e inio account the fact that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be quite improper for it as a federal go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment, lo ratify a convention unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: State jurisdictions were exercised in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same way as the Federal Government pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to exercise federal jurisdictions in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the implementation of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention? It would be a gross breach of faith

Speaker: NA
Text: for a federal government such as the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government to ratify a convention

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to land tenures unless it were cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain in advance of ratification that State

Speaker: NA
Text: governments would come into line. It is idle

Speaker: NA
Text: for anyone on the Opposition side of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House to suggest that the ground has been

Speaker: NA
Text: laid or may be laid for Commonwealth Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment ratification of Convention 107

Speaker: NA
Text: because the necessary foundation for rati-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication is lacking inasmuch as State governhas

Speaker: NA
Text: ments have not agreed and, for all 1 know,

Speaker: NA
Text: show no signs of agreeing to render tbeir

Speaker: NA
Text: laws uniform to the point at which it could

Speaker: NA
Text: be said that the Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment could bona fide ratify this convention

Speaker: NA
Text: or treaty.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why 1 say that the Opposition's

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism is based upon a fundamental mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: conception of the whole nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. It is very easy to make a super-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficial attack upon the Government based

Speaker: NA
Text: upon what is really a selective misquotation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the relevent statistics and to gloss over

Speaker: NA
Text: the underlying problem. Let me inform the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that prior to 1946 a government

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Commonwealth Government-

Speaker: NA
Text: a federal government-coul d ratify an ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: convention while limiting its ratification

Speaker: NA
Text: federal jurisdiction. In 1946, as the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition ( Mr Whitlam) will well

Speaker: NA
Text: know, the constitution of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Organisation was amended so as to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide in substance that any federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government, if it ratified a convention,

Speaker: NA
Text: would be taken to do so in an overall sense

Speaker: NA
Text: so that the ratification would extend to

Speaker: NA
Text: matters lying within State jurisdiction. In

Speaker: NA
Text: that state of affairs- I mention this for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of emphasis-i t would be not only

Speaker: NA
Text: idle but also bad faith for the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government at this stage, in the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement by all the State governments on

Speaker: NA
Text: any particular topic, to ratify conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: If, as 1 hope it will, this becomes under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood by the members of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: the weakness of the arguments they have

Speaker: NA
Text: sought to propound this afternoon will

Speaker: NA
Text: become apparent to any of them with any

Speaker: NA
Text: common sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another point which should not

Speaker: NA
Text: go unnoticed. If Australia ratines a parti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cular convention we undertake and bind

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves in advance, according to the

Speaker: NA
Text: charter or constitution of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Organisation, to be bound not by

Speaker: NA
Text: our interpretation of what the convention

Speaker: NA
Text: means and our interpretation of the obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions which it expresses or implies but by

Speaker: NA
Text: the interpretation not of our own Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: meni legal adviser but of a committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: experts set. up to interpret the text of the

Speaker: NA
Text: convention. This is in itself a very sound

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for adopting a cautious approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: the ratification of these conventions. No

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition supporter so far this afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned the fact that in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom where, as we all know, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a Labour government-perhap s for not

Speaker: NA
Text: very much longer-whic h has announced

Speaker: NA
Text: categorically that it will not ratify Conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 100 on equal pay for women.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Werriwa-Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition) [4.18]-Th e Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: brought up for discussion the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing record on the ratification and

Speaker: NA
Text: application ol International Labor Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation conventions. It is quite clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: Government supporters from the Minisler

Speaker: NA
Text: down are seeking to justify that record. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me reiterate the facts. The ILO Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: has adopted 128 conventions. Of these, 26

Speaker: NA
Text: to have been ratified by Australia. Nineteen

Speaker: NA
Text: of those ratified were adopted at pre-war

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO Conferences. There have been 61 con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions adopted since the war and 7 have

Speaker: NA
Text: been ratified by Australia. There have been

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 conventions adopted during the 1950s

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1960s, that is, in the time of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Liberal Government. Of those 30

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions 18 have been supported at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference by the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives and 2 have been ratified by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: This month, as my colleague the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Stirling ( Mr Webb)

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, is the 50th anniversary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO. Our record, which is bad and getting

Speaker: NA
Text: worse, shows that the present Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has little regard for the organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation of which Australia was a foundation

Speaker: NA
Text: member. We have troubles as a federal

Speaker: NA
Text: state, like Canada, whose record is slightly

Speaker: NA
Text: inferior to ours, but at least Canada has

Speaker: NA
Text: had a spate of ratifications in the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: years under the Pearson Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we compare ourselves with all of our

Speaker: NA
Text: trading partners, particularly those in

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, we find that their record is

Speaker: NA
Text: immeasurably better.

Speaker: NA
Text: The greatest attention in today's

Speaker: NA
Text: debate has been directed to the Equal

Speaker: NA
Text: Remuneration Convention of 1951. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: a convention upon which Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government representatives abstained from

Speaker: NA
Text: voting. They nevertheless supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation. Under the recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion the Government has an obligation to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the application of the principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: equal remuneration for men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: workers for work of equal value in all

Speaker: NA
Text: central government departments and agen-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies, to encourage the application of the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle to employees of State, provincial

Speaker: NA
Text: or local authorities or agencies and to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: the application of the principle as regards

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and services where such rates are

Speaker: NA
Text: determined under public authority, indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries and undertakings operated under public

Speaker: NA
Text: ownership or control and, where approp-

Speaker: NA
Text: riate, work executed under the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: public contracts. It is quite clear that under

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendation, which the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government supports, we have had, since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1951, the obligation to provide equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Commonwealth Public Service, in

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth instrumentalities and under

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth contracts. We have not

Speaker: NA
Text: done so. We cannot hide behind the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Conciliation and Arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission in these matters. As a nation

Speaker: NA
Text: we have an obligation to apply this prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple in these Commonwealth fields of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the federal public services in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States and Canada and in the unitary

Speaker: NA
Text: public services of Britain and New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: equal pay has long since applied. While

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada and the United States have not

Speaker: NA
Text: ratified the Equal Remuneration Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: at least 70% or 80% of their total popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion enjoys equal pay because the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial states of tbe United States and

Speaker: NA
Text: provinces of Canada have legislated for the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle. There were interjections earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: about the position of the only Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in Australia, that in Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: As tbe Premier of Tasmania pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: in his policy speech last night, efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide legislation for equal pay linger

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial awards had been thrown out by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Legislative Council, which limited equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay to State government employees. So

Speaker: NA
Text: much for equal pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a field in which the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth clearly has sole authority, namely

Speaker: NA
Text: our overseas territories, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory of Papua and New Guinea.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are ten conventions which are directly

Speaker: NA
Text: applicable to that Territory. We abstained

Speaker: NA
Text: from voting on two of them; we have

Speaker: NA
Text: applied none of them. To its non-metro-

Speaker: NA
Text: politan territories in the Pacific, Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain has applied six of them, New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand six and France two. No arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: commission is required here. All that we

Speaker: NA
Text: bave to do is honour the obligations which

Speaker: NA
Text: we have assumed under the body of which

Speaker: NA
Text: we were a founding member 50 years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, the Commonwealth has the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility as regards Aboriginals, the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest number of whom live in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory. It did not require the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1967 referendum to give the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth authority to apply in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory International Labour Organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions-th e Indigenous and Tribal

Speaker: NA
Text: Populations Convention of 1957 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Discrimination (Employment and Occupa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion) Convention of 1958. We did not do

Speaker: NA
Text: so. We are in fact pursuing the policy which

Speaker: NA
Text: we followed in those years at the ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: conferences where we abstained from voting

Speaker: NA
Text: on both of those conventions. Finally, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth has the overwhelming

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility in navigation. Nearly all Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian shipping is interstate or overseas;

Speaker: NA
Text: very little is intrastate. As regards interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: and overseas and territorial shipping, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has complete power to apply ILO

Speaker: NA
Text: maritime conventions. We have not done

Speaker: NA
Text: so. In fact, we have had tbe ludicrous

Speaker: NA
Text: spectacle of legislation amending the Navi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation Act to permit compliance later being

Speaker: NA
Text: repealed before we had in fact ratified the

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: As regards equal pay, overseas territories,

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals in the Northern Territory,

Speaker: NA
Text: navigation between the States and to other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries: In every case we have failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: carry out our international obligations. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition, under the 1946 amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ILO constitution the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has an obligation to arrange for periodical

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations between Federal and State,

Speaker: NA
Text: provincial or cantonal, authorities with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to promoting within the Federal State

Speaker: NA
Text: co-ordinated action to give effect to the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of such conventions and recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations. These efforts take place at a

Speaker: NA
Text: low level-th e annual conference in April

Speaker: NA
Text: of Departments of Labour, between officials

Speaker: NA
Text: who have proved notably ineffective in

Speaker: NA
Text: persuading their ministerial masters or who

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been apprised sufficiently of our

Speaker: NA
Text: international obligations. International con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferences may be attended by persons nomin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ated by tbe Commonwealth alone. The

Speaker: NA
Text: States have no international standing what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever. As a matter of practice the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth has, since the post-war Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government, nominated a represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative of tbe State governments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual ILO conferences. We have the

Speaker: NA
Text: ludicrous situation where the States obstruct

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth in carrying out obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions undertaken at conferences where they

Speaker: NA
Text: have no standing. We make our federal

Speaker: NA
Text: system a farce where we undertake obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions which we. then allow our constituent

Speaker: NA
Text: States to frustrate. Our obligation since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946 has been to arrange for periodical

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations. Answers to questions which

Speaker: NA
Text: I regularly ask about ILO conventions

Speaker: NA
Text: illustrate that there has been scant effort by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to secure State col-

Speaker: NA
Text: laboration even on those matters where the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth itself has the greatest obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, as in navigation, Aboriginals and equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay. If it were not for debates of the kind

Speaker: NA
Text: we have initiated today this subject would

Speaker: NA
Text: never be debated in the Parliament. State-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which Ministers make to the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are never debated. I can find no

Speaker: NA
Text: record of any debate in Parliament on state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments about annua] ILO conferences.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The ment

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr HALLEIT
Text: Canning) [4.28]-I

Speaker: NA
Text: raising this matter today the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to what it describes as the Governdebating

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's disappointing record in the ratifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and application of International Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation conventions. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parkes ( Mr Hughes) dealt in

Speaker: NA
Text: some length with the difficulties, mainly of a

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery nature, in ratifying many of

Speaker: NA
Text: these conventions. These difficulties are well

Speaker: NA
Text: known. We have our difliculties even in

Speaker: NA
Text: ratifying agreements between management

Speaker: NA
Text: and labour in this country. When you get

Speaker: NA
Text: into the international field obviously the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties will be multiplied many times

Speaker: NA
Text: over.

Speaker: NA
Text: In claiming that the Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing record in these matters it is

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious that the Opposition is referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of equal pay. This is the crux

Speaker: NA
Text: of the whole business. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Stirling ( Mr Webb) said, if I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember his remarks correctly, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had failed to promote the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cept of equal pay. It is on this claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition bases its submission that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's record is disappointing.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we combine these two particular issues,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the responsibility of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring about a position of equal pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: the sexes in Australia? It must be well

Speaker: NA
Text: known that what we would have to do in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, or in any other country, is

Speaker: NA
Text: to create a climate whereby the principle

Speaker: NA
Text: of equal pay could be introduced, if this

Speaker: NA
Text: is lhe requirement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's responsibility, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: see it, is twofold. Firstly, it has to set up

Speaker: NA
Text: certain machinery to deal with this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this case the machinery would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Commission. This has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: existence for many years. Any disputes

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding wages have been dealt with by

Speaker: NA
Text: a commission or body set up for the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular case. This is the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. Secondly, as 1 see it, it is the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government's responsibility to make

Speaker: NA
Text: certain things possible. It surprises me that

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter has been brought forward at

Speaker: NA
Text: this time. If, in fact, we did not have at

Speaker: NA
Text: this particular time a registered unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: figure of a little over 1%, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that we would not be debating this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular matter today. If, for instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: n there were an unemployment figure of

Speaker: NA
Text: has 3% or 4% we certainly would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: it today. We are debating this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter because conditions have been estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished in Australia in which we are still

Speaker: NA
Text: very short of labour, notwithstanding the

Speaker: NA
Text: rapid influx of newcomers to this country

Speaker: NA
Text: under our migration programme. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is in fact in dire need of more labour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore an atmosphere has been estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished in wbich we can perhaps discuss

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: I come to the question of whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is opposed to this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of equal pay for the sexes. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly not opposed to the principle. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has made it perfectly clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not opposed to the principle of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for equal work. So having created the

Speaker: NA
Text: position in wbicb we can employ more

Speaker: NA
Text: people than are available at the moment, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that we are putting ourselves in thc

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in which we can support such a

Speaker: NA
Text: measure in a practical way, not merely in

Speaker: NA
Text: words or on pieces of paper. They would be

Speaker: NA
Text: empty words or empty paper if we were to

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate a principle but were not in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to do anthing practical about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would be the case if the economy were

Speaker: NA
Text: not sound and if the state of the labour

Speaker: NA
Text: force was not sucb that we could not absorb

Speaker: NA
Text: extra labour. But that is not the case in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. 1 think that one of our greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: problems today is that we want more skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: labour in Australia. One of our greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: inflationary pressures at the present time

Speaker: NA
Text: results from the fact that we do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient labour to carry out the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment work thai is confronting us.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the first obligation of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is to create a healthy climate in which these

Speaker: NA
Text: things can be done. If this is not done, then

Speaker: NA
Text: it is empty words to suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government recommends that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: be done. The Government does not oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of equal pay for the sexes and

Speaker: NA
Text: has not opposed it in the United Nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is perhaps the highest authority in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world in which these matters can be

Speaker: NA
Text: debated. The Government has agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions on this question which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: moved at the United Nations, lt did not vote

Speaker: NA
Text: for them, but tbat is only a technical point.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has agreed to the principle not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia but also in the wider field of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations. It is clear to me that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a matter on which we should make any

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions in this House. It should be left to

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriate authority. Could you

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine anything worse than the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the day making decisions in its own

Speaker: NA
Text: right in relation to wbat wages or salaries

Speaker: NA
Text: should be paid within the nation? What a

Speaker: NA
Text: chaotic situation that would create. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why I said when I first rose to speak that

Speaker: NA
Text: I was a little surprised that this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: should be debated at this particular time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps we do not always agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: the decisions which are made in some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, but J believe that the correct policy

Speaker: NA
Text: is lo have a tribunal to sort out the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular issues. That is the only fair and

Speaker: NA
Text: just way in which a case can be debated

Speaker: NA
Text: and in which each side of an argument

Speaker: NA
Text: can be put in an unbiased way before an

Speaker: NA
Text: independent commission. It is not for

Speaker: NA
Text: governments and it is not for parliaments

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with these matters, other than to

Speaker: NA
Text: set up the machinery. 1 repeat again that

Speaker: NA
Text: in this atmosphere and with the machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: we have in Australia, the first responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility of the Government is to maintain a

Speaker: NA
Text: stable economy and to attract to this

Speaker: NA
Text: country the right sort of industries which

Speaker: NA
Text: can in fact employ labour-no t only men

Speaker: NA
Text: but women. As we know, many women

Speaker: NA
Text: are in employment in Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Governinent has a responsibility to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain employment, and this has been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my own State the registered unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment figure was approximately .7% or

Speaker: NA
Text: .8% for a long time. It is slightly higher

Speaker: NA
Text: than that at the present time, but it is fall-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing again. In my book, it is too high and

Speaker: NA
Text: it results in inflationary pressure. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has a responsibility to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that a balance is maintained. It is not for

Speaker: NA
Text: a government to sort out differences of

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion between employers and employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government simply has to set up the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary machinery. As thc honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parkes ( Mr Hughes) pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out, there are six State governments also

Speaker: NA
Text: to be consulted regarding the ratification

Speaker: NA
Text: of the particular conventions of which we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been speaking this afternoon. The

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure is even more complex in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia than it is in many other countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not an easy matter to sort out all thc

Speaker: NA
Text: problems associated with international

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions. It is difficult enough to sort

Speaker: NA
Text: out the many complications in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that the Government has carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out its responsibilities in establishing tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: climate whereby this principle of equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for equal work can be introduced. The

Speaker: NA
Text: technical details can be overcome.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: WUls) [4.37]-Di d 1 hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Canning ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hallett) aright when I heard bim suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are at a stage of over full employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: I n fact, unemployment is

Speaker: NA
Text: part and parcel of his philosophy. He does

Speaker: NA
Text: not look like that kind of a person. The

Speaker: NA
Text: matter seems to be quite foreign to what we

Speaker: NA
Text: are debating this afternoon and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: general principles of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Organisation. Of course, we know

Speaker: NA
Text: that honourable members opposite do not

Speaker: NA
Text: care a darn when people are out of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are more concerned with inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: than they are with people. It is time that

Speaker: NA
Text: they started to apply themselves to the

Speaker: NA
Text: human problem which is before the House

Speaker: NA
Text: this afternoon. We have listened to a suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cession of speakers, including apologists

Speaker: NA
Text: for inaction, inequality, inability and insin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerity who are capable of any slide of lan-

Speaker: NA
Text: guage or of logic rather than looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject fairly and squarely. Today we are

Speaker: NA
Text: discussing Australia's attitude to conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in accordance with its membership of

Speaker: NA
Text: the International Labour Organisation, of

Speaker: NA
Text: which we were a foundation member and

Speaker: NA
Text: of which we have been a continuing mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber. In some ways it is an admirable orga-

Speaker: NA
Text: nisation, as far as its structure is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments send to the organisation dele-

Speaker: NA
Text: gates from employers, employees and go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment sources, all, I understand, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to vote as they think fit when

Speaker: NA
Text: they get there. It is an estimable organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in that regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been disappointing that honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite do not face up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of where our responsibilities really

Speaker: NA
Text: lie. We have heard so much this afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: about how difficult it is to do things. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Parkes ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes)-h e has fled the field but I have

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt he will return because he is a

Speaker: NA
Text: man of great honour and intrepid political

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity but with a lack of sagacity in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter-sai d that we were unable to face

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the basic difficulties in ratifying this

Speaker: NA
Text: question in a federal system. This afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: an attempt was made to dodge the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: by means of a point of order which was

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by my friend the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Higinbotham ( Mr Chipp), and by means

Speaker: NA
Text: of remarks in the debate to the effect that

Speaker: NA
Text: some questions which we bave raised today

Speaker: NA
Text: are sub judice. The subject of equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for women is supposed to be sub judice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The matter of land rights of Aboriginals is

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to be sub judice. I for one, speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the forum of this Parliament, do not

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that sanction whatsoever. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament must be in a position at any time

Speaker: NA
Text: to discuss whatsoever it needs to discuss and

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to discuss. It ought not be restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: in any way in these discussions.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are our duties? It has been said

Speaker: NA
Text: here that wc should look at comparable

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. In fact, there are very few com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parable countries. Of the 130 nations in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world very few have our standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living and very few now have continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: political stability. But of those 130 nations

Speaker: NA
Text: only some 30 or so could claim to be

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic, taking the most liberal view of

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy. Only 12 or 15 countries would

Speaker: NA
Text: measure up to the kind of society most of

Speaker: NA
Text: us want to live and play a part in. Until

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 or 3 years ago there were only four

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in which there were no political

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoners and Australia was one of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I. am afraid we have spoilt our record by

Speaker: NA
Text: the way we have treated conscientious

Speaker: NA
Text: objectors. So we are not here this afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: to follow other people. It is time Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: started to set some standards. Australia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: foundation member of and played a form-

Speaker: NA
Text: ative part in the creation of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. Our responsibility here today is to

Speaker: NA
Text: see whether we can apply the principles

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been worked out at these inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national organisations, to get them cracking

Speaker: NA
Text: in this community and not look continuously

Speaker: NA
Text: for an escape hatch.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like my colleagues the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Oxley ( Mr Hayden) and the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition ( Mr Whitlam) I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the question of the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia and talk about our

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility there, because our responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities are now clear-cut. Has my friend,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Parkes not

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that in 1967, some 2 years ago, the

Speaker: NA
Text: people accepted a referendum proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: which placed the responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal people fairly and squarely on

Speaker: NA
Text: this House, and that in fact the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: system no Longer need apply in this regard,

Speaker: NA
Text: if we have the sense, the wit and

Speaker: NA
Text: moral attitude towards

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals of Australia, 21,000 of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: live in the Northern Territory. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: also the responsibility to apply the high

Speaker: NA
Text: principles which are expressed in the prestates:

Speaker: NA
Text: amble to the amended constitution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Labor Organisation which we

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted when we put it into the Act in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1947-49. I t reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: The High Contracting Parties, moved by sentiis

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of justice and humanity as well as by

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to secure the permanent peace of the

Speaker: NA
Text: and with a view to attaining the objectives

Speaker: NA
Text: forth in this Preamble, agree to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: tion:

Speaker: NA
Text: Now let me come to ILO Convention No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 107. How is it that we are unable to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: this convention? It seems to me that the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues are clear-cut and that our responsipeople

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities are well defined. Our constitutional

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities now Jie with this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Morally and in every other way it is our

Speaker: NA
Text: bounden duty to get on with the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Article 2 of the Convention states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Government shall have the primary responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for developing co-ordinated and systematic

Speaker: NA
Text: for the protection of the populations concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: and their progressive integration into the life

Speaker: NA
Text: their respective countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is nothing in that section which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been beyond the scope of this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has been the case since May 1957, at shall

Speaker: NA
Text: least. Article 3 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . special measures shall be adopted for

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of the institutions, persons, property

Speaker: NA
Text: labour of these populations.

Speaker: NA
Text: This afternoon the point was made that we

Speaker: NA
Text: may not bring up the question of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Yirrkala, who I believe are being visited

Speaker: NA
Text: trampled on rather unceremoniously,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the matter is sub judice. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is that the culture and institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: these people are not being treated with

Speaker: NA
Text: proper regard. This would also apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals at Wattie Creek and other

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals in other parts of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two or three other instances in

Speaker: NA
Text: which people are being moved off their

Speaker: NA
Text: land and that land is being taken over

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial purposes. Article 4 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention states:

Speaker: NA
Text: due account shall be taken of the cultural and

Speaker: NA
Text: religious values and of the forms of social control

Speaker: NA
Text: Have we really observed that? Do we really

Speaker: NA
Text: the right observe it even in Papua and New

Speaker: NA
Text: the 80,000 Guinea where, strange to say, we bave

Speaker: NA
Text: often been more tender about the rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: the people than we have about the rights

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Aboriginals in Australia. Article 6

Speaker: NA
Text: The improvement of the conditions of life and

Speaker: NA
Text: work, and level of education of tbe populations

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned shall be given high priority . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: What have we done in that field? There

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to stop us. No State government

Speaker: NA
Text: the is going to cavil if we produce plans which

Speaker: NA
Text: world, are definite and dynamic in the field of the

Speaker: NA
Text: set development of Aboriginals and of their

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Organisaeducation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I visited Yirrkala as recently as January.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been there four or five times in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 5 or so years. On each occasion I have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken a look to see what steps have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken for the vocational training of these

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet the confrontation which will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen as a result of the mining develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I can see very little evidence of any

Speaker: NA
Text: such steps. Article 9 of the convention states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Except in cases prescribed by law for all citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: the exaction from the mcmbers of the populations

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned of compulsory personal services . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: action shall be prohibited. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: of Do we take any steps to see that on pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: properties and other places this type of

Speaker: NA
Text: service is not exacted from the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people? Article 10 of the Convention states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Persons belonging to the populations concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: be specially safeguarded against the improper

Speaker: NA
Text: application of preventive detention. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: thc It is time we did something about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: and Back in January, accompanied by some of

Speaker: NA
Text: my colleagues, I. visited the Woorabinda

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement in Queensland. An apologist for

Speaker: NA
Text: the system from the Melbourne 'Herald'

Speaker: NA
Text: the place a few days later and said:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Well, the prison was all right. It was cooler

Speaker: NA
Text: inside the prison than it was in the office.'

Speaker: NA
Text: of The prison, in fact, was as I described it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was similar to the cells which were used

Speaker: NA
Text: the at Port Arthur over a century ago. The

Speaker: NA
Text: prison in this Aboriginal settlement con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sisted of 8 ft by 10 ft reinforced concrete

Speaker: NA
Text: cells. The prisoners are locked up in them

Speaker: NA
Text: for 14 days for the vicious and deplorable

Speaker: NA
Text: for and abominable crime of overdrinking. I

Speaker: NA
Text: say it is a pity this punishment was not

Speaker: NA
Text: applied-speakin g a.s a wowser-t o a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of other people i f this is the system that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to adopt. But, of course, we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: apply it to others.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I am saying this afternoon is that

Speaker: NA
Text: most of the principles contained in Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention 107 are ones most members of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House would adopt in their personal rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionships. They are mostly ones that people

Speaker: NA
Text: here would say are correct and in line with

Speaker: NA
Text: the generally established ethics and morality

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people of this community. I can think

Speaker: NA
Text: of no sound reason why Convention 107

Speaker: NA
Text: ought not be adopted. It may well be that

Speaker: NA
Text: until the referendum in 1967 the Conven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion could not have been ratified because

Speaker: NA
Text: there were 6 State authorities and 2 Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth authorities, 1 here and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory. It also may well

Speaker: NA
Text: be that this matter was complicated by State

Speaker: NA
Text: rights and such things. But that situation no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer exists. The political power, the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitutional authority and the dynamics of

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole system lie in this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: While one may be able to say about equal

Speaker: NA
Text: wages-an d I do not agree with it-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: there are constitutional difficulties, and

Speaker: NA
Text: while this may apply to some other con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention, it does not apply to Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: 107. It ought not apply to Convention 111

Speaker: NA
Text: and it should not apply to any of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventions that are applicable to our external

Speaker: NA
Text: territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, this afternoon, when we say we are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned and disappointed at the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's failure to establish principles of policy

Speaker: NA
Text: in line with ILO conventions, we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking here just simply for the sake of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics. We are speaking because we believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this field at least Australia has the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity and the social dynamics established

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past to set up standards for the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world and should not wait for some-

Speaker: NA
Text: one else to set the signpost up for us.

Speaker: Mr CHIPP
Text: Higinbotham) [4.48]-

Speaker: NA
Text: Today we have had a very clever subterfuge

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrated on this House by honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Opposition. I suppose it is

Speaker: NA
Text: good tactics in an election year to propose

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of public importance for discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House each day. It gives the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion a chance of obtaining headlines, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is good tactics. I can visualise the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion that was held by the Executive of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party when it met

Speaker: NA
Text: tbis week. When someone said: 'Well, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, what is the matter to be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed for discussion on Wednesday?', I can

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine the honourable member for Stirling

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Webb) would have chimed up and said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'What about giving equal pay another run?'

Speaker: NA
Text: Someone with some sense of honour would

Speaker: NA
Text: have said: 'No, we cannot do that because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is being discussed at the moment by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Commission'. Now we see the subter-

Speaker: NA
Text: fuge- a rather clever one. Equal pay is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the item on the agenda; it is the ratification

Speaker: NA
Text: of the International Labor Organisation's

Speaker: NA
Text: conventions. Once the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Stirling paid lip service to this for about

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 seconds, he then proceeded for the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of his speech to discuss equal pay. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was notwithstanding a point of order 1 took.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am glad I did this because I was able to

Speaker: NA
Text: register my deep concern. I now re-register

Speaker: NA
Text: my concern, Mr Deputy Speaker. While

Speaker: NA
Text: paying ultimate courtesy to Mr Speaker and

Speaker: NA
Text: to yourself, I think this Parliament is drift-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing into a very dangerous method of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedure if, when a matter is before a court,

Speaker: NA
Text: or a body such as the Commission, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has all the stature and facilities of a court,

Speaker: NA
Text: that matter is allowed to be debated by

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians in the heat and the cut and thrust

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliamentary debate..If this is done I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the integrity of one of our most

Speaker: NA
Text: precious institutions, the judiciary, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: under some threat.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, having made that comment,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I do with respect, let me come back

Speaker: NA
Text: to the substance, if one can so natter it, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter of public importance which is

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Chair. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Stirling, who is a notoriously gallant

Speaker: NA
Text: man as far as ladies are concerned, ended

Speaker: NA
Text: his speech with a rather extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on the women of today. He said-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I hope I do not misquote him-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: the women of today do not have the sting

Speaker: NA
Text: and the courage of their counterparts 50

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago. I hope the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Watson ( Mr Cope) will admonish his

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague for being so ungallant in this the

Speaker: NA
Text: twentieth century. What a dreadful thing to

Speaker: NA
Text: say! Why blame the women of today for

Speaker: NA
Text: the present situation? The honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Stirling, who has had considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in the trade union movement,

Speaker: NA
Text: knows very well that no trade union in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has raised the question of equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay since this Government has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: office. The Government came into office in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1949. For 19 years the trade union move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has not brought this matter before an

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial tribunal in any form. With

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to you, Sir. I challenge any honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member opposite to quarrel with that

Speaker: NA
Text: by way of interjection. They cannot because

Speaker: NA
Text: it is an absolute fact. Instead, we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: facade of an equal pay debate raised twice

Speaker: NA
Text: a year in this Parliament by Opposition pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: licity seekers to keep the pot boiling as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as the women are concerned. I take

Speaker: NA
Text: objection to the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Stirling blaming the women of today for

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation which exists.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to refer briefly to the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Organisation conventions themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Stirling and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Whitlam)

Speaker: NA
Text: know full well that the ILO conventions

Speaker: NA
Text: are not adopted, cannot be adopted and

Speaker: NA
Text: were not meant to be adopted by all mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber states attending ILO conferences. The

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics would in a flash indicate that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is true. The average number of ratifications

Speaker: NA
Text: per member nation is 29. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Stirling knows this. Why does

Speaker: NA
Text: he not say so and put his case in proper

Speaker: NA
Text: context? Australia has ratified 26 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions which have been brought for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward. Some of the resolutions brought for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward are clearly inappropriate to Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the honourable member well knows.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada hns ratified only 24 and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States only 7. Of course, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member would be aware of this. He would

Speaker: NA
Text: also know that under the constitution of

Speaker: NA
Text: the ILO a membeT state is not obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: ratify a convention and that until a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vention is ratified by a member state that

Speaker: NA
Text: state has no obligation to obey it. On this

Speaker: NA
Text: point I wish to refer to the comments made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Leader of the Opposition. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman makes an outward

Speaker: NA
Text: fetish of credibility. He has an obsession

Speaker: NA
Text: about the credibility of other people. He

Speaker: NA
Text: should look inwards at some stage and

Speaker: NA
Text: examine his own credibility. He said that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia now has a legal obligation under

Speaker: NA
Text: the conventions to grant equal pay and other

Speaker: NA
Text: things. So that I cannot be accused of being

Speaker: NA
Text: inaccurate in quoting what he said today,

Speaker: NA
Text: I will also quote what he said on 18th May

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965. It appears at page 1565 of Hansard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Referring to equal pay, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth now has some obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, he is on record as having said it.

Speaker: NA
Text: he knows as well as anybody else in

Speaker: NA
Text: place tbat Australia has no legal obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: to follow these conventions until it has in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact ratified them. As the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Canning ( Mr Hallett) said, we rely

Speaker: NA
Text: on the conciliation and arbitration system

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring changes of wage conditions and

Speaker: NA
Text: wage rates into being.

Speaker: NA
Text: I come now to the effect of equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: on the economy. I state categorically that

Speaker: NA
Text: I am for equal pay. I have stated this before.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I want it implemented in such a way

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will not fracture our economy or

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage the women who now consti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute 30% of the work force. Over 1.5

Speaker: NA
Text: million females are now in the work force.

Speaker: NA
Text: What would be the effect on certain indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries, such as the food processing industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the textile industry, where a predomi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nance of females is employed, if equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for work of equal value were immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: impacted on them? The obvious result would

Speaker: NA
Text: be wholesale unemployment of women in

Speaker: NA
Text: those industries and skyrocketing costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: These industries are a very important and

Speaker: NA
Text: significant component of the cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: structure which affects the working man.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the Opposition want this Parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: without the expertise and analytical back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground of a full scale investigation, which

Speaker: NA
Text: only the Commonwealth Conciliation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Arbitration Commission can undertake, to

Speaker: NA
Text: pluck a figure out of the air-sa y $200m,

Speaker: NA
Text: $300m or $400m-a s an estimate of what

Speaker: NA
Text: equal pay would cost the economy without

Speaker: NA
Text: going into it in a scientific way? The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition regards this subject as a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: definite public importance and has brought

Speaker: NA
Text: on the debate on that basis. I regard the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's attitude as sheer humbug be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the Commonwealth has already made

Speaker: NA
Text: it quite clear in the case that is being heard

Speaker: NA
Text: at present, as the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Stirling would know, that it does not object

Speaker: NA
Text: to equal pay. Mr Woodward, Q.C, has

Speaker: NA
Text: stated the Commonwealth's position. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth is in favour of it. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: pleaded with the Commission not to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: any undue delay in its decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, may I add one more

Speaker: NA
Text: the remark of my own? I hope that equal pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for women will be with us soon because

Speaker: NA
Text: I have never been persuaded of the justice

Speaker: NA
Text: or the equity of a breadwinner in a family

Speaker: NA
Text: who docs precisely the same work as a

Speaker: NA
Text: But man and with equal efficiency having to

Speaker: NA
Text: this go home with a pay packet which is

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced by 25% and look after an aged

Speaker: NA
Text: or ill mother. The same applies with a

Speaker: NA
Text: widow who has to look after 3 or 4

Speaker: NA
Text: children. I make the plea that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: made before in this House: If the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: misison does not see its way clear to equate

Speaker: NA
Text: wage levels at this point of time, will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government take action of a social services

Speaker: NA
Text: nature to equate the income of the female

Speaker: NA
Text: breadwinners in a family with that of their

Speaker: NA
Text: male counterparts until such time as equal

Speaker: NA
Text: pay is instituted for equal work?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Lucock)

Speaker: NA
Text: -Th e discussion is now concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1969

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 26 March (vide

Speaker: NA
Text: page 917), on motion by Mr Swartz:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Erwin- Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek

Speaker: NA
Text: the indulgence of the House to raise a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of procedure. This Bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pay-roll Tax Assessment Bill are associated

Speaker: NA
Text: measures. It would no doubt meet the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: venience of honourable members if the

Speaker: NA
Text: House were to have a general second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading debate covering both Bills. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion of the debate separate questions

Speaker: NA
Text: will, of course, be put on each of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills. Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: you permit this course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ther e being

Speaker: NA
Text: no objection, I will allow this course to

Speaker: NA
Text: followed.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Melbourne Ports) [4.59]-

Speaker: NA
Text: These Bills involve technical amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Income Tax Assessment Act and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pay-roll Tax Assessment Act respectively.

Speaker: NA
Text: The short title of each Bill seems to have

Speaker: NA
Text: been carefully chosen so as to preclude

Speaker: NA
Text: general debate on income tax and pay-roll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax matters. The first Bill is described as

Speaker: NA
Text: a Bill for an Act to amend sections 23c

Speaker: NA
Text: and 160AC of the Income Tax Assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1936-58 and to make certain conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quential provisions. The second Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a Bill for an Act to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pay-roll Tax Assessment Act 1941-1968

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to rebates of tax allowable to

Speaker: NA
Text: producers of gold.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, both sets of amendments to each

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Bills deal with the taxing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sales of gold. This, I suppose, arises from

Speaker: NA
Text: what is now described as the 'two tier

Speaker: NA
Text: system' of gold pricing. Certain gold, in as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as it enters into central banking trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: actions, is sold at a fixed price of SUS35 an

Speaker: NA
Text: ounce, and it has been set at tbatfigurefor

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 40 years now. However, certain gold

Speaker: NA
Text: is allowed to be sold on what is described

Speaker: NA
Text: as the 'free market'. Much of it is sold in

Speaker: NA
Text: Hong Kong, some in Australia and some on

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial markets in various parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. But it has been the practice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government, and of previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian governments, to subsidise the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of gold by, in effect, making it free

Speaker: NA
Text: from the impact of income tax. If a profit is

Speaker: NA
Text: made from gold mining it is not liable to

Speaker: NA
Text: bear any income tax at all. This has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a deliberate policy of governments and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the gold industry in Australia today

Speaker: NA
Text: is confined primarily to one State, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: one very small part of that State-t o the

Speaker: NA
Text: city of Kalgoorlie and the areas around

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. Slightly less than 1 million ounces

Speaker: NA
Text: of gold per annum is still mined in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, most of it from the Kalgoorlie fields,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it earns foreign exchange for Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: of about $30m to $35m.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here we have one of the sections of our

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax legislation-and , to a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: extent, the same applies to pay-roll tax, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause pay-roll tax is related to the provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: that exempt from payment of pay-roll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings that improve export sales dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the year-wher e forms of taxation are

Speaker: NA
Text: being used to secure what essentially are not

Speaker: NA
Text: be revenue provisions at all. We are endeavour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to obtain what we call 'desirable econo-

Speaker: NA
Text: mic and social practices' by reason of the

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions that are available in our taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion legislation. I have in my possession a

Speaker: NA
Text: document that I secured from the office of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer ( Mr MCMahon) a short time

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. It is entitled 'Income Tax for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mining Industry' and contains some 80

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly closely printed pages indicating the

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions that are available to the gold

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry and also for the search and

Speaker: NA
Text: production of oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent days there has been quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: debate in the financial Press about the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions which were ostensibly designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to encourage the search for and the produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of oil in Australia. No-one would deny

Speaker: NA
Text: that oil has great economic significance for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, because we bave an annual bill

Speaker: NA
Text: amounting to some hundreds of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars for the import of oil. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is a country where the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of motor cars has increased rapidly. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the motor car population is rising at a

Speaker: NA
Text: faster rate than is our population, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: places a great toll upon our roads and

Speaker: NA
Text: upon petrol and so forth. All of our petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements, or most of them until last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, came from overseas. In order to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage the search for and the extraction

Speaker: NA
Text: of oil certain concessions were given in

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax provisions. They had the bless-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings of both sides of the House when they

Speaker: NA
Text: were passed but recently it has seemed

Speaker: NA
Text: that the provisions that were thought to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the search for and the physical

Speaker: NA
Text: production of oil are being used by people

Speaker: NA
Text: for purely speculative purposes. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment Australia is being obsessed by what

Speaker: NA
Text: might be called a 'speculamania' which goes

Speaker: NA
Text: all the way from the price of individual

Speaker: NA
Text: pieces of land to the search for minerals

Speaker: NA
Text: and natural resources. Again, one cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be too categorical about this.

Speaker: NA
Text: I noticed yesterday that when a question

Speaker: NA
Text: was addressed to the Treasurer he was

Speaker: NA
Text: rather cautious in his answer. I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps he had reason to be cautious be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause, unfortunately, it is difiicult sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: to determine who is a speculator and who

Speaker: NA
Text: is a genuine investor serving the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: that the provisions were designed to cover.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is why I repeat a suggestion that I

Speaker: NA
Text: made on another occasion in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the provisions are too complicated

Speaker: NA
Text: in their nature and, in essence, they do

Speaker: NA
Text: not collect tax, they rather see that tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: npt collected. They have a sort of negative

Speaker: NA
Text: effect which is designed to promote the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic benefit that the Government hns

Speaker: NA
Text: in mind. I submit thaf many of these pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: positions are too complicated io be satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factorily evaluated by the ordinary legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive processes that are available to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. I point out that part of the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for the amendments being before us today

Speaker: NA
Text: is the discovery that the legislation does not

Speaker: NA
Text: do what it was intended to do. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, there are mistakes in the wording

Speaker: NA
Text: of the legislation which, consequently, does

Speaker: NA
Text: not give effect to the intent of the legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. This seems to me to be the case

Speaker: NA
Text: at present. An argument is going on about

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not certain calls and certain

Speaker: NA
Text: capital subscriptions to oil companies

Speaker: NA
Text: ought or ought not to be allowable for taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion purposes. I submit that when a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: is as important as this there ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: some machinery by means of which these

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints can be properly evaluated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes I am astonished at the things

Speaker: NA
Text: that nnancial journalists regard as imagina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. This is a little bit off the trail of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, but it is relevant to the argument that

Speaker: NA
Text: I am following. I refer to the enthusiasm

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been engendered among nnancial

Speaker: NA
Text: journalists for the new device called the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'certificate of deposit'. Apparently if a

Speaker: NA
Text: person holds a deposit, provided he has

Speaker: NA
Text: units of $50,000-whic h takes it out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: province of most men in the street-an d

Speaker: NA
Text: turns the deposit from a fixed deposit into

Speaker: NA
Text: some other kind of account at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: bank, it can earn him something like

Speaker: NA
Text: another i % . Why this is supposed to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mote the economic development of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is beyond me. Nevertheless there are

Speaker: NA
Text: people writing in nnancial journals who get

Speaker: NA
Text: enthusiastic about this thing. 1. submit that

Speaker: NA
Text: something of the same kind of hysteria has

Speaker: NA
Text: crept in recently concerning the condem-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation of the practices that are going on

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of investments in oil companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think that anybody denied originally

Speaker: NA
Text: that the provisions of the law were bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficial, but if the provisions are being

Speaker: NA
Text: breached for other than the development

Speaker: NA
Text: reason, there is a case for re-examining the

Speaker: NA
Text: law. In order that the law may be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: examined it should be open for considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion by people other than the experts in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department and the experts who mani-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulate activities on the stock exchange.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other genuine pockets of interests

Speaker: NA
Text: in the community in which there are people

Speaker: NA
Text: who deserve to have access to the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: information that is necessary to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: proper appraisal of this sort of situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the matter is important

Speaker: NA
Text: because in the mineral field-an d here we

Speaker: NA
Text: are talking about only one mineral, gold-

Speaker: NA
Text: we talk about spending in the next 2 or

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 years as much as $1,500m or $2,000m.

Speaker: NA
Text: To some extent the question of where that

Speaker: NA
Text: money is spent is conditioned by the taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion concessions that are allowed. To a

Speaker: NA
Text: great extent the Commonwealth is under-

Speaker: NA
Text: writing this kind of expenditure by revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: forgone, but sometimes the transactions are

Speaker: NA
Text: encompassed in such a way that they yield

Speaker: NA
Text: gains to sections of the community in the

Speaker: NA
Text: form of capital accretions that are not

Speaker: NA
Text: always easily tied down for taxing purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: For this reason we must have a much more

Speaker: NA
Text: sophisticated approach to amendments of

Speaker: NA
Text: this kind than is the case at present. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: competent for a parliament to argue about

Speaker: NA
Text: the incidence of income tax and the rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of income tax as these affect individuals in

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. It is competent for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament to consider what is the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of tax, what is taxed and what is not

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed. The same applies to a great extent

Speaker: NA
Text: to the basic rate of company tax. I t is when

Speaker: NA
Text: we come to these special kinds of provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: that we should be especially careful.

Speaker: NA
Text: The taxing of insurance companies, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, is another way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax legislation is used as a means

Speaker: NA
Text: of achieving what are thought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable social objectives, although they

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be directly connected with the

Speaker: NA
Text: collection of income tax itself. Often

Speaker: NA
Text: matters of this kind are so complicated in

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves and can become so esoteric that

Speaker: NA
Text: the ordinary person can know very little

Speaker: NA
Text: about them. Often the first he hears of them

Speaker: NA
Text: is when somebody complains that a racket

Speaker: NA
Text: is being worked, if I may use a term that

Speaker: NA
Text: is sometimes employed in this connection.

Speaker: NA
Text: A famous judge many years ago in England

Speaker: NA
Text: said that every person was entitled so to

Speaker: NA
Text: manage his own economic affairs that he

Speaker: NA
Text: paid the minimum of tax that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: legally obliged to pay. Nevertheless, if

Speaker: NA
Text: clever people try to drive coaches and

Speaker: NA
Text: horses through the spirit of the law. the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislature is entitled to take its remedy by

Speaker: NA
Text: closing the loophole that allows that avoid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. I know that some people are very

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive about whether one should use the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'evade' or the word 'avoid'. One can

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes cloak what one's left hand is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing by making that kind of dubious dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinction. It is a fact that in many cases as

Speaker: NA
Text: soon as a provision is made in the law some

Speaker: NA
Text: clever person seeks a way to get round it,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that way usually enhances his income

Speaker: NA
Text: and often destroys the very principle on

Speaker: NA
Text: which the concession in question had been

Speaker: NA
Text: granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not make any judgment one way

Speaker: NA
Text: or the other in the argument that is going

Speaker: NA
Text: on about calls and subscriptions in oil com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies other than to suggest that the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be probed very carefully by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury. I think also that other bodies of

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion ought to be given a chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate their views, and that we should not

Speaker: NA
Text: simply accept the opinion of the two sets

Speaker: NA
Text: of experts who are involved. Having made

Speaker: NA
Text: these few additional remarks, Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: I may say that the Opposition offers no

Speaker: NA
Text: objection to either of these measures we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been discussing. They merely tidy up

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies that should be corrected.

Speaker: NA
