Text: Question resolved in the afiirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be

Speaker: NA
Text: moved forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Swartz) read a

Speaker: NA
Text: third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: PAY-ROLL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 26 March (vide

Speaker: NA
Text: page 917), on motion by Mr Swartz:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in tbe affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: The BiM.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Darling Downs-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for Civil Aviation) [5.18]- I refer to clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 which reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: After section 71 of the Principal Act the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing heading and Schedule are inserted:-

Speaker: NA
Text: "THE SCHEDULES

Speaker: NA
Text: "FIRST SCHEDULE Section 16x.

Speaker: NA
Text: TABLE FOR ASCERTAINING THE PRESCRIBED RATIO

Speaker: NA
Text: FOR THE PURPOSES OF SECI ION I6X

Speaker: NA
Text: Column 1 Column 2 Column 3

Speaker: NA
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: Omit from column 2 of the proposed First

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule the figures " 23,476", insert the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: This amendment will correct an error in

Speaker: NA
Text: column 2 of the proposed first schedule in

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 5 of the Pay-roll Tax Assessment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 1969. It will substitute the figure of

Speaker: NA
Text: 46,854 for the figure of 23,476 first appear-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in column 2 of that schedule. The figure

Speaker: NA
Text: to be replaced was wrongly calculated. The

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the figures set out in the schedule

Speaker: NA
Text: is explained in the notes relating to para-

Speaker: NA
Text: graph (A) of the definition of 'the prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: ratio' at page 9 of the printed explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum to the Bill which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: circulated. The amendment now proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: will not involve any change in the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of the schedule as explained in the printed

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum. It will simply increase to

Speaker: NA
Text: what it should be the proportion, represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing gold sold for industrial use in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: by which the value of export sales of gold

Speaker: NA
Text: producers for the base period year 1960-61

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be reduced.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Melbourne Ports) [5.19]-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has no objection to accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this amendment. I must say, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it supports one of the contentions 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have been putting this afternoon, that these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters are so complicated that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: to rely on this kind of information being

Speaker: NA
Text: provided from outside. I am sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation would have gone through just as

Speaker: NA
Text: easily with the one figure as with the other.

Speaker: NA
Text: This in my view reinforces the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: some different kind of process at least for

Speaker: NA
Text: examining these aspects of taxation legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion where the Government is endeavour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to give a benefit not directly related

Speaker: NA
Text: to the tax concerned and where the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions are of a complicated kind. With

Speaker: NA
Text: these few remarks, I indicate that the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition accepts the amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill reported with an amendment; report

Speaker: NA
Text: -b y leave-adopted .

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Swart/)-b y leav.;

Speaker: NA
Text: -rea d a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUDIT BILL 1969

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 26th March (vide

Speaker: NA
Text: page 919), on motion by Mr Swartz:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Melbourne Ports) [5.22]-

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments contained in the Bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: described as technical amendments but i'ney

Speaker: NA
Text: are different to those of the Income Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Assessment Bill and the Pay-roll Tax Assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bill. It seems to me that the short

Speaker: NA
Text: title of the Bill is wide enough to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: a general debate on all the principles of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Audit Act. This is a Bill for an Act relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the audit of public moneys and the

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of public property, and it seeks

Speaker: NA
Text: to amend the Act of 1901-64, which has thc

Speaker: NA
Text: broad title 'An Act to make provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: the collection and payment of the public

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys the audit of the public accounts

Speaker: NA
Text: and the protection and recovery of public

Speaker: NA
Text: property and for other purposes'.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the most part the amendments deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with the handling of what is described as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General's warrant. It is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the established practices of British par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liamentary procedures, which Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: follows, that no sum of public money

Speaker: NA
Text: should be expended unless that expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: has the sanction of Parliament. We go

Speaker: NA
Text: through the process annually of passing a

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget which is supposed to authorise the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of every single dollar that is

Speaker: NA
Text: spent by the Commonwealth of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in a period commencing on 1st July of one

Speaker: NA
Text: year and concluding on 30th June in the

Speaker: NA
Text: following year. That period is known as a

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year. It is true that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: one or two measures to bridge the gap

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by the fact that Parliament does

Speaker: NA
Text: not meet on lst July to determine expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture for the next 12 months. The Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: does not come down until August, and by

Speaker: NA
Text: that time almost 2 months of the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year have passed. So supply is provided

Speaker: NA
Text: in advance. And because modern govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments cannot always conceive at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of a year what is likely to happen

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of it provision is made for

Speaker: NA
Text: Supplementary Estimates. Also in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: we have what is called the Treasurer's

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance where a block sum of about $20m

Speaker: NA
Text: is set aside for expenditure for which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer can give authority until finally it

Speaker: NA
Text: is sanctioned in the Supplementary Esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each Government department does not

Speaker: NA
Text: get at the beginning of a year all the

Speaker: NA
Text: money that it wants during the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: that. year. It receives its money by a series

Speaker: NA
Text: of dribblings out. There are two reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: for that. First, it enables some control to

Speaker: NA
Text: be kept. If all of us were to have our

Speaker: NA
Text: annual salary paid in advance we might

Speaker: NA
Text: not be quite as prudent as we are when

Speaker: NA
Text: paid each fortnight or each month. We

Speaker: NA
Text: tend to budget during the course of the

Speaker: NA
Text: year and so to some extent can exercise

Speaker: NA
Text: control. The other reason is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government does not collect all its money

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately. Taxes are paid throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the year. Direct taxes are paid periodically

Speaker: NA
Text: as people receive their assessments, and

Speaker: NA
Text: indirect taxes are paid daily as people

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase items such as motor vehicles, beer

Speaker: NA
Text: and cigarettes. It is for those two reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: that departments cannot be paid their full

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement when the Budget is approved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, I suppose that in a strict

Speaker: NA
Text: sense once the Budget has been passed

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Parliament has approved the total

Speaker: NA
Text: amount that is payable to a department,

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not matter a great deal whether,

Speaker: NA
Text: as was previously the case, it is paid

Speaker: NA
Text: quarterly for groups of items, or, as is now

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed, item by item.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would tbink that in 1969 we ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a different eoncept of what is des-

Speaker: NA
Text: cribed broadly as the auditing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government accounts to what we had in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1901 when the Audit Act was first passed.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 have not had the opportunity to see what

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of fundamental amendments have been

Speaker: NA
Text: made to the Audit Act since it was first

Speaker: NA
Text: passed, but I doubt whether if the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General were to follow the strict letter of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Act that would be a satisfactory way

Speaker: NA
Text: of looking after the financial undertakings

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government of Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General has perhaps had to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: discretionary powers that technically are

Speaker: NA
Text: written into the Act. I hope that he has.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the reasons for the amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: now before us is the influence, if you like,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the computer upon the processes of

Speaker: NA
Text: government accounting. I am one of those

Speaker: NA
Text: who still claim to be rather mystified by

Speaker: NA
Text: processes of the computer. I asked someone

Speaker: NA
Text: rather recently: 'How do you audit a

Speaker: NA
Text: computer?' He, being one of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: leading experts in this field, said: 'It

Speaker: NA
Text: bit harder to And the audit trial, but you

Speaker: NA
Text: feed your trial samples into the computer'-

Speaker: NA
Text: just the same, I presume, as happened with

Speaker: NA
Text: the checks in the old days when ledgers

Speaker: NA
Text: were hand processed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately this Bill was introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: into the House on the afternoon of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday on which the House adjourned

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Easter recess and I did not have time

Speaker: NA
Text: to go down to see the computer establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the Treasury building. What I did

Speaker: NA
Text: in the fortnight during the Easter break

Speaker: NA
Text: was to go into the Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and see the computer mechanism in

Speaker: NA
Text: operation there. The way in which the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: puter picks up mistakes is astonishing. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: was rather intrigued when shown a few

Speaker: NA
Text: samples of documents that had been put

Speaker: NA
Text: through the computer. One was returned

Speaker: NA
Text: because of a mistake by the clerk engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in manual operations who had written

Speaker: NA
Text: across the document '31st June 1969'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently the computer knew that old

Speaker: NA
Text: rhyme: Thirty days hath September, April,

Speaker: NA
Text: June and November'. Back the document

Speaker: NA
Text: came with the mistake corrected. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: only, 1 suppose, a minor kind of exercise.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nevertheless, the arrangements there enable

Speaker: NA
Text: about 200,000 cheques a fortnight to be

Speaker: NA
Text: issued. The Victorian office of the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Social Services accounts for about

Speaker: NA
Text: a quarter of total social service payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The annual bill for age pensions last year

Speaker: NA
Text: was about S520m-$10 m a week or $20m

Speaker: NA
Text: a fortnights-an d Victoria's share of that

Speaker: NA
Text: was about $5m a fortnight. The cheques are

Speaker: NA
Text: simply churned out like great rolls of

Speaker: NA
Text: paper. Even the signatures are applied non-

Speaker: NA
Text: manually.

Speaker: NA
Text: This brings home immediately that

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency in government departments and

Speaker: NA
Text: the efficacy of the audit are no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: questions of chasing money. I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been any large scale frauds in

Speaker: NA
Text: government departments recently. I noticed

Speaker: NA
Text: not that the Auditor-General drew attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: one in the Department of Customs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Excise, but apparently that involved col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lusion between people outside and people

Speaker: NA
Text: inside the Department. The handling of

Speaker: NA
Text: cash in departments no longer seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: the present a great problem. Auditing ought

Speaker: NA
Text: now to be turned in the direction of

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency of departments. There is no diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty, it seems to me, about whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: is a warrant is issued monthly, quarterly,

Speaker: NA
Text: annually, or item by item, or whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: signed or countersigned by this person rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than that. I would think that what is not

Speaker: NA
Text: properly evaluated often is what happens

Speaker: NA
Text: to the money once it starts to be used. Time

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a little against me in trying to find

Speaker: NA
Text: some references to this but I found a rather

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting publication recently. The book

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently coincides more or less with the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of the first 100 years of the Audit

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the United Kingdom. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled 'The Accountability and Audit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments, A Comparative Study', is

Speaker: NA
Text: written by E. L. Normanton, and was

Speaker: NA
Text: published by the Manchester University

Speaker: NA
Text: Press in 1966. Mr Normanton, it seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me, sums up very well the sort of problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am trying to indicate ought to concern

Speaker: NA
Text: us a bit more:

Speaker: NA
Text: If a Department had a large sum voted for

Speaker: NA
Text: 'purchase of (unspecified) supplies' and cared to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend it entirely upon green and yellow budgerigars,

Speaker: NA
Text: this would not be an infringement against regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larity, provided that the proper authorisation*

Speaker: NA
Text: were obtained and the birds were actually received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their utility to the nation would be 'an

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative question' outside the competence of

Speaker: NA
Text: a state audit body charged with the sole control

Speaker: NA
Text: of regularity. The Minisler concerned might have

Speaker: NA
Text: to face parliamentary criticism of his aviary, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the chances are that its very existence would not

Speaker: NA
Text: become known, since the auditors would not

Speaker: NA
Text: report a matter which was within the formal

Speaker: NA
Text: rules. In this way the confusion of control of

Speaker: NA
Text: regularity which a proper state audit often has

Speaker: NA
Text: covered, and in a few countries still does cover,

Speaker: NA
Text: a multitude of administrative sins. It has also

Speaker: NA
Text: obscured the meaning of audit to the state, by an

Speaker: NA
Text: oversimplification of its role.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would suggest that the title of the Audit

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1901-1964 certainly indicates an over-

Speaker: NA
Text: simplication of the role of audit.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the report of the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Board for the year ended June 1968,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General's Office has a total staff

Speaker: NA
Text: of 527. They deal with government trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: actions that employ some 211,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: and are responsible for an aggregate expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture of $6,000m. I do not think there is

Speaker: NA
Text: any substantia] financial fraud. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: occasional instances both in government

Speaker: NA
Text: departments and in private business. 1 was

Speaker: NA
Text: astonished the other day to read that at

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively minor metropolitan branch of a

Speaker: NA
Text: bank in New South Wales some character

Speaker: NA
Text: had got away with $320,000. I would not

Speaker: NA
Text: think that that kind of thing could happen

Speaker: NA
Text: in a government department unless there

Speaker: NA
Text: was collusion on a very substantia] scale.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of this aggregate expenditure of $6,000m administer.

Speaker: NA
Text: about $ 1,500m goes directly to the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: About $ 1,000m goes in expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: social service benefits which are transferred

Speaker: NA
Text: via the revenue system from taxes collected

Speaker: NA
Text: to people according to their categories of

Speaker: NA
Text: need. This still leaves a vast sum of about

Speaker: NA
Text: $3,000m. One category of expenditure alone

Speaker: NA
Text: -defence-account s this year for over be

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 1,200m. This is a matter that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to consider seriously.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have one very useful committee con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with this project-th e Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Accounts Committee. Some members of it

Speaker: NA
Text: are present, including its distinguished

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, the honourable member for Swan

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Cleaver). I believe that it does a very

Speaker: NA
Text: competent job but these days there should

Speaker: NA
Text: also be other committees. We suggest there

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be a separate defence estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: committee. I am not sure whether we ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to have Public Accounts Committees No. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: and No. 2, but there certainly should be a

Speaker: NA
Text: defence estimates committee. In another

Speaker: NA
Text: publication from the Manchester University

Speaker: NA
Text: Press entitled 'Public Sector Economies',

Speaker: NA
Text: edited by Professor A. R. Prest, is a chapter

Speaker: NA
Text: on measuring the efficiency of government

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure, which is what I am talking

Speaker: NA
Text: about this afternoon.

Speaker: NA
Text: They say this:

Speaker: NA
Text: An associated problem arises from the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: many government services are indivisible. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the defence programme is 'consumed'

Speaker: NA
Text: by the whole community. Only one level of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision is possible, and there is no agreed method

Speaker: NA
Text: by which the value of (benefit from) the service

Speaker: NA
Text: can be arrived at and imputed to individual

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the community. It also follows that

Speaker: NA
Text: even those who would not voluntarily contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the provision of such services may not bc

Speaker: NA
Text: able to be denied access to them. Market pricing

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be used to govern efficiency in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of such services, to which a 'principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: exclusion' cannot be applied. The level of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of services, and the allocation of their

Speaker: NA
Text: costs to individual citizens, thus becomes a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter for political bargaining.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have heard a lot of speeches in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: by members complaining about the fact thai

Speaker: NA
Text: the role of Parliament has been taken away

Speaker: NA
Text: a and that it has been assumed by the Execu

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. I do not believe that a government can

Speaker: NA
Text: govern in a modern sort of community

Speaker: NA
Text: unless it has strong executive powers, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that governments can make mistakes

Speaker: NA
Text: and that Ministers often do not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: time to check everything and to look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency of the departments that ihey

Speaker: NA
Text: The question arises of who ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for this overall efficiency. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe there is a better role that can still

Speaker: NA
Text: be played by the Parliament. After all, if a

Speaker: NA
Text: government decides on political grounds-

Speaker: NA
Text: and all these decisions ultimately tend to

Speaker: NA
Text: political-tha t it wants to spend $l,200m

Speaker: NA
Text: it should be as concerned as anybody else

Speaker: NA
Text: that it gets value for every $J that i i

Speaker: NA
Text: expended. It is not just a question of deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mining whether the office boy is rifling the

Speaker: NA
Text: morning tea money, although I think there

Speaker: NA
Text: is still sometimes a tendency to think that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is auditing. I am not being critical of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General's Department here

Speaker: NA
Text: because I think it is a very efficient depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and those officers that I have met-

Speaker: NA
Text: and I was a member many years ago of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts Committee-ar e men of

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable competence. But nevertheless

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 think that today we ought not to be just

Speaker: NA
Text: contemplating a few technical amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Audit Act; I think we should bc

Speaker: NA
Text: looking at this question as a whole.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Ther e is a further review.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: 1 know, and the further

Speaker: NA
Text: review has been promised for a very long

Speaker: NA
Text: time. It was even promised when I was a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Public Accounts Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and I ceased to be a member of that Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee in 1956, so it has been promised

Speaker: NA
Text: for a long time.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: I t is to be a part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: review.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Al l I am stating is that I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope when it does come that there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive amendments to the Audit

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. I am pleased to know that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Civil Aviation ( Mr Swartz) suggests that

Speaker: NA
Text: it will come. I hope that it will not be treated

Speaker: NA
Text: quite as hurriedly as these measures have

Speaker: NA
Text: been. 1 believe that this sort of proposition

Speaker: NA
Text: should lay on the table of the House for

Speaker: NA
Text: about 6 months so that people inside and

Speaker: NA
Text: outside government can examine it because

Speaker: NA
Text: after all the people outside the House whose

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes are being expended surely have some

Speaker: NA
Text: right also to indicate their satisfaction or

Speaker: NA
Text: dissatisfaction as to what might be called

Speaker: NA
Text: the efficiency audit of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: machine. I am not too sure that the Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General or his staff should necessarily be

Speaker: NA
Text: cast in this particular role or whether it

Speaker: NA
Text: needs superior mechanisms in the various

Speaker: NA
Text: departments. These are not easy matters. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: know one of the complaints of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nationalised industries in the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom many years ago when it was suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that their day to day activities should be

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to parliamentary scrutiny was that

Speaker: NA
Text: they could not be efficient if they felt that

Speaker: NA
Text: someone was breathing down their neck all

Speaker: NA
Text: the time. I do not know how close the

Speaker: NA
Text: breathing down the neck of government

Speaker: NA
Text: departments is, but nevertheless I tbink that

Speaker: NA
Text: when sums as large as is the case here are

Speaker: NA
Text: expended there should be some scrutiny.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, how does one evaluate govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment efficiency. One of these documents 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have quoted, and 1 do not want to quote

Speaker: NA
Text: any more of it now but I commend it to

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone who is interested in this kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, says that as far as national accounts

Speaker: NA
Text: are concerned-an d we talk about econo-

Speaker: NA
Text: mic growth and gross national product and

Speaker: NA
Text: what is called the contribution of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to the national product-thi s is mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in the salaries paid to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: servants who perform the tasks. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the way that the item of government pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction, or a large part of it, is entered into

Speaker: NA
Text: the national accounts. It is simply the

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries that are paid, and therefore one

Speaker: NA
Text: would get the rather curious result that the

Speaker: NA
Text: national income would appear to rise if there

Speaker: NA
Text: were more government servants and would

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to fall if a computer was installed

Speaker: NA
Text: and made a certain number redundant and

Speaker: NA
Text: they were released to go somewhere else. But

Speaker: NA
Text: if the computer was cheaper than the people

Speaker: NA
Text: disposed of-an d I have no doubt that that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the case-the n it would appear

Speaker: NA
Text: that the national income had fallen.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why sometimes strict accounting

Speaker: NA
Text: methods of evaluating efficiency are not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory. I have read, as I have no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of others have, about trying to subject

Speaker: NA
Text: government performance to what is called

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit cost analysis. I should think that

Speaker: NA
Text: while that kind of conjecture has some value

Speaker: NA
Text: in equating one proposition with another

Speaker: NA
Text: -i n choosing that one will do this rather'

Speaker: NA
Text: than do that-ther e is a large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: fields of government activity where such

Speaker: NA
Text: a method of assessing has no validity at all,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is why I think that other kinds

Speaker: NA
Text: of devices have to be applied to see whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government macnine, if you like, is

Speaker: NA
Text: being as effective in its performance as

Speaker: NA
Text: it ought to be. I will conclude there, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am glad of the assurance of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that more fundamental amendments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: law are contemplated, but I hope that when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are made that there will be adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion. I have no doubt that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: already been considerable discussion between

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General's Department and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts Committee on it, but if

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter finally is to become the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of legislation I think that at least members

Speaker: NA
Text: of tbe House and interested sections outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the House should be given the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to comment on the proposed amendments.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: Swan) [5.48]- 1 have

Speaker: NA
Text: followed the honourable member for Melliament

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Ports ( Mr Crean) with a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of interest. As usual the nonourabie member

Speaker: NA
Text: has brought to the subject of public

Speaker: NA
Text: accounting a broad expanse of experience

Speaker: NA
Text: both in the House and beyond it. 1 note

Speaker: NA
Text: bis reference to the possibility of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: committees. 1 am one who is beginning to

Speaker: NA
Text: fear that if the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: follows the line of the other House we will

Speaker: NA
Text: have members of this chamber so fully

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied with committee duty that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: never have time for other routine work.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not to say that I am not a supporter

Speaker: NA
Text: of the analyses that parliamentary coma

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees, select committees and others can

Speaker: NA
Text: make. I was a little concerned, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: when my friend from the Opposition report

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the possibility of a wider task

Speaker: NA
Text: to be performed by the officers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Auditor-General. He talked of

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency audits, and of getting down to

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of investigation that seem to me closer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Parliament itself and closer to

Speaker: NA
Text: committee activity. I would be one who

Speaker: NA
Text: would think that the task of the Auditormaking

Speaker: NA
Text: General is pretty clearly defined and has

Speaker: NA
Text: been magnificently performed. Speaking on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Parliamentary Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts, I would point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee has repeatedly paid tribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: the efficiency of the Auditor-General.

Speaker: NA
Text: would hope that we would not try to deflect

Speaker: NA
Text: him and his staff from a very clear-cut

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility, to which 1 would like to refer

Speaker: NA
Text: later in my remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 5.51 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: I n continuing my reand

Speaker: NA
Text: marks upon the Audit Bill which is before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, I would like to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Audit Act is, in my opinion, the fundamenmain

Speaker: NA
Text: tal legislation which supports the appropriabeen

Speaker: NA
Text: tion procedures, the control of funds and

Speaker: NA
Text: the preservation of the control of

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive by the Parliament itself. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are five principal stages in

Speaker: NA
Text: control over Commonwealth finances. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that my fellow members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House will agree that the first stage is

Speaker: NA
Text: preparation of the Budget and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Eslimates by departments, and that very

Speaker: NA
Text: close scrutiny which is given to those Esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates by Treasury. This, of course, is a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong system of control. Secondly, there is

Speaker: NA
Text: the consideration of the Estimates by Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: itself and the subsequent appropria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the necessary funds by Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, there is the execution of the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament's authorisation by the departments

Speaker: NA
Text: which receive the funds. We can see here

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a control to which I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: referring shortly when I refer to the war-

Speaker: NA
Text: rant system. Fourthly, there is that all im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant check by the Auditor-General and

Speaker: NA
Text: his staff. The Auditor-General is a statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: officer who brings his own report direct

Speaker: NA
Text: to Parliament. We can call this the fourth

Speaker: NA
Text: method of control. Lastly, in the name of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament we have here in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts Committee which carries

Speaker: NA
Text: out certain examinations according to the

Speaker: NA
Text: availability of time and presents its own

Speaker: NA
Text: to both Houses of the Parliament. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: felt that I ought to indicate that here was

Speaker: NA
Text: Coman inbuilt system of five varying stages

Speaker: NA
Text: which represents a control over the funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like much of tbe procedure of the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: liament itself, the financial procedures em-

Speaker: NA
Text: bodied in the Audit Act to which 1 am

Speaker: NA
Text: reference have so often an interest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing history and derive their form actually

Speaker: NA
Text: from the earlier steps taken by the Uniled

Speaker: NA
Text: on Kingdom Government to set up an adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme of control over the expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament. It is for this reason thai

Speaker: NA
Text: I in the debate tonight I want to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that I believe the Parliament should

Speaker: NA
Text: not permit an alteration to this type of

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional procedure which we find in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Audit Act without careful analysis. Altera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion surely should only be permitted when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament itself is convinced that cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances completely justify the change

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is in any amendment that is

Speaker: NA
Text: being approved no derogation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: authority of the Parliament. One of the

Speaker: NA
Text: features of this small Bill which has

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to by a previous speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think, as a 'technical Bill', is the change in

Speaker: NA
Text: the procedure concerning the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General's warrant. From my own

Speaker: NA
Text: the inquiries and the limited research I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to do 1 still find it possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: summarise the development of this warrant

Speaker: NA
Text: the system and the existing requirements under

Speaker: NA
Text: draft the Act as we know it today.

Speaker: NA
Text: No money may be withdrawn from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth public account unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General in advance gives his cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tificate that the moneys requisitioned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer are legally available and applicable

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purposes specified in the warrant.

Speaker: NA
Text: This procedure itself is of traditional im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance in the British concept of parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary control over expenditure, and I find

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was in existence in the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom even before there was an Auditor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General appointed. Prior to the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Auditor-General in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: place in 1866, the officer who was respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible was known as the 'Comptroller-

Speaker: NA
Text: General'. So we see that this function in

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with the use of a warrant was

Speaker: NA
Text: carried on after the Prime Minister of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day, Gladstone, felt that there should be not

Speaker: NA
Text: only a check on issues from the public

Speaker: NA
Text: account but also a check on how moneys

Speaker: NA
Text: were being spent. In my opinion it repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sents, therefore, a traditional control by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament over expenditure, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: is of significant importance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to a recent publication entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Government Accounting in Australia'. The

Speaker: NA
Text: very first article in this informative book

Speaker: NA
Text: was written some years ago by an esteemed

Speaker: NA
Text: former member of this House, who was the

Speaker: NA
Text: first Chairman of the Public Accounts Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee when the Committee was reconsti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuted in 1951. Of course, I refer to the late

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Francis Armand Bland. He wrote

Speaker: NA
Text: an article entitled 'Control of Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Expenditure'. I believe that as we look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Audit Act on this occasion we should

Speaker: NA
Text: not overlook what he said about this history.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The long struggle for control which began as

Speaker: NA
Text: far back as the Plantagenets and the Tudors

Speaker: NA
Text: to limit the access of the executive-th e Crown-

Speaker: NA
Text: to funds, and it has ended in surrendering to

Speaker: NA
Text: another executive-th e Cabinet-al l the powers

Speaker: NA
Text: it withheld from the Monarchs. It is a different

Speaker: NA
Text: executive, it is true, and it holds office not by

Speaker: NA
Text: divine right but by popular vote; but it is still

Speaker: NA
Text: the executive and it has attained the right to say

Speaker: NA
Text: how much is to be spent and for what purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: He then set out the highlights in the struggle

Speaker: NA
Text: for control over finance. He summarised

Speaker: NA
Text: them briefly as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) the insistence by the Commons that they

Speaker: NA
Text: should have the sole right to levy taxation; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) that the King should spend the money on

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose for which it was voted. These things

Speaker: NA
Text: were not achieved until the 1688 Revolution by

Speaker: NA
Text: which time the principle of annual appropriations

Speaker: NA
Text: was adopted. Taxes were levied annually. The next

Speaker: NA
Text: step was taken in 1834, when Departments had

Speaker: NA
Text: to submit accounts of their expenditure. Gradually

Speaker: NA
Text: this practice was made general, and in 1861

Speaker: NA
Text: Gladstone set up the Public Accounts Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: to examine the details of that expenditure sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted by the Departments to the Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The audit of the accounts developed indepen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dently. In 178S there were appointed the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioners for Auditing of the Public Accounts,

Speaker: NA
Text: but these were responsible to the Treasury. By

Speaker: NA
Text: 1834 they were made responsible to Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament was forced to become more interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in thc integrity of public ofncials and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: honesty and regularity of public accounting. Thus

Speaker: NA
Text: came the Exchequer and Audit Act, 1866, which

Speaker: NA
Text: required all Departments to render detailed Appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priation Accounts to Parliament duly certified

Speaker: NA
Text: by an accounting officer. These accounts had to

Speaker: NA
Text: be submitted to a new officer, independent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, called the Comptroller and

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally on this quote I refer to these words

Speaker: NA
Text: of the late Professor Francis Armand Bland:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Act also provided that the credits for the

Speaker: NA
Text: operations of the Departments made available to.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasury were to be issued by the Comptroller

Speaker: NA
Text: and Auditor-General. The Australian practice of

Speaker: NA
Text: obtaining Warrants is similar. The significance of

Speaker: NA
Text: this provision lies in the fact that it embodies the

Speaker: NA
Text: constitutional principle of prior Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: approval over all issues from the Exchequer.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is an appropriate reference to these

Speaker: NA
Text: warrants, which find a most important place

Speaker: NA
Text: in this amending Bill, in the 43rd report

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Parliament's own Public Accounts

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee. I simply draw attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraphs 18 and 19 of that report. Foi

Speaker: NA
Text: those honourable members who are interes-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted, it will be on record for detailed reading.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill, among other things, specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: removes the arbitrary provision of quarterly

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General warrants. It is to this

Speaker: NA
Text: point that I wish to speak rather specifically.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that if, with quarterly warrants,

Speaker: NA
Text: sought the Treasurer has had a form of control

Speaker: NA
Text: over the flow of expenditure within the year

Speaker: NA
Text: and he has had a device whereby he could

Speaker: NA
Text: curtail that flow in the public interest, one

Speaker: NA
Text: wonders whether, with the abolition of this

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary quarterly warrant system, he will

Speaker: NA
Text: now seek some other form of control. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of fact, in earlier thinking about

Speaker: NA
Text: this and in earlier general discussion it was

Speaker: NA
Text: my understanding that there was seen in the

Speaker: NA
Text: quarterly warrant a very valuable control.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe, for example, that the use of it

Speaker: NA
Text: had become traditional in the thinking of

Speaker: NA
Text: public servants, and perhaps of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Auditor-General and his staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, if it is to be removed, one wonders

Speaker: NA
Text: whether previous suggestions about another

Speaker: NA
Text: form of control to replace it have

Speaker: NA
Text: been discarded entirely or whether some

Speaker: NA
Text: other device not requiring the approval ot

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament is in mind.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dobie-I t has not been mentioned in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: No , there is no mention

Speaker: NA
Text: of this in the Bill. J think we can summarise

Speaker: NA
Text: the second reading speech of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Civil Aviation ( Mr Swartz) by saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that he stated that at present computerised

Speaker: NA
Text: methods provide information very quickly

Speaker: NA
Text: and as frequently as desired to the Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sury and to the many other Departments of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth administration. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister argued in his short speech that

Speaker: NA
Text: since the rate of expenditure can be ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: served much more readily the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a quarterly warrant has virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: disappeared. ]. believe he said that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore proposed to permit warrants to

Speaker: NA
Text: be obtained for the full amount appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priated. This would be done not at regular

Speaker: NA
Text: frequencies of every 3 months and the

Speaker: NA
Text: warrant would be not merely for the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be spent in that period of 3

Speaker: NA
Text: months or less. Therefore, no-one can argue

Speaker: NA
Text: against the statement that, for the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: in the long years of history under the Audit

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, we see a very important change. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: may have feared it.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 want to say, although 1 am underlining

Speaker: NA
Text: in my speech the value of much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: tradition of the Parliament and much of

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the traditional methods and

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures regarding appropriations, funds

Speaker: NA
Text: and controls that are written into the Audit

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, that 1 am one who believes that com-

Speaker: NA
Text: puterisation will have very wide ramifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions not only in parliamentary and govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment administration but, of course, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: field of general commerce. I believe we have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be flexible in our thinking and that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should be prepared to face rather drastic

Speaker: NA
Text: changes. Perhaps some of the traditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of Parliament will not be evident in 10 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 years time. Perhaps now, under this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, we will see a change along the lines

Speaker: NA
Text: of something that was said to me not so

Speaker: NA
Text: long ago by a very important official in

Speaker: NA
Text: this sphere. He said that he felt alterations

Speaker: NA
Text: were desirable. Even he, perhaps, has had

Speaker: NA
Text: to alter his mind in face of the facts brought

Speaker: NA
Text: out by the Treasurer and presented to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. Actually, on a previous occasion I

Speaker: NA
Text: argued that the specific quarterly warrants

Speaker: NA
Text: could perhaps be wasteful. I pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was a pressure to issue warrants

Speaker: NA
Text: quarterly through the Treasury, that these

Speaker: NA
Text: would all have to be checked by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Auditor-General and that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would all have to be presented to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General for his approval and

Speaker: NA
Text: signature. I actually raised this point in

Speaker: NA
Text: some remarks that I made: Could the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedure regarding warrants possibly be a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: of the old tradition and in the modern con-

Speaker: NA
Text: text be entirely superfluous? I wondered

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we needed to be strongly convinced

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding its retention.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pointed out that the permanent head

Speaker: NA
Text: of every department carries a very great

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: his department. No-one can really inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: fere with that administrative responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: and his activities. All of the officers of a

Speaker: NA
Text: department are subject to detail checking,

Speaker: NA
Text: if this is desired, by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General. As I have said tonight,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Auditor-General reports to the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the efficiency of a department

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the proper usage of funds and

Speaker: NA
Text: the keeping of fund expenditure within

Speaker: NA
Text: warrant. Whilst I may have been a little

Speaker: NA
Text: controversial in the remarks that I made,

Speaker: NA
Text: any fear that I had about wastage has

Speaker: NA
Text: been vindicated, for the Minister in his

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading speech made the points

Speaker: NA
Text: about computerisation and that the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons which required quarterly warrants

Speaker: NA
Text: are no longer valid. He pointed out that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is another control under the item

Speaker: NA
Text: heading instead of just the subdivisional

Speaker: NA
Text: heading. He went on to say that now that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have decided to do away with the

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary quarterly warrants the savings

Speaker: NA
Text: from these changes under the Bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be of the order of $100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: a year. Being a member of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Public Accounts Committee I can

Speaker: NA
Text: hardly complain of a saving of that magni-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude in a procedure that many people

Speaker: NA
Text: thought was highly desirable, but which I

Speaker: NA
Text: personally considered might have been

Speaker: NA
Text: thought desirable simply because it was

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional and because we had become

Speaker: NA
Text: accustomed to it because there was, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, an element of control inherent in

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Here I find that any fears I had that it

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been superfluous work have

Speaker: NA
Text: virtually been substantiated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apart from the warrant procedure there

Speaker: NA
Text: are other items or amendments in the

Speaker: NA
Text: small Bill. I want to refer to only one

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. Members of the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts Committee, when a

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury minute is reported by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee to the Parliament indicating action

Speaker: NA
Text: that is to be taken, are naturally delighted

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that action eventually taken in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament in the form of an amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment I refer to in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: was suggested as a recommendation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 61st report of the Joint Committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts. The Committee in the

Speaker: NA
Text: report noted difficulties arising from the

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion of deduction and transfer items

Speaker: NA
Text: in the schedules to the various appropria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion measures. This matter has now been

Speaker: NA
Text: corrected by an amendment in this Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other items, whilst they are impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant, do not attract my attention on this

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion for comment. J would like to revert

Speaker: NA
Text: to the main point. We have an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Audit Act. I join forces with my

Speaker: NA
Text: friend, the honourable member for Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Ports ( Mr Crean), who, during the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of his speech said that the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: touches only some items. The Minister at

Speaker: NA
Text: the table interjected and said that there

Speaker: NA
Text: more amendments contemplated. To this,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Ports said: 'Yes, but we have been promised

Speaker: NA
Text: a complete review of the Audit Act for

Speaker: NA
Text: many, many years'. So 1 would add my

Speaker: NA
Text: voice lo an appeal to the Minister for Civil

Speaker: NA
Text: Aviation ( Mr Swartz) who is at Ihe table

Speaker: NA
Text: and who is also the Minister assisting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. I make an appeal for a deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined drive to review every outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment which is being proposed to tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Audit Act. As I said in tbe context of my

Speaker: NA
Text: opening remarks, you cannot go virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the Audit Act for these funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental principles of control over the Execu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. It is through this very legislation that

Speaker: NA
Text: thi.s Parliament exercises a control over all

Speaker: NA
Text: the funds of the Commonwealth. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will not be dilatory in bringing this

Speaker: NA
Text: Acl completely up to date. Of course, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: realistic enough io know that as soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: this is done, in this changing world the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for other amendments will become apparent.

Speaker: NA
Text: But my fear, and that of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne Ports, is that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are many amendments which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: in contemplation for too long. I am satisfied

Speaker: NA
Text: that the main change being made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, relating to the warrant procedure, has

Speaker: NA
Text: been overdue. I trust that we as a Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will observe any other methods of

Speaker: NA
Text: control that may be exercised by the Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: surer and officers of the Treasury.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the afiirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted lor third reading to be

Speaker: NA
Text: moved forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Swartz) read a

Speaker: NA
Text: third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SCHOLARSHIPS BILL 1969

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 20 March (vide

Speaker: NA
Text: page 738), on motion by Mr Malcolm

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser:

Speaker: NA
Text: That lhe Bill be now read a .second lime.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Bass) [8.20]-Thi s is

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time that legislation of this nature

Speaker: NA
Text: has come before the House. In 1967 a

Speaker: NA
Text: Scholarships Bill was introduced in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate by the present Prime Minisler ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: were Gorton), who was then Minisler for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Science. The Bill was very

Speaker: NA
Text: severely criticised in the Senate and

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently withdrawn. After a lengthy

Speaker: NA
Text: period of re-examination and redrafting the

Speaker: NA
Text: Scholarships Bill 1969 has been presented.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill was presented on this occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister for Education and Science

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Malcolm Fraser), who succeeded the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in that portfolio. The

Speaker: NA
Text: initial Bill gave the Minister considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: discretionary powers. It gave him power to

Speaker: NA
Text: determine the number of scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: granted, the terms of eligibility for those

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking scholarships, the way in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: were to be selected and those authorised

Speaker: NA
Text: to grant scholarships. They were very great

Speaker: NA
Text: powers which were in no way circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed by regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the time, my colleagues in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: did not dispute that the Minister needed

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain measure of discretionary power

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Act. The Opposition conceded

Speaker: NA
Text: that there were individual cases in which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister would have lo exercise discre-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion so that fair and equitable treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: all applicants could be assured. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition disputed the sweeping powers

Speaker: NA
Text: which would have been given to the Mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: ster by the 1967 legislation. It argued

Speaker: NA
Text: that the powers of the Minister should be

Speaker: NA
Text: governed by regulations. It was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention of the Opposition to take away

Speaker: NA
Text: all discretionary power from the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: It recognised that be should retain enough

Speaker: NA
Text: power to prevent anomalies and abuses.

Speaker: NA
Text: On these principles several clauses of the

Speaker: NA
Text: original Bill were rejected by the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most notable critics of the wide

Speaker: NA
Text: discretionary powers tbat the Bill conferred

Speaker: NA
Text: was the present Minister for Works

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Wright). This Bill replaces the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1967 legislation. The Opposition believes

Speaker: NA
Text: that most of the objectionable features

Speaker: NA
Text: of the previous legislation have been

Speaker: NA
Text: removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clauses 6, 7, 8 and 9 of the Bill refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to grants of Commonwealth technical,

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced education and university scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships and post-graduate awards. Each clause

Speaker: NA
Text: provides that the appropriate scholarship or

Speaker: NA
Text: award may bc granted by the Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the regulations. 1 emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: the words 'in accordance with the regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions'. 1 understand that it is intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: issue quite extensive regulations covering

Speaker: NA
Text: the administration of the Act and in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular the terms of eligibility of persons

Speaker: NA
Text: for scholarships. This is commendable. It

Speaker: NA
Text: will not limit the discretion of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with the special circumstances wbich

Speaker: NA
Text: may arise from time to time. Of course, this

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been provided for in the initial

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The reassessment of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of this legislation has certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthened and improved it.

Speaker: NA
Text: in the main the Opposition will not

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose the provisions of the Bill. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition endorses clauses 1 to 10 of the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: without reservation. However, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some points that the Minister should clarify

Speaker: NA
Text: for the House. If this is done the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will raise no objections to the other

Speaker: NA
Text: clauses at the Committee stage. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: point the Minister sbould clarify is the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of thc word 'prescribed' in clauses 11 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 12. 1 ask the Minister to explain whether

Speaker: NA
Text: Ihis means prescribed by the regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: If that is the intention of the term the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition accepts the clauses. But if that

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the inicnfion the Opposition will move

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that the clauses clearly state that

Speaker: NA
Text: 'prescribed' means prescribed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: There seems also to be a clear contradic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion between clauses 11 and 12, which deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with secondary scholarships, and clauses 13

Speaker: NA
Text: and 14, which deal with tertiary scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. Clause 11 states that the benefits are

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed. Presumably they are prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with the regulations. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: said earlier, this should be made quite clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 12 also uses tbe word 'prescribed'

Speaker: NA
Text: and provides that some forms of additional

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance shaJJ be determined by tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. However, clauses 13 and 14 state

Speaker: NA
Text: that these benefits shall be determined in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with the regulations. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: face of it there appears to be a clear dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference in terminology between clauses 11

Speaker: NA
Text: and 12, which cover secondary scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships, and clauses 13 and 14, which cover

Speaker: NA
Text: tertiary scholarships. I ask the Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: explain whether this denotes a difference in

Speaker: NA
Text: the granting of benefits in these scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. It may be significant that different

Speaker: NA
Text: phraseology is applied to scholarships for

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary education and scholarships for

Speaker: NA
Text: tertiary education. It could indicate prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical differences in the awarding of scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. If any difference is intended in the

Speaker: NA
Text: awarding of benefits the Minister should

Speaker: NA
Text: explain this fully to the House. If that is

Speaker: NA
Text: not intended he should account for thi.s

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent variation in terminology and again

Speaker: NA
Text: clarify it for the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 18 of the Bill appears to give the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister full authority to vary decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: made in relation to scholarships under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act or the regulations. I ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to assure the House that there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: final right of appeal to him where a

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarship is rejected or a benefit is varied.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an example of where the operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ministerial discretion which is granted

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Act should operate. In his second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech the Minister said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was impressed by the extent to which even

Speaker: NA
Text: the most carefully drafted regulations could

Speaker: NA
Text: cause injustice and hardship if administered

Speaker: NA
Text: inflexibly. He has quite rightly preserved his

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion to prevent injustice and hardship.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister concluded his speech by

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising the need for an adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: framework for the scholarships legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the need to provide for regulations in

Speaker: NA
Text: important sections. In essence, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has considered the merits of the case made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Senate against the original legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: and he has acted to remove deficiences.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the Minister should be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended for this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bill is also significant in that it

Speaker: NA
Text: about the formal dissolution of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Office of Education. Honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: view this move with some nostalgia. This

Speaker: NA
Text: agency was established by the Chifley Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment in 1945. For more than 20 years

Speaker: NA
Text: it served as a vehicle for Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: aid to education. In particular, it made a

Speaker: NA
Text: noteworthy contribution to the administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Commonwealth scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. The functions of the Office were

Speaker: NA
Text: absorbed into the Education Division of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's Department and ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: into the Department of Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science.

Speaker: NA
Text: The process by which the great powers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Government have

Speaker: NA
Text: been applied to education is a long and

Speaker: NA
Text: laborious one. These functions are still

Speaker: NA
Text: being applied in an extremely haphazard

Speaker: NA
Text: way, as the Opposition has repeatedly

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out in this House. However, we

Speaker: NA
Text: can hope that the Department of Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Science, which is still at an early

Speaker: NA
Text: stage of development, will assume increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing burdens in the guidance and promotion

Speaker: NA
Text: of education at all levels in Australia. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is regrettable that there is no longer a role

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Commonwealth Office of Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I take this opportunity, on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the political party which formed it, to

Speaker: NA
Text: formally acknowledge the Office's passing

Speaker: NA
Text: and to pay tribute to its invaluable work.

Speaker: NA
Text: In his second reading speech the Mini-

Speaker: NA
Text: ster gave some account of the scope and

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the scholarship schemes at

Speaker: NA
Text: present in operation in Australia. This

Speaker: NA
Text: gives honourable members a chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the implications of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scheme, to assess the future of

Speaker: NA
Text: university finance in Australia and to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider the adequacy of the finance schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: for university students. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out that under the five schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: contained in the Bill some 56,000 students

Speaker: NA
Text: hold Commonwealth scholarships. He said

Speaker: NA
Text: that without further changes spending on

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme would rise to nearly $35m by

Speaker: NA
Text: 1971-72. These figures sound impressive

Speaker: NA
Text: but on close examination grounds for con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern about the future of the scheme and

Speaker: NA
Text: the burdens which it imposes must be

Speaker: NA
Text: reconsidered. There has been quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: marked erosion in the base of the Combetween

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth university scholarship since its

Speaker: NA
Text: brings introduction in 1951. In that year 3,000

Speaker: NA
Text: open entry scholarships were available for

Speaker: NA
Text: first year university students, and there

Speaker: NA
Text: were 7,601 enrolments at Australian univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities. In short, scholarships were available

Speaker: NA
Text: for 40% of new enrolments. In 1960, 3,000

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships were available for only 29%

Speaker: NA
Text: of new enrolments. Although the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of scholarships available for first year

Speaker: NA
Text: students was doubled to 6,000 in 1968

Speaker: NA
Text: there were scholarships for only one in

Speaker: NA
Text: four of those who enrolled.

Speaker: NA
Text: This remarkable erosion on the scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship base can be illustrated further by infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation supplied by the Minister for Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Science in reply to a question by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Whitlam).

Speaker: NA
Text: The information is contained in Hansard of

Speaker: NA
Text: 25th February of this year at page 111. It

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that in 1952 51% of all applicants

Speaker: NA
Text: were granted Commonwealth scholarships,

Speaker: NA
Text: ln 1968 18.3% of applicants received

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships. This is a most alarming

Speaker: NA
Text: deterioration, despite the provision of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially more scholarships. In 1968,

Speaker: NA
Text: 46,527 applications for Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships were received. Of those appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations, 8,524 accepted scholarships. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: of the unsuccessful applicants would receive

Speaker: NA
Text: university training by way of manpower

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes, that is, by various sorts of cadet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships, by teacher training and similar

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes. On the evidence of the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Future of Tertiary Education in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, known as the 'Martin Committee', the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers receiving such assistance would be

Speaker: NA
Text: about the same as those receiving assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: by way of Commonwealth scholarships. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we include those students whose families can

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to pay their fees or who obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: financial assistance to pay the fees, the best

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment that can be made is that only

Speaker: NA
Text: half of those young people wanting uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity education are covered by the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing system of student assistance. Even

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing for the hiving off of a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: number of students into colleges of

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced education, quite clearly many

Speaker: NA
Text: able students are lost to tertiary education

Speaker: NA
Text: each year. This is a drain of talent which

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be afforded.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth scholarship scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: has made an immense contribution to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. It produced some 30,000 graduates

Speaker: NA
Text: 1952 and 1966, but on the present

Speaker: NA
Text: basis it is far from adequate. This raises the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of whether the scholarship scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: can be expanded and supplemented by other

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of assistance. There has always been

Speaker: NA
Text: a very strong case for fixing the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships at a certain percentage of new

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolments each year. This has been recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended by the Martin Committee and by

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Union of Australian University

Speaker: NA
Text: Students. In the past there has been too

Speaker: NA
Text: much emphasis on the aggregate of scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships available and not on the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: new enrolments. This meant that over a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of 10 years the number of scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships provided was fixed while enrolments

Speaker: NA
Text: increased rapidly. If the number of scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships was fixed at 40% of new enrolments

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e figure which applied when the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced in 1951-10,00 0 scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships should have been made available last

Speaker: NA
Text: year and not 6.000. I feel that the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of scholarships should be fixed at a higher

Speaker: NA
Text: level; certainly at 50% of the enrolments at

Speaker: NA
Text: least. The value of scholarships also should

Speaker: NA
Text: be tied to the cost of Hving index. Existing

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits have fallen far below living costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the broader context there has been much

Speaker: NA
Text: debate in recent years over the financing

Speaker: NA
Text: of university education. Last year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: spending of a further $ 10m of public money

Speaker: NA
Text: would provide free university education in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. This was hotly disputed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Education and Science who

Speaker: NA
Text: said that education at the university level

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be free. He said that most of

Speaker: NA
Text: the taxes which supported universities came

Speaker: NA
Text: from general revenue; that these taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be used for the education of

Speaker: NA
Text: students wbo would become very high in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come earners because of that education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the Minister did not follow

Speaker: NA
Text: through the implications of those remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister did not say that fees form a

Speaker: NA
Text: negligible percentage of the financing of

Speaker: NA
Text: universities today.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the past 20 years revenue from tuition

Speaker: NA
Text: fees and private endowments have declined

Speaker: NA
Text: sharply. Every university student is already

Speaker: NA
Text: being handsomely subsidised by the taxpayer

Speaker: NA
Text: even if he is on a scholarship or even if he

Speaker: NA
Text: is paying fees. It is unfortunate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should have seized on a mere

Speaker: NA
Text: SlOm as the burden borne by unfortunate

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers whose income cannot be raised

Speaker: NA
Text: by university education. At the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial elite will go to universities

Speaker: NA
Text: because they can pay the fees; the intellec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tual elite will go to universities through

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships. However, there remains a very

Speaker: NA
Text: large number of potential students who can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not afford the fees and cannot win a place

Speaker: NA
Text: because there are not enough scholarships.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is unfortunately true that a high propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of scholarships are won by students

Speaker: NA
Text: from economically more privileged groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: In these circumstances it is incorrect to

Speaker: NA
Text: argue that the incidence of making tuition

Speaker: NA
Text: free would fall harshly on the less privileged.

Speaker: NA
Text: The burden of taxation subsidies to univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities already falls heavily on these groups.

Speaker: NA
Text: One solution is a substantia] expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships. Another is the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: far greater credit facilities for students who

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot win scholarships but who have the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to benefit from university education.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of loans to students has

Speaker: NA
Text: always been a vexed one. It was rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Robbins Committee on Higher

Speaker: NA
Text: Education in the United Kingdom, although

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee did recommend that some

Speaker: NA
Text: experimentation with this sort of financing

Speaker: NA
Text: might be necessary. The concept of loans

Speaker: NA
Text: to students was also rejected by the Martin

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee. 1 feel that this attitude should

Speaker: NA
Text: be reconsidered with a view to providing

Speaker: NA
Text: credit facilities for students on a national

Speaker: NA
Text: basis. Credit facilities are provided to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover the whole range of tangible goods

Speaker: NA
Text: and services in the economy. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested that credit should not be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for intangibles such as health and education.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, contributions to health funds and

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance funds are in a sense credit

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: In these circumstances I feel that a Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth corporation to provide credit for

Speaker: NA
Text: students seeking it could be established.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such a corporation could provide low

Speaker: NA
Text: interest loans for tuition fees and such loans

Speaker: NA
Text: could be repayable from the future earnings

Speaker: NA
Text: of the recipients. It could underwrite loans

Speaker: NA
Text: made privately to university students. It

Speaker: NA
Text: could also be used to supplement a a

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded scholarship scheme. Such a cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration could make loans repayable at 1%

Speaker: NA
Text: interest during student years and 2% there-

Speaker: NA
Text: after. Alternatively, it could subsidise tuition

Speaker: NA
Text: fees by the formation of a revolving fund

Speaker: NA
Text: that would be replenished by repayments. In

Speaker: NA
Text: association with an expanded scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, it would replace the existing com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex and unsatisfactory structure. An exten-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive loan scheme, allied to a wider scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship scheme, would mean that everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to a university education would

Speaker: NA
Text: have his fees paid and would receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: living allowance during his education. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: a revision of the existing system is needed

Speaker: NA
Text: if a further erosion of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarship base and a further wastage of

Speaker: NA
Text: potential talent are to be avoided.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have clearly indicated to this House

Speaker: NA
Text: how the number of scholarships as a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of the number of applicants has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen in recent years. No doubt the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Education and Science and Government

Speaker: NA
Text: members may be able to argue, and suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessfully argue, that some years ago the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of those students who were suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessful in obtaining Commonwealth assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance under the Commonwealth scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme was at a satisfactory level-althoug h

Speaker: NA
Text: it has never reached the level that the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party has been advocating in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years. But there has been a steady

Speaker: NA
Text: deterioration in tbe percentage of those

Speaker: NA
Text: who successfully apply for scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: under the existing scheme. We have argued

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently, as was pointed out by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition some time ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: that university education should be entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: free. 1 think that is a valid point.

Speaker: NA
Text: The wastage of talent at the secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: school level is far more than this country

Speaker: NA
Text: can afford. Any country that refuses to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the importance of education

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is prepared to accept the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of wastage to which I have just

Speaker: NA
Text: referred will find itself inevitably in extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties in the years that lie ahead. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin Committee has made a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: very valuable suggestions on what should

Speaker: NA
Text: be the approach of an enlightened Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment not only on the question of Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scholarships but also on the question

Speaker: NA
Text: of tertiary education generally. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Education and Science took the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to criticise the suggestion that

Speaker: NA
Text: had been made by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition that tertiary education in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country should be entirely free, and he dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: puted the statement by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition that it would involve taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: in an additional expense of about SlOm

Speaker: NA
Text: annually. The Minister for Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science, as I have already indicated to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House, did not point out that all university

Speaker: NA
Text: students are today being highly subsidised,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they are receiving a Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scholarship or not. As a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendations initially made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray Committee, which was set up by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government, and the subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the Martin Committee,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has accepted a measure of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility in education at this level. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of the Government's decision

Speaker: NA
