Text: university education has been heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidised.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that university education

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be the responsibility of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government. If the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth were prepared to accept full

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for education at this level, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would undoubtedly make additional finance

Speaker: NA
Text: available to State Education Departments

Speaker: NA
Text: for education at the primary, secondary and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical levels. Therefore, I want to point

Speaker: NA
Text: out once again that the policy enunciated

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Leader of the Opposition on the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of tertiary education is one that

Speaker: NA
Text: will be implemented by a future Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. University education should

Speaker: NA
Text: be free. No Government can condone the

Speaker: NA
Text: present deterioration in the facilities made

Speaker: NA
Text: available to those who want to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: education at the tertiary level. The wastage

Speaker: NA
Text: at the secondary school level is far greater

Speaker: NA
Text: than this country can afford.

Speaker: NA
Text: ln addition to pointing out what we

Speaker: NA
Text: believe ought to be the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to the question of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships and other scholarships that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be available under this legislation, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that the Government should con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider granting loans to university students

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable them to complete a course at a

Speaker: NA
Text: university. I want to reiterate that those

Speaker: NA
Text: who belong to affluent families are in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to undertake a university course of

Speaker: NA
Text: education. If they are gifted intellectually

Speaker: NA
Text: they can win Commonwealth scholarships.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who do not belong to affluent

Speaker: NA
Text: families and whose parents cannot pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: their university education and who cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify for a Commonwealth scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: under the present scheme are the students

Speaker: NA
Text: who concern members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. The Government must face up to

Speaker: NA
Text: its responsibilities on tbe loss of oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunities and the wastage of talent at this

Speaker: NA
Text: level.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having made those points, I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to say in summary that the Opposition does

Speaker: NA
Text: not oppose this Bill. It welcomes the very

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial modifications to the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: outlined by the Minister for Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science. 1 have tried to draw attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: the deterioration of the present scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and the need for rehabilitating and

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementing it. Unfortunately the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Education and Science is not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House tonight, but I hope that when he

Speaker: NA
Text: reads the points that have been made by

Speaker: NA
Text: myself in resuming this debate on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition and the points that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be made by my colleagues who will follow

Speaker: NA
Text: me in this debate he will incorporate these

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestions in lhe Bill. If it is not possible

Speaker: NA
Text: to incorporate these provisions now I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will give serious considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to amending the legislation as soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible.

Speaker: Mr ARTHUR
Text: Barton) [8.50]- I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Scholarships Bill 1969 for our industrial life.

Speaker: NA
Text: several reasons. Before stating those reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: may I say that Ibe attitude of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labor Party to education has always

Speaker: NA
Text: amazed me. Honourable members on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition side are great theoreticians,

Speaker: NA
Text: their main forte is in trying to cast suspicion

Speaker: NA
Text: on the aims and integrity of the Governthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in this field. I can understand this,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the record of the Labor Party in

Speaker: NA
Text: thc field of education is so lamentable that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parly tries to hide its inadequacy by

Speaker: NA
Text: making wild promises and vaguely veiled

Speaker: NA
Text: aspersions. I often wonder whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: really interested in education or only

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining votes at the next election. It must

Speaker: NA
Text: be rather frustrating for members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party to view the great strides

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has made in tbe past decade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us face the fact that the performance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Party in the field of educaof

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has been a poor one, and the speech

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Barnard) made tonight will do nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: change ihis. I often wonder why the Oppobodies

Speaker: NA
Text: sition still carries on with its

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to keep alive in Australia the

Speaker: NA
Text: phoney class attitude that permeates almost

Speaker: NA
Text: every phase of its political philosophy. That

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude was perpetuated tonight in

Speaker: NA
Text: speech of the Deputy Leader of the Oppodebate

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, and it is just as phoney today as

Speaker: NA
Text: was when the Opposition adopted it a am

Speaker: NA
Text: decade ago. This type of snobbery, inverted

Speaker: NA
Text: though it may be. does little justice to Ihe

Speaker: NA
Text: young people of today who care nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: for the time worn cliches of three decades

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, and who have completely rejected the

Speaker: NA
Text: emotional appeals to class hatred that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is consistently making in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House. The Opposition should recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are at the end of tbe 1960s and

Speaker: NA
Text: not in the depression of the 1930s.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another thing that amazed me about the

Speaker: NA
Text: speech of the Deputy Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition was that he spent most of his time

Speaker: NA
Text: extolling the virtues of having a university

Speaker: NA
Text: education and uttered not a word about the

Speaker: NA
Text: education of those who wished to become

Speaker: NA
Text: tradesmen or technicians. For a Party which

Speaker: NA
Text: professes to have an interest in the working

Speaker: NA
Text: man and his family it is astonishing that

Speaker: NA
Text: he did not even mention the thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: splendid young men and women who every

Speaker: NA
Text: year train to become tradesmen or tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nicians. These people are the backbone of

Speaker: NA
Text: The first reason why 1 support this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is that I have great respect for the vast

Speaker: NA
Text: strides in education this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: but made possible in the last decade. One does

Speaker: NA
Text: not need to have a long memory to recall

Speaker: NA
Text: days when it was considered to be quite

Speaker: NA
Text: improper for the Federal Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: take any part in the development of educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional facilities in Australia. Education was

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded strictly as a State function, and

Speaker: NA
Text: attempts by the Federal Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist the States with specific projects were

Speaker: NA
Text: in looked upon with great suspicion. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, under successive Ministers for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Science, first the then Sena-

Speaker: NA
Text: this tor John Gorton and now the Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: Malcolm Fraser. has initiated moves vastly

Speaker: NA
Text: to improve the facilities for and the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: education in Australia. Most of the

Speaker: NA
Text: advances made by the Government were

Speaker: NA
Text: new and imaginative, but almost invariably

Speaker: NA
Text: they were met with hostility by the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition in this Parliament and by the outside

Speaker: NA
Text: which control the Labor Party and

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary dictate its policies.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Barton that the

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Scholarships Bill does not

Speaker: NA
Text: it range over the whole field of education. I

Speaker: NA
Text: finding it a little difficult to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevance of these remarks to this Bill.

Speaker: Mr ARTHUR
Text: J hope that I can remedy

Speaker: NA
Text: that. J think it may be of interest to honourstudents

Speaker: NA
Text: able members to have a look at the types

Speaker: NA
Text: of scholarship schemes in operation at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment because not everyone realises what

Speaker: NA
Text: is being done by tbis Government in the

Speaker: NA
Text: field of education. The first one is the

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth postgraduate awards scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been in existence since 1959 and

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced by the Liberal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: after it considered the Murray report on

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian universities. The scheme provides

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance for well qualified graduates for

Speaker: NA
Text: an approved programme of postgraduate

Speaker: NA
Text: studies, usually leading to either a master's

Speaker: NA
Text: degree or a doctorate at an Australian uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity. The benefits payable under this

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme comprise a stipend of $2,350 per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum, an annual contribution of $400 to

Speaker: NA
Text: go towards research costs for each student,

Speaker: NA
Text: and other allowances.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second scheme is the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: university scholarship scheme. This scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: was commenced in 1951 by tbe Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government as the Commonwealth scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship scheme when awards were offered for

Speaker: NA
Text: first degree and diploma courses at univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities and tertiary courses at other approved

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions such as technical colleges. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1966 the Commonwealth scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme was replaced by two schemes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth university scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and the Commonwealth advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: education scholarship scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth university scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme provides awards for full-time and

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time study in first degree and diploma

Speaker: NA
Text: courses at Australian universities. Pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously the detailed administration of these

Speaker: NA
Text: awards was carried out by the State Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Departments. It was decided that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth should take over this func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, starting at the beginning of 1968. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are three types of scholarships-ope n

Speaker: NA
Text: entrance scholarships for matriculation,

Speaker: NA
Text: later year scholarships for students who

Speaker: NA
Text: have completed some university studies, and

Speaker: NA
Text: mature age scholarships for students who

Speaker: NA
Text: have turned 25 years of age.

Speaker: NA
Text: Benefits paid by the Liberal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: include the payment of all compulsory fees

Speaker: NA
Text: for all award holders without means test. A

Speaker: NA
Text: living allowance is also payable subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: a means test. Maximum living allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: rales in 1969 are $559 per annum for

Speaker: NA
Text: living at home and $904.80 per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum for students Hving away from home.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then we bave the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced education scholarships which were

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by this Government under a

Speaker: NA
Text: Com- separate scheme from the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1966, assistance for similar courses being

Speaker: NA
Text: previously available under the old Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth scholarship scheme. Awards are

Speaker: NA
Text: given by this Government for full-time and

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time study in diploma and other

Speaker: NA
Text: approved tertiary courses at technical col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leges and similar institutions. There are two

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds of scholarships-ope n entrance

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships for students at matriculation

Speaker: NA
Text: standard, and later year scholarships for

Speaker: NA
Text: students who have completed part of an

Speaker: NA
Text: approved course. Benefits are the same as

Speaker: NA
Text: those paid under the university scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fourth scheme is Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary scholarships scheme. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary scholarships were taken up in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965. Awards are given for the final 2

Speaker: NA
Text: years of secondary schooling. Benefits avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to a secondary scholarship holder

Speaker: NA
Text: include a living allowance of $200 per year,

Speaker: NA
Text: a text book and equipment allowance of

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 per year, and up to $150 per year for

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory tuition fees, examination fees

Speaker: NA
Text: and service fees on production of receipts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last one is the Commonwealth tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical scholarships scheme. The first tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical scholarships were taken up in 1965

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Governnient. Awards are given

Speaker: NA
Text: mainly for certificate level courses at tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: nical institutions. Benefits available to a full-

Speaker: NA
Text: time technical scholarship holder are: a

Speaker: NA
Text: living allowance of $200 per year, a text-

Speaker: NA
Text: book and equipment allowance of $50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: year, and up to $150 per year for com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsory tuition fees, examination fees and

Speaker: NA
Text: service fees on production of receipts. A

Speaker: NA
Text: technical scholarship holder taking a course

Speaker: NA
Text: part-time receives an allowance of $100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: year and reimbursement of compulsory fees

Speaker: NA
Text: up to $100 per year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to emphasise that all these

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes were introduced by this Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and that all these payments

Speaker: NA
Text: were made by the Government. These were

Speaker: NA
Text: completely new advances in the field of

Speaker: NA
Text: education. In order to have some perspec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive in this matter I would like to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the House to the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of awards given under each heading in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1969. The number for ihe Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: postgraduate awards is 650; Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: university scholarships, 9,500; Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth advanced education scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. 1,500; Commonwealth secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships, 10,000; and Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: technical scholarships, 2,500. This gives an

Speaker: NA
Text: overall total of 24.150 for the year 1969.

Speaker: NA
Text: The number of scholarship holders in train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in 1969-thi s includes people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking the second and third year of

Speaker: NA
Text: their course-i s estimated to be 56,500,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a far cry from the total of only

Speaker: NA
Text: 6,444 in 1951, just after the Labor Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment went out of office. The appropriations

Speaker: NA
Text: to finance these scholarships for the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 1968-69 totalled 828.880,000 compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with S632.194 in 1950-51. I mention these

Speaker: NA
Text: figures because the Opposition in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament talks as though it had made

Speaker: NA
Text: great strides in the field of education when

Speaker: NA
Text: it was last in power. The reverse is true,

Speaker: NA
Text: however. The AustraUan Labor Parly has

Speaker: NA
Text: done little about education except talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: it and it was left to Liberal-Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to get down to work

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! There is far too

Speaker: NA
Text: much conversation on my lefi.

Speaker: Mr ARTHUR
Text: I can understand that.

Speaker: NA
Text: This cannot be palatable to the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was left to the Liberal-Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to introduce the forward-

Speaker: NA
Text: looking policies of the past decade.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: H e reads so badlv, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker.

Speaker: Mr ARTHUR
Text: I hear mutterings from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition benches and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Leader of the Opposition to the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect that the Labor Party has not been in

Speaker: NA
Text: power in the past rwo decades, so it cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be blamed. This is true, despite the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has tried at election after election

Speaker: NA
Text: to buy votes of the Australian people by

Speaker: NA
Text: offering fantastic measures that it knew

Speaker: NA
Text: could not be carried out by any responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: governmeni and that it knew it would never

Speaker: NA
Text: have the responsibility to carry out. It

Speaker: NA
Text: true that the Labor Party, due to the sound

Speaker: NA
Text: common sense of the Australian voter, has

Speaker: NA
Text: not been in power in the federal sphere

Speaker: NA
Text: for 20 years, but it was in power in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales for several decades and it

Speaker: NA
Text: the education system deteriorate to such

Speaker: NA
Text: an extent

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I would again

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the honourable member for Barton

Speaker: NA
Text: that his remarks are very wide of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tents of the Bill. 1 can see in the last few

Speaker: NA
Text: statements no real relevance to the Bill.

Speaker: Mr ARTHUR
Text: I apologise, Mr Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought that they were most apposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope I may be able to finish that sentence.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Labor Party was in power in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales it let the education system

Speaker: NA
Text: deteriorate to such an extent

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! If the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member persists in abusing the forms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House 1 shall have to deal with him.

Speaker: Mr ARTHUR
Text: I certainly do not per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sist. I am sorry if I was transgressing. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought I could finish my sentence. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me say that this Bill brings up to date the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements needed for such a vast scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: to operate effectively, while at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time it gives full protection to those who

Speaker: NA
Text: come under its various, wide-ranging rami-

Speaker: NA
Text: fications. It also, 1 am pleased to note,

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasises the need to preserve ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion. Those of us who deal constantly

Speaker: NA
Text: with a wide range of educational problems

Speaker: NA
Text: for our constituents, as 1 do in Barton, know

Speaker: NA
Text: how many apparent anomalies crop up in

Speaker: NA
Text: such a vast scheme as this. While we may

Speaker: NA
Text: not always agree with the decisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister when he exercises his discretion,

Speaker: NA
Text: we know that these decisions are the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of long and searching research into each

Speaker: NA
Text: individual case and that the Minister is, to

Speaker: NA
Text: use a well worn Australianism, completely

Speaker: NA
Text: fair dinkum in both his approach and his

Speaker: NA
Text: outlook. We know that under his wise and

Speaker: NA
Text: imaginative administration we will have new

Speaker: NA
Text: and improved assistance given to both State

Speaker: NA
Text: and independent schools in Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: years ahead. I commend this Bill.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Werriwa-Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition) [9.3]-Australian s increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly recognise that their Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment must treat education as a national

Speaker: NA
Text: is problem and a national challenge. They

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that a nation's children can enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: equal opportunities for the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: their talents only if its education system is

Speaker: NA
Text: financed and planned on a national basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: let They recognise that education is the key

Speaker: NA
Text: to national development, national prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: and national survival. Successive Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: governments and successive Liberal Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters responsible for education have, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of policy, minimised the role of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth in education. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: resisted the development of new Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth initiatives in educational matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals are as anxious to slow down the

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitable increase in government expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture on schools as they are to slow down

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on hospitals and urban services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, both State and Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals assert that schools, hospitals and

Speaker: NA
Text: urban services are State functions. They

Speaker: NA
Text: know that the best way to restrict govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment expenditure on any activity is to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the particular activity is one for the

Speaker: NA
Text: States, which have fewer financial resources

Speaker: NA
Text: than the Commonwealth, and which raise

Speaker: NA
Text: tbeir revenue by indirect rather than direct

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation, by regressive rather than by pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressive taxation. Again, Liberals seek con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantly to dampen public interest in educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and to lower the temperature of public

Speaker: NA
Text: debate by insisting that there is no crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: education and by resisting demands for any

Speaker: NA
Text: national inquiry into education. State

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries into education such as the inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: recently commenced by the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia are no substitute for a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prehensive investigation at the national

Speaker: NA
Text: level.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kevin Cairns- I take a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Are these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters appropriate to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scholarships Bill, in view of tbe ruling given

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the remarks of the last

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Lucock)

Speaker: NA
Text: -Tber e is no substance in the point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: I t would be possible

Speaker: NA
Text: for every State government to conduct an

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into its own education system

Speaker: NA
Text: without establishing the national needs and

Speaker: NA
Text: national priorities around which national

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure may be organised with greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage, and for which public support

Speaker: NA
Text: would be most extensive. Moreover,

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals use scholarships as a device to

Speaker: NA
Text: defer free education for all by paying the

Speaker: NA
Text: fees of a minority. Commonwealth scholarwere

Speaker: NA
Text: ships mask the failure of our national

Speaker: NA
Text: government to follow comparable national

Speaker: NA
Text: governments into sharing the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: education without charge. Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondary Scholarships are a typical

Speaker: NA
Text: example of the way in which Liberals defer

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing educational reforms by buying off

Speaker: NA
Text: potentially critical minorities within the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. They exemplify this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's cynical disregard for social priori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. Secondary Scholarships are awarded

Speaker: NA
Text: on the basis of intellectual tests and not

Speaker: NA
Text: nnancial need. Inevitably, therefore, they

Speaker: NA
Text: favour students who have benefited from

Speaker: NA
Text: social and economic advantages, not least

Speaker: NA
Text: among them access to superior schooling.

Speaker: NA
Text: Inevitably, a high proportion of the funds

Speaker: NA
Text: which are provided go to parents who are

Speaker: NA
Text: well able to afford to keep their children

Speaker: NA
Text: at school. A questionnaire sent to members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Victorian Association of Head-

Speaker: NA
Text: masters in 1964 elicited the information

Speaker: NA
Text: that of 2151 Secondary Scholarship winners

Speaker: NA
Text: only 24 would have left school if they had

Speaker: NA
Text: not been awarded a scholarship. The

Speaker: NA
Text: headmasters pointed out that there was no

Speaker: NA
Text: way of knowing how many of the children

Speaker: NA
Text: in who in fact left school would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to remain if they had received

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate assistance. It is highly unlikely

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Secondary Scholarship scheme has

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly increased the number of young

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who are able to complete a

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary education. Instead, the system

Speaker: NA
Text: has enhanced the situation described by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Director of Secondary Education in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, Mr R. A. Reed, on 3rd September

Speaker: NA
Text: 1968. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Compared with secondary schools, the cele-

Speaker: NA
Text: brated rat race of industry and commerce is

Speaker: NA
Text: like a picnic forfieldmice.Education is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: human enterprise based on a confident anticipa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of failure. We not only accept failure as

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitable, we actually build it into the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals are unable to see that at this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's development it may be worth

Speaker: NA
Text: devoting a signincant part of our resources

Speaker: NA
Text: to developing the capacities of all our

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens. They cannot understand that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no way of accurately sorting out human

Speaker: NA
Text: beings, and that attempts to do so in

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary schools invariably cost the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation some of its finest intellects and most

Speaker: NA
Text: useful graduates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Twenty-four thousand young Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted to universities in 1968 but

Speaker: NA
Text: only 6,000 were able to secure Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scholarships. The total enrolment

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian universities rose to 102,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: of whom only 25,000 were Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: scholars. The Secretary of the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Science Research Council of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: commented:

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems to me impossible to argue that barely

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a quarter of the new students entering

Speaker: NA
Text: degree courses in our universities are worth a

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarship. At least one half should qualify for

Speaker: NA
Text: such an award.

Speaker: NA
Text: The leader writer of the 'Australian'

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out:

Speaker: NA
Text: Penalisation of a substantial proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: annual matriculants, otherwise well qualified, by

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's failure to offer financial

Speaker: NA
Text: tance is inexcusable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The number of Commonwealth scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships available to university entrants has in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact declined from 40% in 1951, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: postwar scheme was launched, to 25% in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1968. The additional 1,500 scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshadowed in the 1968 Budget will not

Speaker: NA
Text: even restore the 1951 situation, far less

Speaker: NA
Text: improve it. Nor will the situation be im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved by the Minister for Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) arguing, as

Speaker: NA
Text: he did in the 'Australian' on 20th May

Speaker: NA
Text: 1968, that:

Speaker: NA
Text: When Commonwealth assistance to students

Speaker: NA
Text: being considered it is important to survey the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole field and not just one particular aspect

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: University students who now enjoy not

Speaker: NA
Text: much more than half as good a chance of

Speaker: NA
Text: obtaining a scholarship as they did in 1951

Speaker: NA
Text: are no better off for knowing that scholara

Speaker: NA
Text: ships are available elsewhere for education

Speaker: NA
Text: of a different kind. The loss the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: sustains when talented people are unable

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake university studies for want

Speaker: NA
Text: financial assistance is not reduced because

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships are now available at colleges

Speaker: NA
Text: of advanced education. The Minister, moreResearch.

Speaker: NA
Text: over, should be in no doubt about the

Speaker: NA
Text: status to which colleges of advanced educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion have been reduced by the policies of

Speaker: NA
Text: his Government. The essential features

Speaker: NA
Text: these colleges set out in the report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin Committee have now largely disthe

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared. In particular, the Martin

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee's insistence that they should acquire

Speaker: NA
Text: status equivalent to that of universities has

Speaker: NA
Text: been explicitly abandoned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The public no longer believes and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government no longer troubles to

Speaker: NA
Text: that colleges of advanced education are anyTeacher

Speaker: NA
Text: thing other than also-rans, providing

Speaker: NA
Text: limited tertiary education at bargain prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister himself is so little concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with the colleges that he has so far been

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to tell me for how many students

Speaker: NA
Text: they cater. The Government is so little con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned that it provides for the colleges only

Speaker: NA
Text: one-fifth the number of scholarships which

Speaker: NA
Text: it provides for universities. Even so, the

Speaker: NA
Text: pent-up demand for a tertiary education is

Speaker: NA
Text: so great that the colleges are already falling

Speaker: NA
Text: a prey to many of the difficulties which

Speaker: NA
Text: beset the universities. Quotas have already

Speaker: NA
Text: been imposed for a number of courses in

Speaker: NA
Text: assisNew South Wales, Victoria, South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and Western Australia. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: become much more widespread if the Wark

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee succumbs to pressure from

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments and recommends grants

Speaker: NA
Text: for the new triennium which are unrealisti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally low. Restricted entry applies also

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the nation's teacher training col-

Speaker: NA
Text: leges. Although the number of Higher Cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tificate examination candidates in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales increased between 1967 and 1968 by

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000, only 200 additional places were pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided in teachers colleges, and at least J .500

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible applicants were refused studentships.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Martin Committee recognised that any

Speaker: NA
Text: is serious plan for tertiary education in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: of tralia must include teacher training. By

Speaker: NA
Text: refusing to accept responsibility for teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: training in any form, Sir Robert Menzies

Speaker: NA
Text: abandoned at a stroke the possibility of an

Speaker: NA
Text: integrated tertiary system. He abandoned

Speaker: NA
Text: unique opportunity to improve the quality

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian schools. He abandoned a most

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant method of helping the struggling

Speaker: NA
Text: State authorities cope with their education

Speaker: NA
Text: of crises. The present Prime Minister ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Gorton) was then Minister-in-charge of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Activities in Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: While Sir Robert Menzies on 24th March

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965 was extracting the heart from the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Martin proposals in the House of Represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives, Senator Gorton was extracting it in

Speaker: NA
Text: other place. He said in his ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: Comstatement on the report that:

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, while we do not in the least deni-

Speaker: NA
Text: grate the importance of the Committee's recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation in this field, we believe that it is one

Speaker: NA
Text: where action can be, and should be, left to the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments who have before them the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's recommendations for adoption and

Speaker: NA
Text: pretend action should they so decide.

Speaker: NA
Text: education is the only tertiary field

Speaker: NA
Text: a in which the Commonwealth refuses to

Speaker: NA
Text: become involved. Is the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the acute shortage of teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: which is currently embarrassing each and

Speaker: NA
Text: every one of the State governments? Is he

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the harm which is being inflicted

Speaker: NA
Text: educationally upon yet another generation

Speaker: NA
Text: of young Australians by over-large classes,

Speaker: NA
Text: untrained and semi-trained 'temporary*

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers and the unavailability of a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: range of specialist teachers, particularly at

Speaker: NA
Text: crucial stages of the secondary course? Does

Speaker: NA
Text: he still believe that this is a matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: 'can be, and should be, left to the State

Speaker: NA
Text: governments'?

Speaker: NA
Text: Years were allowed to elapse before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Holt Government finally made available

Speaker: NA
Text: grants for the construction of buildings for

Speaker: NA
Text: new teachers colleges. In most States it was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for these grants to be used to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: place existing buildings which had outlived

Speaker: NA
Text: their usefulness. In Victoria, the Teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: Union estimates that the grants will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: only a third of the sum actually required to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide adequate facilities. No assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: is being given with the recurrent costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher training. Commonwealth teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: training scholarships recommended in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin report have not been provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unbonded teachers entitled to 10% of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new places created with the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: grant for buildings have therefore presum-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably been unable to take up those places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The number of additional places is in any

Speaker: NA
Text: case paltry compared with the 10,000 which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Martin Committee estimated will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required by 1975.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Education and Science

Speaker: NA
Text: refers frequently, fulsomely and fatuously

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact that Commonwealth expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: for education has risen in 5 years from

Speaker: NA
Text: $70m to $210m. Yet Australia is still spend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for education only 4.3% of its gross

Speaker: NA
Text: national product, whereas the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: spends 7.1%, Japan 6.8%, the Soviet Union

Speaker: NA
Text: 6.2% and Britain 5.9%. We are still able

Speaker: NA
Text: to retain in full-time education only 33%

Speaker: NA
Text: of our young people aged 15 to 19, whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States retains 68%, the Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Union 52%, Canada 48% and the Nether-

Speaker: NA
Text: lands 45%.

Speaker: NA
Text: We still enable only 481 young Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians for every 100,000 of population to

Speaker: NA
Text: complete their secondary education, where-

Speaker: NA
Text: as in Japan 2,014 do so, in the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,450, in Britain 893 and in Italy 625. We

Speaker: NA
Text: produce only 149 graduates from tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: education for every 100,000 of population,

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the United States produces 325,

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan 204, the Soviet Union 198 and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada 186. Yugoslavia and Greece equal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia in the proportion of their young

Speaker: NA
Text: people undergoing full time education.

Speaker: NA
Text: Puerto Rico, Singapore and Taiwan excell

Speaker: NA
Text: us in the proportion of their young people

Speaker: NA
Text: who complete the secondary school course.

Speaker: NA
Text: Among 72 countries whose expenditure is

Speaker: NA
Text: listed by the Organisation for Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Co-operation and Development, Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: ranks 37th. Consequently, although Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has become one of the great mineral-

Speaker: NA
Text: producing countries of the world, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: only 1,300 geologists, whereas the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States with an area similar to our own has

Speaker: NA
Text: 20,000, and the Soviet Union with three

Speaker: NA
Text: times our area has 90,000. Although we

Speaker: NA
Text: are one of the world's great centres of

Speaker: NA
Text: animal husbandry, we have 6.5 veterinary

Speaker: NA
Text: surgeons for every million head of stock,

Speaker: NA
Text: while Britain has 94 and the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: 65. These deficiencies are an index of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's 20-year failure to take an ade-

Speaker: NA
Text: quate or appropriate interest in education.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are not, however, the only index. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is indicative of the Government's whole

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to education that the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, the Attorney-General ( Mr Bowen) and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Education and Science have

Speaker: NA
Text: given serious consideration over recent

Speaker: NA
Text: months to withdrawing scholarships from

Speaker: NA
Text: students who participate in demonstrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is indicative that income derived by

Speaker: NA
Text: universities from fees increased between

Speaker: NA
Text: 1963 and 1966 by 234%, although enrol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments increased by only 32%. Clearly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's policy is one of making uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versities less free and more expensive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, State governments oblige the uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versities to increase their fees in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: squeeze greater sums from the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth through its commitment for scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships, to wit, the payment of fees for

Speaker: NA
Text: scholars.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1966, 10% of university income, or

Speaker: NA
Text: $17m out of almost $171m, came from

Speaker: NA
Text: student fees and of these student fees 40%

Speaker: NA
Text: were paid by the Commonwealth. More

Speaker: NA
Text: than $135m came from Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: and. State government grants. The aboli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of fees would cost only $llm but

Speaker: NA
Text: would produce many favourable results.

Speaker: NA
Text: There would be a temporary strain on

Speaker: NA
Text: university places, but it would be fairer

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the places allotted on ability tban

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed by parental income or employer

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsorship. As free university places in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased, universities would cease to be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as places for an elite alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parents would recognise that a tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: education is just as natural for their

Speaker: NA
Text: children as a primary and secondary educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Sweden plans education to the age

Speaker: NA
Text: of 18 years for 80% of its population

Speaker: NA
Text: by 1970 and for 96% of its population

Speaker: NA
Text: by 1980. I would recall that a generation

Speaker: NA
Text: ago Sweden had the lowest per capita in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come in Europe. Today it has the highest.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has made the maximum use of its natural

Speaker: NA
Text: and human resources. It has educated its

Speaker: NA
Text: people and its people therefore are able

Speaker: NA
Text: to make the maximum use of its natural

Speaker: NA
Text: resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is remarkable and reprehensible that

Speaker: NA
Text: any government should direct scarce educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional resources into the hands of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: need them least. A Labor government would

Speaker: NA
Text: not give scholarships to children whose

Speaker: NA
Text: families are in any case able to support

Speaker: NA
Text: them throughout their school careers while

Speaker: NA
Text: refusing grants to the schools on which

Speaker: NA
Text: underprivileged Australians depend for an

Speaker: NA
Text: equal opportunity in education. It would not

Speaker: NA
Text: finance second science blocks for wealthy

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government schools while other govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and non-government schools are still

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting for their first blocks. Guided by a

Speaker: NA
Text: representative schools commission, Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: will develop in both government and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools the excellence which at

Speaker: NA
Text: present characterises an affluent and for-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate few. Labor will invest discriminately

Speaker: NA
Text: in schools the resources required to over-

Speaker: NA
Text: come cultural deprivation and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage, lt will provide the living

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances which families with smaller

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes require to support children through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out their secondary school careers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor believes that able students should

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer be priced out of a university

Speaker: NA
Text: education, as my deputy said in resuming

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate on this Bill. Labor will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: over three years an additional $llm a year

Speaker: NA
Text: to abolish fees at all Australian universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: For this investment the places for which

Speaker: NA
Text: fees are now charged will be filled by

Speaker: NA
Text: students on the basis of academic capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: and not financial capacity. As an integral

Speaker: NA
Text: part of its plan for the achievement of

Speaker: NA
Text: excellence in schools a Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide free teacher training for pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pective teachers in both the government and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-government school systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the Commonwealth 12 years ago

Speaker: NA
Text: entered upon its commitments, pursuant to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Murray Committee's report, to help

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian universities it required the Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity of Western Australia-th e only uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity in Australia which has been free-

Speaker: NA
Text: to charge fees over the course of the years

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent to those charged in other univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities. Accordingly, whereas in the last 11

Speaker: NA
Text: years other Australian universities have

Speaker: NA
Text: doubled or trebled their fees, in the Univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity of Western Australia the fees which

Speaker: NA
Text: have now to be paid are ten times what

Speaker: NA
Text: was paid in sports union, union and all

Speaker: NA
Text: other charges in the course of getting a

Speaker: NA
Text: university degree. Far from making univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity education free, the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively ended free university education

Speaker: NA
Text: in the only university which had it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth used its money power io

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the University of Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia could not expand or improve with

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe funds which the Commonwealth alone

Speaker: NA
Text: could make available unless it abandoned

Speaker: NA
Text: its principles and imposed charges over the

Speaker: NA
Text: following decade to bring it into line with

Speaker: NA
Text: all the other universities in Australia-thos e

Speaker: NA
Text: already operating and those established in

Speaker: NA
Text: the interim.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only the Commonwealth can now ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that an equal opportunity is given to every

Speaker: NA
Text: student to develop his natural talents irres-

Speaker: NA
Text: pective of his parents' locality, relig on, :

Speaker: NA
Text: means or occupation. The parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers of students at government schools

Speaker: NA
Text: must realise that they will not receive

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary assistance from the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth unless the Commonwealth also

Speaker: NA
Text: gives assistance to non-government schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: The parents and teachers at non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government schools must realise that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are unlikely to receive necessary assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Commonwealth unless govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment schools are assisted by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. The Commonwealth must realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that it can involve itself as naturally in

Speaker: NA
Text: the affairs of all schools as it now does

Speaker: NA
Text: in the affairs of all tertiary institutions save

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers' colleges alone. It must accept as

Speaker: NA
Text: its aim the provision of services without

Speaker: NA
Text: charge at every level of the education

Speaker: NA
Text: system. Scholarships, to which this Bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: restricted, are a method of providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: free education for a minority of students

Speaker: NA
Text: who already excel!. They do nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: emancipate the majority of students, whose

Speaker: NA
Text: natural talents remain under existing con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions unrecognised and underdeveloped.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Angas) [9.27]-Th e first

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to which I would like to draw the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the House is the fascinating

Speaker: NA
Text: comment by the Leader of the Opposition The

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Whitlam), by way of interjection, if

Speaker: NA
Text: my ears did not deceive me, that the honourfor

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Barton ( Mr Arthur) was

Speaker: NA
Text: reading from copious notes.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: An d reading poorly.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: O n the contrary, it was the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition who read poorly.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think ihe honourable member for Barton

Speaker: NA
Text: read rather well. I think that anybody

Speaker: NA
Text: would shoot arrows in the fashion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition might at least

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt a more liberal method of putting

Speaker: NA
Text: over a speech so that it sounded a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more interesting for those on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: the House who had to listen to the honourit

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman struggling through it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would remind the Leader of the Oppothe

Speaker: NA
Text: sition of one small point. Tonight he seemed

Speaker: NA
Text: to adopt a rather noval method of dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with his topic. He employed phrases such

Speaker: NA
Text: as 'an affluent and fortunate few*. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: last few weeks he seems to have been conment

Speaker: NA
Text: ducting a personal vendetta-h e is not alone

Speaker: NA
Text: in this. He. would have us believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: class war exists, as though we were still

Speaker: NA
Text: the throes of the depression. He also

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely contradicted remarks that he

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the past. I would like to quote

Speaker: NA
Text: remark passed about the Federal Governamount

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's record in education by a man

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia named Chamberlain.

Speaker: NA
Text: The remark was made at a meeting in

Speaker: NA
Text: March 1964.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Webb-Tak e your hand out of your

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Th e honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: would need to take both hands out. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamberlain said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment by the Federal Government

Speaker: NA
Text: of science blocks and the provision of science

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities in private schools is quite obviously con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary to Federal Party policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within a few weeks the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition had said that he thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's decision was consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the prime socialist objective of ensurreason

Speaker: NA
Text: ing an equal opportunity for all in life.

Speaker: NA
Text: does the Leader of the Opposition reconcile

Speaker: NA
Text: that encouraging statement about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's policy on education with his

Speaker: NA
Text: discovery tonight of the class war? He re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to an affluent and fortunate few, and

Speaker: NA
Text: used these sorts of phrases. I suppose there

Speaker: NA
Text: are one or two reasons to account for this.

Speaker: NA
Text: first, I expect, is that he imagines there

Speaker: NA
Text: is an election due shortly and he is scuffling

Speaker: NA
Text: cover in view of his other rather un-

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate thoughts in terms of aid to all

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of education. The second reason

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly would be that the case of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government in the field of

Speaker: NA
Text: education has been so remarkably success-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful in the eyes of the people of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: that frankly all that is left to do is to

Speaker: NA
Text: who mouth a few words of encouragement along

Speaker: NA
Text: the line.

Speaker: NA
Text: This time last year the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition congratulated the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: of on its Socialist objective and the efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: was putting into education. This year,

Speaker: NA
Text: things being different when they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: same, he seems to take a different point

Speaker: NA
Text: of view. Let us look at some of these facts

Speaker: NA
Text: or at some of his opinions. The first matter

Speaker: NA
Text: to which he referred and which alarmed

Speaker: NA
Text: me-an d I think rightly so-wa s his state-

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was an intentional slowing

Speaker: NA
Text: down by the Government in various fields

Speaker: NA
Text: a of education. This is the most rotten

Speaker: NA
Text: in statement that I have heard for some time,

Speaker: NA
Text: comand that is saying plenty. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: has ment's record is one of doubling the

Speaker: NA
Text: a number of scholarships of doubling the

Speaker: NA
Text: spent within a period of 5 or 7

Speaker: NA
Text: from years in every category of education

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by this Bill. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham)

Speaker: NA
Text: is trying to interject. Queensland has not

Speaker: NA
Text: a remarkably good record in any of these

Speaker: NA
Text: fields due to the terrible fact that it had a

Speaker: NA
Text: long and dismal run of Labor State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments which put Queensland so far behind

Speaker: NA
Text: every other State in the field of education

Speaker: NA
Text: that frankly it is not funny if you look

Speaker: NA
Text: at national need at this point of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leaving that matter aside, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition then said that the national

Speaker: NA
Text: aspirations of the younger people of today

Speaker: NA
Text: were for greater education. I suppose he

Speaker: NA
Text: was logically thinking that that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: why they supported his Party in the

Speaker: NA
Text: How new electorates during the last general

Speaker: NA
Text: election. Any opposition can sit back and

Speaker: NA
Text: come good with wild ideas, it having no

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility, no power of the purse and

Speaker: NA
Text: not having to draw up its own priorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: It just talks for the sake of talking. As

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I am concerned, this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has given a lead to this country in a very

Speaker: NA
Text: few years that has meant that education

Speaker: NA
Text: has gone on step by step to the remarkably

Speaker: NA
Text: successful stage at which we find it today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the last few years the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth scholarships given, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, in terms of applicants has been

Speaker: NA
Text: better than 1 in 4. This is at a time when

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole population of Australia is in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creasing its affluence and its determination

Speaker: NA
Text: for education and when people on the

Speaker: NA
Text: minimal wage in this country are succeed-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, through their own thrift, in sending

Speaker: NA
Text: children right through education-righ t

Speaker: NA
Text: through university courses. They are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: this in some cases of which 1 know-no t

Speaker: NA
Text: frequently-regrettabl y without the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of scholarships because they have not won

Speaker: NA
Text: them. This is the stage which this country

Speaker: NA
Text: has reached. People want to provide for

Speaker: NA
Text: their children and send them on to higher

Speaker: NA
Text: education. I do not think it is any use the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition thinking back to the days when

Speaker: NA
Text: these things could not be done, because

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 feel rather keenly on this matter because

Speaker: NA
Text: a relation of mine who happened to be

Speaker: NA
Text: quite brilliant- a female-wen t through an

Speaker: NA
Text: economics degree course in the 1950s. She

Speaker: NA
Text: got her Batchelor of Economics degree. She

Speaker: NA
Text: went on and did her Master of Economics

Speaker: NA
Text: degree, and passed with top honours in

Speaker: NA
Text: every subject. In those days this unfortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate girl who was highly qualified and

Speaker: NA
Text: highly educated but who, perhaps because

Speaker: NA
Text: she was a female, could not get a job,

Speaker: NA
Text: because there was no room within the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy of the nation at that time for that

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of qualification, if the person concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: was a female. This molehill does not make

Speaker: NA
Text: a mountain, but I think the point was taken

Speaker: NA
Text: very well by my friend the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Barton ( Mr Arthur) a short

Speaker: NA
Text: time ago when he referred to the necessity

Speaker: NA
Text: for a national balance in education. The

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which this should be done has been

Speaker: NA
Text: accurately described by numerous expert

Speaker: NA
Text: committees which have looked into this

Speaker: NA
Text: question. They have said that we need a

Speaker: NA
Text: balance in education today.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite wrong on any statistic to adopt

Speaker: NA
Text: the point of view which the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition adopted when he said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was attempting to slow down

Speaker: NA
Text: these things. In any figures at which one

Speaker: NA
Text: cares to look-an d I will not weary the

Speaker: NA
Text: House by repeating them-ther e is the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the number of universities in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country has approximately trebled in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last 9 years. But it is no earthly use having

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole nation of university graduates. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: think that any honourable member opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: will agree with me that this is so. One can

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about the national aspirations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: young people. One can try to ensure, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as a government can, that every student

Speaker: NA
Text: will be given, as far as possible, equal

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity. But there are many people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the community today who do not feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: half the youngsters of Australia should be

Speaker: NA
Text: university graduates. Many people in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia today do not feel that this is the way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which Australia should go.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said previously, many expert com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittees have laid it on the counter quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly that our shortage in education in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia today is in the field of technology.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not only we who have in this Held a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of trained and technically accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: plished young people; this is the case in the

Speaker: NA
Text: developing countries around us. 1 think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition, when he

Speaker: NA
Text: makes some of his sweeping statements, for-

Speaker: NA
Text: gets a lot of matters, including the fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: effort of this Government in the field of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing scholarships under the Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan, and the role which we are playing in

Speaker: NA
Text: the region in which we live. There are Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: people training in this country today who

Speaker: NA
Text: in other countries would comprise an entitre

Speaker: NA
Text: university. This is a mighty performance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think, perhaps, it might be as well to

Speaker: NA
Text: look, for instance, at the number of new

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolments and total enrolments since the

Speaker: NA
Text: inception of the Commonwealth scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship scheme. In 1951 there were 28,000

Speaker: NA
Text: total enrolments. In 1961 total enrolments

Speaker: NA
Text: had approximately doubled to 52,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Between 1961 and 1968 they increased to

Speaker: NA
Text: 90,000. Once again there has been almost

Speaker: NA
Text: a doubling in the number. This Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has succeeded in providing scholarships at,

Speaker: NA
Text: by and large, an increasing rate, contrary to

Speaker: NA
Text: the point made, I think, by the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Barnard), who

Speaker: NA
Text: referred, perhaps, to a shorter number of

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and contrary to the point made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition. Over 8 years

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government has succeeded in maintain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the same ratio of scholarships to tolal

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolments. In the years to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: just referred, 1951 to 1968, the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: total enrolments not only doubled, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: doubled again. This is no mean feat. Quite

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary to the position in 1951, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Barton quite accur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately described it when scholarships were

Speaker: NA
Text: down to 400 for the whole of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of the period of rule by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party and total enrolments

Speaker: NA
Text: at universities were only 28,000, enrolments

Speaker: NA
Text: today are nearly 90,000 and the percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: of scholarships from 1951 onwards has

Speaker: NA
Text: improved. Therefore, I do not think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition is telling the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole story when he refers to only one

Speaker: NA
Text: factor. There are other factors involved

Speaker: NA
Text: that are very important and I think amply

Speaker: NA
Text: vindicate the Government for the mighty

Speaker: NA
Text: effort it has put into the field of education

Speaker: NA
Text: over the years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another favourite trick of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: on any debate on education is to impress

Speaker: NA
Text: on this House and those who might be

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to a broadcast thc deep national

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of education. 1 accept thut it is

Speaker: NA
Text: nationally important. It has very significant

Speaker: NA
Text: national implications indeed. But the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition always glosses over the fact that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are living in a federation and the State

Speaker: NA
Text: vernments do take seriously their responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities in the field of education. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition convinced the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: today that we should have a national in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiry into education I profoundly believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the knowledge that I have of my own

Speaker: NA
Text: State and others adjoining it, that the State

Speaker: NA
Text: governments would not co-operate 'vith the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth in such an inquiry. If I am

Speaker: NA
Text: right-an d I cannot, of course, give evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence that I am-wha t is the point in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition repeatedly requesting the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment to hold a national inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: education? I wonder who is bluffing whom

Speaker: NA
Text: on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: my own State of South Australia, :n rather

Speaker: NA
Text: a derogatory fashion, I felt. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: why he picked on the South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment. One would have thought that he

Speaker: NA
Text: might have picked on, for instance, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian Governnient, because at that

Speaker: NA
Text: point of his argument he was playing down

Speaker: NA
Text: the interest of Liberal governments in edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. But, to be fair, he did not do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead he mentioned South Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: said that South Australia is running its own

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into education. If he had net been

Speaker: NA
Text: reading his speech I would have interjected

Speaker: NA
Text: and asked him why he thought that South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia should not inquire inio its educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion system. Although we give section 96

Speaker: NA
Text: grants and other grants to the States, the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for education is still with 'he

Speaker: NA
Text: States and I know of no reason why the

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australian Government should not

Speaker: NA
Text: hold an inquiry into education if it wishes

Speaker: NA
Text: to. I agree that State committees of inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: into State education systems must be

Speaker: NA
Text: limited. But then, so is the responsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: thc Commonwealth Government of today

Speaker: NA
Text: limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: lt is easy, I suppose, for the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to imagine what it would do if it attained

Speaker: NA
Text: office. Would its attitude be any difierent

Speaker: NA
Text: from that of the Government today? If it

Speaker: NA
Text: were, would it be accused of being centralist

Speaker: NA
Text: and of trying to dictate to the States in

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters? Would the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that the Commonwealth should so

Speaker: NA
Text: dictate? ff the answer to this is no, then, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I asked before, what is tbe basis for this

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion of a national inquiry? Is it based

Speaker: NA
Text: on reality or is it based cn bluff? What is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition's point in coming forward

Speaker: NA
Text: go- so frequently devoid of argument ond rely-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing solely on the demand for a ig inquiry?

Speaker: NA
Text: h

Speaker: NA
Text: This has been going on for 5 years now to

Speaker: NA
Text: my certain knowledge.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition also

Speaker: NA
Text: attacked the Government with an argument

Speaker: NA
Text: based on the percentage of gross national

Speaker: NA
Text: product spent on education in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the original idea for this form of

Speaker: NA
Text: attack came from Professor Karmel of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia who made a comparison

Speaker: NA
Text: many years ago of the percentage of gross

Speaker: NA
Text: national product spent on education in

Speaker: NA
Text: various countries. His comments and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parisons were always taken out of perspec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive by those who wished to use a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parison without telling the whole, story. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that very shortly after Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: know Karmel made those statements, and after

Speaker: NA
Text: GoI had heard Opposition, both State and

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal, attacking governments on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of Professor Karmel's ngures, I ran into

Speaker: NA
Text: him in South Australia and asked him

Speaker: NA
Text: about the different standards adopted in

Speaker: NA
Text: different countries in connection with ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure on education. I knew very little

Speaker: NA
Text: about it at that tirne. He set to to tell me

Speaker: NA
Text: the different standards adopted in various

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. I do not remember them all now,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do remember, for instance, that ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure on education in the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom includes the cost of free lunches. I

Speaker: NA
Text: expect that in Queensland it would include

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of air-conditioning plants-bu t I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not know. There was a wide variety of edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cational costs in the English total figures

Speaker: NA
Text: on which the percentage of gross national

Speaker: NA
Text: product was based.

Speaker: NA
Text: The standards vary widely from country

Speaker: NA
Text: to country. If I remember rightly, in

Speaker: NA
Text: Switzerland the education costs included

Speaker: NA
Text: interest on capital expenditure incurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe construction of school buildings. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: deny very vigorously that Australia suffers

Speaker: NA
Text: at all, on any comparison in real terms

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than imaginary ones, based on a

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of gross national product.

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankly, I have not looked at these figures

Speaker: NA
Text: for 18 months or so. But when I last looked

Speaker: NA
Text: at them I was quite convinced that this

Speaker: NA
Text: country had nothing to be worried about

Speaker: NA
Text: on any comparison based on a percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: of gross national product.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are briefly the points in the speech

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Leader of the Opposition that in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terested me. I would like, for a moment,

Speaker: NA
Text: to get back to the terms of the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: itself. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: who spoke before the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, referred to the 1967 Act which was

Speaker: NA
Text: put before another place during that year

Speaker: NA
Text: requesting sweeping powers. He said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the other place at that time argued in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of regulations. The Government at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time, probably being aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation then existing, accepted many of

Speaker: NA
Text: the remarks and comments made in the

Speaker: NA
Text: other place. Several people, one of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: was mentioned by the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition by name, now have confidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I notice that the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition referred to clause 11 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Scholarships Bill. Clause 11 deals with beneform.

Speaker: NA
Text: fits under Commonwealth secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships. The Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition pointed out that he would have

Speaker: NA
Text: no complaint with clauses 1 to 10. He said

Speaker: NA
Text: that his only complaint with clause 11 would

Speaker: NA
Text: revolve around the use of the word 'pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed'. Clause 11 states:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the payment by the Commonwealth in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect of each year in which the scholarship

Speaker: NA
Text: is held, for the purpose of assistance in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to text boots and equipment for

Speaker: NA
Text: use by the holder of the scholarship, of such

Speaker: NA
Text: amount as is prescribed for the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: of this paragraph;

Speaker: NA
Text: I suppose the Deputy Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition is slightly more experienced than I

Speaker: NA
Text: am in theses masters. But the use of the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'prescribed', to my way of thinking,

Speaker: NA
Text: can mean nothing other than 'prescribed by

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation'. If anyone has any doubt on

Speaker: NA
Text: that, other than the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, I would like to hear his inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: pretation. From my experience of State go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernments and my minor experience here

Speaker: NA
Text: I know of no way in which we could inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: pret this term other than that it n eans 'pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed by regulation'. Although I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: had a chance to consult with the Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no doubt that he will say precisely

Speaker: NA
Text: the same thing as I am saying when he

Speaker: NA
Text: replies to the comments made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill sets up three criteria. As these were

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Barton, I will not repeat them. The only

Speaker: NA
Text: source of doubt in my mind was not re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to by the Opposition. I refer to clause

Speaker: NA
Text: 19, which reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister may, by instrument in writing

Speaker: NA
Text: Which I take to be definitely not

Speaker: NA
Text: verbally

Speaker: NA
Text: delegate to a person, either generally or other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise as provided in the instrument of delegation,

Speaker: NA
Text: all or any of his powers or functions under this

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, except this power of delegation.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 am not clear to whom this power can be

Speaker: NA
Text: delegated. I do not know whether it can

Speaker: NA
Text: be delegated to an officer of the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Education and Science or whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the person to which the clause refers must

Speaker: NA
Text: be a prescribed person. That is my main

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt. Having regard to the line of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate in the other place on the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion, I have no doubts whatsoever,

Speaker: NA
Text: except the one to which I have referred,

Speaker: NA
Text: about the wording of the Bill in its new

Speaker: NA
Text: A little while ago I referred to new enrol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and I quoted some figures. I thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that as soon as I could find some figures

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to the contention by the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition that the quality of pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and aUowances in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships in the five fields covered by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill has not been kept up to standard

Speaker: NA
Text: I should cite them. I hope the figures 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have are entirely accurate and that I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not misquoting the Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion when I say that he said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of allowances and other payments

Speaker: NA
Text: had been downgraded by the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: over the years. One could argue whether

Speaker: NA
Text: his remarks are correct in every facet-i n

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to South Australia for instance.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they are not true of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth's interest in its own scholarships.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many indicators to support this

Speaker: NA
Text: contention. Let us take as an example the

Speaker: NA
Text: living away from home allowance which is

Speaker: NA
Text: paid fo full time scholars by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government. In 1961, 39% of those

Speaker: NA
Text: in receipt of scholarships claimed the living

Speaker: NA
Text: away from home allowance. Today, 44.3%

Speaker: NA
Text: are claiming this allowance. This is in

Speaker: NA
Text: spite of the huge increase in enrolments at

Speaker: NA
Text: universities. Another indicator is the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age allowance per scholar. In 1961 it was

Speaker: NA
Text: $434; today it is $534. So these payments

Speaker: NA
Text: have, in real terms, more than kept up with

Speaker: NA
Text: the standards set in the past. This is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary to the remarks of the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite frankly, I think that the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is very wise in not opposing the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has adopted a typical

Speaker: NA
Text: tactic that it adopts from time to time of

Speaker: NA
Text: preaching that more of everything is good

Speaker: NA
Text: for all. I am happy with the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth's involvement in the field of educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I think it has proved lo be extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile. The Commonwealth's rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure in this field is increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: enormously. I believe that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth cannot just rush in and attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: take over the control of education from the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments. Frequently the State

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have a far more intimate

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of local priorities. Tn my view

Speaker: NA
Text: much of the control of education in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future must be retained by those closest to

Speaker: NA
Text: the local scene. I suppose it is all a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of priorities. Any Opposition could habitu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally take the point of view that there must

Speaker: NA
Text: toe more expenditure on everything. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: just a fact of life. I am quite sure that if

Speaker: NA
Text: one spoke quietly to many of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite one would find that they

Speaker: NA
Text: completely approve the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: record. But at this time of the year, with

Speaker: NA
Text: exciting times around the corner and elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions hoving in view, it is customary for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition to say: 'Let us spend a bit more

Speaker: NA
Text: on everything'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support the Bill. 1 congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Education and Science on the

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated and lirst-class job that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. 1 conclude my remarks by saying

Speaker: NA
Text: only one thing by way of complaint. 1 think

Speaker: NA
Text: that the means test on the living away from

Speaker: NA
Text: home allowance for scholarship holders-

Speaker: NA
Text: naturally this relates more to those living

Speaker: NA
Text: in country areas than it does to those living

Speaker: NA
Text: in city areas-shoul d be raised. Quite

Speaker: NA
Text: recently 1 had personal experience in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard concerning two families living in

Speaker: NA
Text: that fine area I represent, the Barossa Val-

Speaker: NA
