Text: ley, where incomes can be very erratic. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously believe that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should relax the means test as it applies to

Speaker: NA
Text: living away from home allowances. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that where incomes are erratic, as they can

Speaker: NA
Text: be in areas where people do not have an

Speaker: NA
Text: assured weekly salary, people can be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: advantaged. I think you will agree, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, that that is a very small

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion lo make. I congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government upon its education policy.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Lucock)

Speaker: NA
Text: -Order ! The honourable member's time

Speaker: NA
Text: has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr PA1TERSON (Dawson) [9.58]- 1

Speaker: NA
Text: support the remarks made by the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Barnard) and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Whidam).

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 have listened with interest to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Barton ( Mr Arthur) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Angas ( Mr Giles).

Speaker: NA
Text: What struck me most about their remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: was their attempts to criticise the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition for raising the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are many parents in Australia who

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot afford to send their children to

Speaker: NA
Text: places of higher learning. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Barton and, to the best of my

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge, the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Angas said that the Australian Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: was living in the past, the post-depression

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and that this is 1969. 1 do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: what sort of electorates the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members for Barton and Angas represent,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is quite obvious that they mix in only

Speaker: NA
Text: the most elite circles. They do not have any

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with tbe under privileged people

Speaker: NA
Text: who must surely exist even in their

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Th e average person in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate would earn less than the average

Speaker: NA
Text: person in your electorate; make no mistake.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: Th e honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has had his say. There must be

Speaker: NA
Text: people in his electorate who cannot afford

Speaker: NA
Text: to send their children to places of higher

Speaker: NA
Text: learning, such as an institute of technology

Speaker: NA
Text: or a university. Certainly in the areas that

Speaker: NA
Text: I know there is still a large proportion of

Speaker: NA
Text: parents who do not have sufficient means

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to send their children-eve n

Speaker: NA
Text: if those children have the capacity-t o

Speaker: NA
Text: places of higher learning. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member instanced a relative of his who

Speaker: NA
Text: gained, t sbould think with honours or

Speaker: NA
Text: distinction, the degree of Master of

Speaker: NA
Text: Economics and could not find a job. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not quarrel with the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: about the facts, but I find it extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: because in the 1950s, the period he quoted,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a tremendous demand for trained

Speaker: NA
Text: economists. That was a period when

Speaker: NA
Text: economists were coming into their own in

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing numbers as compared with arts

Speaker: NA
Text: students. There were few university

Speaker: NA
Text: graduates in economics and my own ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience at that time was that there was

Speaker: NA
Text: a dearth- a shortage-o f economists, parti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cularly those with the degree of Master of

Speaker: NA
Text: Economics. It is possible that the particular

Speaker: NA
Text: person to whom the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: referred may have wanted to specialise in

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain field of economics and there may

Speaker: NA
Text: not have been opportunities in that field.

Speaker: NA
Text: But speaking generally there is, always has

Speaker: NA
Text: been and will be in the near future anyhow

Speaker: NA
Text: a strong demand for trained economists.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was not certain what the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Angas meant, but if he meant

Speaker: NA
Text: what I think he meant, I agree with him

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is an imbalance with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: the types of graduates who are graduating

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australian universities. He made the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that there is a serious deficiency in

Speaker: NA
Text: the field of technology. He did not define

Speaker: NA
Text: technology, but technology, of course, can

Speaker: NA
Text: include university graduates in the fields

Speaker: NA
Text: of engineering and in the sciences for ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample. The main point I wish to make

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns the problem of priorities and how

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Scholarships Board

Speaker: NA
Text: member wants to speak, why does he not

Speaker: NA
Text: I am only going to give this one example

Text: ciplines I rank the former as a practical

Text: post-graduate awards we find that post-

Text: graduate scholarships in music arefivetimes

Speaker: NA
Text: as many as post-graduate scholarships in

Text: science it is the export meat industry. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 am using this only as a practical

Speaker: NA
Text: example because, as I have said before,

Speaker: NA
Text: have no wish to criticise or degrade postpeople

Speaker: NA

Text: I am biased- I believe that post-graduate

Text: rinary science is more important to this

Speaker: NA
Text: nation when Commonwealth funds are Australia?

Text: involved. I am not saying this in respect of

Text: the funds of private individuals who can do

Text: what they like, but I am concerned where

Text: Commonwealth funds are involved. This

Text: the principle I am arguing: Some priority

Speaker: NA
Text: faculties. In Australia there are areas

Text: work that are crying out for more trained

Text: men, because there is a shortage of such

Text: men. I do not know whether there is

Text: shortage of graduates in French, German

Text: or music. Perhaps there are. But I do know

Text: that there is a severe shortage of trained

Text: agricultural scientists to do very valuable

Text: work in the arid zone of Australia for

Text: example. This zone is of extreme imporwill

Text: tance to Australia, but it is an area about

Text: which we know very Httle. We need ecopersonnel.

Text: logists, botanists, agronomists and climatolo-

Text: gists-peopl e trained in the specialties of

Text: agricultural or applied science-t o work on

Text: various problems in this area. I am arguing

Text: that some greater priority should be given

Text: to the practical side-t o those areas where

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a definite shortage of trained men.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the northern parts of Australia we have

Speaker: NA
Text: a severe shortage of agricultural scientists

Speaker: NA
Text: to work in the field of tropical pastures.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a field which has tremendous scope

Text: income. We must do everything possible to

Text: tropical pastures.

Text: This Government pays a subsidy on

Speaker: NA
Text: nitrogen, but very little is known in Aus :

Text: tralia about the effect, of nitrogen on

Text: pastures. Most of the elements that have

Text: been applied to pastures have been phos?

Speaker: NA
Text: phatic materials, not nitrogenous materials.

Text: The Commonwealth Scientific and Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial Research Organisation and the Depart-

Text: be achieved by applying' nitrogen to native

Text: pastures and to some species of natural

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 shortage of agricultural scientists and

Speaker: NA
Text: trained in this field who can get the

Text: knowledge across to the farmer and show

Speaker: NA
Text: d perhaps him what can be achieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: this overseas that could be applied to

Text: I do not think suffi-

Text: be given to those fields of work where

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a definite shortage of trained

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not wish to say anything more than

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Wills) [10.14]-I n many

Speaker: NA
Text: ways in this BiM we see a change in Ihe

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which the Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment looks at education. I suppose we can

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the 1945 Education Act arrived

Speaker: NA
Text: with a bang because it marked the entry

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth into the field of edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation in a legislative way for the first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since then it seems to have vanished from

Speaker: NA
Text: the field without even a whimper. It is time

Speaker: NA
Text: the attention of the House was drawn to

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that what was the original charter

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Parliament in regard to education

Speaker: NA
Text: has been withdrawn and has been replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: by a definition of certain areas of scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. These scholarships are granted on a

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive basis and are about the only

Speaker: NA
Text: area of Commonwealth activity in educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion today. So I think it is time that we

Speaker: NA
Text: applied ourselves to some of the principles

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which the Commonwealth Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be operating.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight we are considering what one

Speaker: NA
Text: might call a hotch-potch of political seda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives. In recent years the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrated on various fields, some of

Text: which have been politically expedient. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer io the Commonwealth grants to the

Speaker: NA
Text: States for science laboratories and second-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary school libraries. In general, at times,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has done whatever has

Speaker: NA
Text: been politically expedient. I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is because of pressure from the

Speaker: NA
Text: universities or pressure from other bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: for scholarships in certain fields that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: done this. I see no concept of a Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth education policy. I see no plan or

Speaker: NA
Text: system being developed. If Australian edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation needs anything, it is planning and

Speaker: NA
Text: some systematic approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 deny the assertions by honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite that we members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition are centralist to the extent that

Speaker: NA
Text: we want everything controlled from some

Speaker: NA
Text: press button system operating in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are nothing of the sort. Those of us

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with education on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House would be the first to admit that we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know quite the best way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: communities ought to participate in educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion or the best way of utilising the great

Speaker: NA
Text: resources of national effort that are avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to us. I have a hope that somewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canberra perhaps these problems are

Speaker: NA
Text: being worked out. I would like to see Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth ancl State officials sitting side by

Speaker: NA
Text: side, working almost in the same office, on

Speaker: NA
Text: a modus operandi for educational effort that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be an example to the whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Perhaps it is possible to get this

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of co-operation by establishing a sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem of local education authorities through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out Auslralia, each covering, say 150,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to 200,000 people. There is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: with the administrative competence thai is

Speaker: NA
Text: available to us, with the financial stability

Speaker: NA
Text: that enables us to give anything if we really

Speaker: NA
Text: try, and with the lines of communication

Speaker: NA
Text: that are available no matter where any per-

Speaker: NA
Text: son may live, we ought to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve something.

Speaker: NA
Text: My regret is that in this instance we are

Speaker: NA
Text: repealing what is the fundamental charter

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Parliament and replacing it with a

Speaker: NA
Text: very singlcminded education objective. In

Speaker: NA
Text: some ways I am one of those who believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that scholarships do not have strictly educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional objectives. They represent some ideal

Speaker: NA
Text: which I reject as an educational ideal. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: know, of course, that some of the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite seem to be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely out of sympathy with our approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to education. 1 think it was the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Angas ( Mr Giles) who sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested that the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Whitlam) was dredging up some

Speaker: NA
Text: elements of the class war. I am not sure

Speaker: NA
Text: what exactly he did say, but I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: he attacked the concept that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: economic deprivation in the field of educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in Australia. One only has to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's background to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that he does not know what serious to

Speaker: NA
Text: economic deprivation could mean, and 1 in Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: would not like to wish economic hardship

Speaker: NA
Text: upon him.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the present time the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Science ( Mr Malcolm

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser) in all his public announcements

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to be concerned with non-State

Speaker: NA
Text: education. We can look at his public

Speaker: NA
Text: announcements and see that they are always

Text: concerned with some political gimmickry

Text: such as what we are to do with what are

Speaker: NA
Text: technically called independent, schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: course, independent schools are non-existent

Speaker: NA
Text: anyhow. I do not see any approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: education in the total sense. I would remind

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members that the 1945 Educabe

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Act imposed some seven or eight

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations upon the Commonwealth Office

Speaker: NA
Text: of Education. One would presume that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Education and Science has

Speaker: NA
Text: become the beir of the functions of this

Speaker: NA
Text: body. What has been happening to some

Speaker: NA
Text: of these obligations? One obligation was

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the Minister on matters relating

Speaker: NA
Text: education. I. have no doubt that that is

Speaker: NA
Text: done. Another obligation was to establish

Speaker: NA
Text: and maintain a liaison on matters relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to education with other countries and with

Speaker: NA
Text: the States and to arrange for consultations

Speaker: NA
Text: between Commonwealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities on matters relating to education.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were three or four more of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: - The interesting point is that tbis charter

Speaker: NA
Text: was enshrined in legislation and it was

Speaker: NA
Text: for all to read. Tonight we are repealing

Speaker: NA
Text: that charter, we are removing it from the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The Government makes no

Speaker: NA
Text: attack upon what I believe are the features

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian education that ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: under attack. What are we doing about probably

Speaker: NA
Text: inequalities in education? The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, tbe Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ( Mr Barnard) and the honourpresent

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Dawson (Dr Patterson)

Speaker: NA
Text: have pointed out where some of these women

Speaker: NA
Text: inequalities lie. There is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: are great inequalities in this country arising

Speaker: NA
Text: from geography. Some of it is political

Speaker: NA
Text: geography inasmuch as there is a difference

Speaker: NA
Text: between the capacity of universities in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales and universities in Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: absorb students. This is the product of

Speaker: NA
Text: political attitudes that have developed over

Speaker: NA
Text: a quarter to half a century. People in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales in general have greater access

Speaker: NA
Text: university education than people who live

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there is the geographical disability

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed upon people who live in remote

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. What are we doing lo allow people

Speaker: NA
Text: who pass through the secondary stage of

Speaker: NA
Text: education in the remoter areas, of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to find satisfactory accommodation and

Speaker: NA
Text: financial support when they do go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: university? What are we doing to supply

Speaker: NA
Text: some mobility inside the university scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: so that the Australian National University

Speaker: NA
Text: Of could be expanded by perhaps 4,000 or

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000 students, or so that the university in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, the one at Townsville or the one

Speaker: NA
Text: at Armidaie could be expanded? This might

Speaker: NA
Text: a more satisfactory method of approach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the problem tban expanding the metro-

Speaker: NA
Text: politan universities. One does not have to

Speaker: NA
Text: look very far to realise that there are great

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of economic deprivation in Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: education. I represent one of the industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of Australia, an area in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: to great majority of the. people are in the

Speaker: NA
Text: to lower income bracket. Every family whose

Speaker: NA
Text: being children manage to matriculate, and even

Speaker: NA
Text: those whose children achieve a Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scholarship, have a great struggle to

Speaker: NA
Text: get their children through to the university.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has made no approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: State this problem at all. The general Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scholarship scheme is based upon

Speaker: NA
Text: what might be called academic excellence,

Speaker: NA
Text: or whatever it is that one achieves to get

Speaker: NA
Text: a satisfactory result at the secondary and

Speaker: NA
Text: there tertiary level. As I said, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to this problem at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tlie great wastage in Australian educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is the disability imposed upon women

Speaker: NA
Text: by their sex. As I have said before, this is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a political' issue but is some-

Speaker: NA
Text: of thing to do with the society in which we

Speaker: NA
Text: live. I tbink the ngures show that at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time about 60,000 or 70,000 young

Speaker: NA
Text: men and about 25,000 or 30,000 young

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia are at the universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: there Between 40,000 and 50,000 young women

Speaker: NA
Text: have the same capacities as their brothers,

Speaker: NA
Text: and same social backgrounds, the same

Speaker: NA
Text: economic backgrounds and the same intel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lectual capacities. These girls who take out

Speaker: NA
Text: to prizes at certain levels of education some-

Speaker: NA
Text: how drop out of the system. This is a most

Speaker: NA
Text: tragic wastage. It is one that all honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: New members have to take up in some way or

Speaker: NA
Text: other if Australia is to get the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: possible advantage from the intellectual

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is also the wastage based upon

Speaker: NA
Text: race. 1 raised this question this morning

Speaker: NA
Text: during another debate, but during the day

Speaker: NA
Text: I received a new bulletin from the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bureau of Census and Statistics.

Speaker: NA
Text: It showed the Aboriginal population of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Figures at page 29 of that docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment show that 39.23% of the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: population have no education at all. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course that includes 16% under school age;

Speaker: NA
Text: so 23% of the adult Aboriginal population

Speaker: NA
Text: have no education whatsoever. But in the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-Aboriginal community only about 1%

Speaker: NA
Text: have no education. Any Australian govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment conscious of its duty would be tackling

Speaker: NA
Text: these problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: What do we intend to do about the

Speaker: NA
Text: environment in which education is carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out? I suggest that honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: should visit the schools in Canberra. These

Speaker: NA
Text: schools may have their deficiencies. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard Canberra citizens complain about

Speaker: NA
Text: them, but compared with schools in the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia or in most areas of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: they are, although not exactly luxurious,

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially in advance of other schools.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Education and Science

Speaker: NA
Text: represents the western part of Victoria. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand from his friends that he owns

Speaker: NA
Text: most of it. I suggest that he should drive

Speaker: NA
Text: a little further north out of his electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: and visit the city of Horsham, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: the centre of one of the wealthiest pastoral

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in Australia. I visited the high school

Speaker: NA
Text: there last week. I did not know that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was any such school building in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I represent an area in which there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: great amount of neglect of school buildings,

Speaker: NA
Text: but thc Horsham High School building is a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace to Australia's education system.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a disgrace to those people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: represented that area in this place and in

Speaker: NA
Text: the State Parliament. The walls of the

Speaker: NA
Text: building are cracking and the roofs are fall-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in. One area of the walls is buttressed

Speaker: NA
Text: up and part of it is capable of inflicting

Speaker: NA
Text: both serious injury on people should it col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lapse and hardship by inflictions on health.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that tbe Minister for Education

Speaker: NA
Text: and Science should take a drive up there and

Speaker: NA
Text: have a look at the buildings instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: worrying about some of the wealthy schools

Speaker: NA
Text: which his children and the children of his

Speaker: NA
Text: friends attend. He might even come along

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Moreland High School in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate which has some substantial new build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings but where there is no room for any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the children to spread their wings.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I would remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Wills that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill deals with scholarships.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Tha t is right.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! It does not cover

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole field of education. I remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member that I cannot see the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevance between the state of schools and

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of scholarships. I suggest the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member might get back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Wit h due respect, I point

Speaker: NA
Text: out that clause 3 repeals the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Act of 1945. That Act sets out a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of functions for the Ministry and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: suggesting that those functions ought to have

Speaker: NA
Text: been retained. I am producing, I hope,

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that it needs Commonwealth atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. However, I intend to conclude my

Speaker: NA
Text: speech in a moment because I want my col-

Speaker: NA
Text: league the honourable member for Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Donald Cameron) to have his say, not

Speaker: NA
Text: that he will often vote against the gag when

Speaker: NA
Text: it is applied against me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fundamental requirements of education

Speaker: NA
Text: exist in the field of teaching. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Education and Science should consider

Speaker: NA
Text: making available scholarships to women in

Speaker: NA
Text: their 30s, 40s and even in their 50s. A great

Speaker: NA
Text: reservoir of skills, intellectual and otherwise,

Speaker: NA
Text: would be available in the community if

Speaker: NA
Text: there were a special system for training such

Speaker: NA
Text: people. If Australia needed 20,000 or 30,000

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary teachers within the next few

Speaker: NA
Text: year, with dramatic and dynamic planning

Speaker: NA
Text: and by offering something to women whose

Speaker: NA
Text: family responsibilities were nearing comple-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion it could obtain these teachers and have

Speaker: NA
Text: them qualified within 4 or 5 years. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: noted amongst my own circle of friends

Speaker: NA
Text: and in my own family the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: many women are taking up university

Speaker: NA
Text: education quite late in life. Women in their

Speaker: NA
Text: 40s still have a quarter of a century of profit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able professional endeavour before them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present approach is quite unimaginative.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scholarship system that is inflicted upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community is a perpetuation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the continual competitive system of elitist

Speaker: NA
Text: education. Labor's philosophy is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: totality as compared to the competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: system wbich the Liberal Party and its

Speaker: NA
Text: lite inflict on society generally. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Education and Science will

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly bring some omnibus legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House to tell honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members what the Government's proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: are to systematise Australian education.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Text: Griffith) and

Speaker: NA
Text: [10.28]- I fully realise that, time is moving

Speaker: NA
Text: on and the Minister. for' Education and

Speaker: NA
Text: Science ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) is preparing

Speaker: NA
Text: to close the debate. I refer briefly to.

Speaker: NA
Text: the charge . of . political gimmickry know

Speaker: NA
Text: laid by the honourable member. for Wills

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Bryant) against the Minister and his

Speaker: NA
Text: claim that every .time the Minister speaks

Speaker: NA
Text: what he says has something to do with gim-.

Speaker: NA
Text: micks. It is very easy for the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wills to overlook the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister has stated-thi s is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: of gimmickry-tha t in 1964-65 the expendiwork

Speaker: NA
Text: ture qn Commonwealth scholarships was

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 12.7m; in 1969 it was $28.9m; and that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is anticipated that in 1971-72 it will

Speaker: NA
Text: $35m. Since. 1964-65 the expenditure has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased almost, threetimes, and yet

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Wills ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: shrugs it off. I refer also to remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the honourable, member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dawson (Dr Patterson), particularly his

Speaker: NA
Text: claim about the shortage of veterinary,

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists. Perhaps the lack of incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: not just at the scholarship stage. It may

Speaker: NA
Text: be the end result when these men are out

Speaker: NA
Text: in the field. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawson, who himself is so close to the soil,

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that many prospective veterinary raised

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists opt out of this field and choose

Speaker: NA
Text: medicine instead, perhaps because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: attractiveness and glory of the medical proin

Speaker: NA
Text: fession. I agree with him when he says that

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation has arisen in the country areas . which I have been concerned. The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: where more than ever before technical

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge is required.

Speaker: NA
Text: I liave risen to speak mainly on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ject of mature age scholarships. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see the Minister for Education

Speaker: NA
Text: and Science present tonight. He is aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have written various letters to

Speaker: NA
Text: on this subject. I am quite sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister himself is quite concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: this problem. However, for the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: the record I want to state that at present

Speaker: NA
Text: we have 250 mature age scholarships. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate in recent weeks I have had

Speaker: NA
Text: no fewer than eight people over 25 years

Speaker: NA
Text: satelof age who have approached' me with the

Speaker: NA
Text: that problem of whether or not they would

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a mature age scholarship. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: these people are in their late 20s or early

Speaker: NA
Text: 30s. They left school at an early age and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in this society of ours which offers oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity for self education, they, have reached

Speaker: NA
Text: the stage where they haye entered university

Speaker: NA
Text: have passed their first year. I sincerely

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that serious consideration will be

Speaker: NA
Text: given either to increasing the lower age

Speaker: NA
Text: limit to 30 or 35 or increasing'the number-

Speaker: NA
Text: of mature age scholarships available. I

Speaker: NA
Text: that a sad situation exists now. in that

Speaker: NA
Text: many second year students have no hope

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever ' of ' obtaining a scholarship.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of them have acquired up to three

Speaker: NA
Text: distinctions and credits in their first year's

Speaker: NA
Text: studies. Many who have perhaps done early,

Speaker: NA
Text: years at the university on a pari time basis

Speaker: NA
Text: matter and have had to face married life and

Speaker: NA
Text: during the day have had early failures

Speaker: NA
Text: takeninto consideration. I cannot allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to pass without saying some-

Speaker: NA
Text: be thing on their behalf. I hope that a freer-

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude will be taken in - relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. I see that the Leader of the House-

Speaker: NA
Text: Erwin) is hot on my trail to ...s/se

Speaker: NA
Text: me to cease, so on that note I 'conclude.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MALCOLM FRASER'. (Wannon-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Education and. Science) [10.32]

Speaker: NA
Text: is -i n reply- I would like to thank honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members for the remarks that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: made during this debate. I am glad to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Opposition in broad terms supports

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill but a number of matters have been

Speaker: NA
Text: that do, in part at least, require some

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of answer. I would like to apologise to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House for riot having been able to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber throughout the' debate, but-

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet has been meeting'on matters with

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition ( Mr Whitlam), I am

Speaker: NA
Text: advised, made a number of points, not all

Speaker: NA
Text: strictly related to this Bill. He made some

Speaker: NA
Text: subpoints which I think need greater examina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion than he has perhaps given them. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, he said that he would abolish all

Speaker: NA
Text: university fees and that this would cost

Speaker: NA
Text: him Slim. All right, that is Slim, but where

Speaker: NA
Text: are one's priorities in terms of education?

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just one amount.of Slim. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: of Slim or an increasing amount for every

Speaker: NA
Text: year thereafter. If one sets this beside the

Speaker: NA
Text: other things that could be done in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of education with Slim, I suggest that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely doubtful whether one would give

Speaker: NA
Text: the abolition of university fees complete and

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute priority.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should also like to raise another ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in relation to the abolition of university

Speaker: NA
Text: fees which I tbink I mentioned once before

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House and which representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: unions in this place might do very well to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider. I tbink it is very widely recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: that whatever advances might be made in

Speaker: NA
Text: education in the future the majority of our

Speaker: NA
Text: population will not be going to universities.

Speaker: NA
Text: An increasing number and an increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage will go to universities and an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing number and an increasing per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage will go to colleges of advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: education. But no country, I think, has

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved a .situation in which a majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of its people of university age do in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: go to a university. What is the justice of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing the unionist and the average worker

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the country, to provide a free

Speaker: NA
Text: education for a doctor, a lawyer or a

Speaker: NA
Text: solicitor, who will be going out into the

Speaker: NA
Text: world with professional qualifications enab-

Speaker: NA
Text: ling him to charge fees at an extraordinarily

Speaker: NA
Text: high level-i n a large part a charge on the

Speaker: NA
Text: unionists who are said to be the supporters

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Opposition? I believe that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a matter which members sitting behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition might do well

Speaker: NA
Text: to consider, and to see where the true

Speaker: NA
Text: balance of justice, need and equity lies in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to this matter. Tt is by no means

Speaker: NA
Text: as simple as the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: suggests.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has also said, as I think other speakers

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, that more scholarships are

Speaker: NA
Text: needed. Of course, it is always easy to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that more are needed. This is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that the Opposition always can do

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is the Opposition's privilege to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to do it. But in saying that, one should

Speaker: NA
Text: not ignore the fact that repeatedly through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out its period in office the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased tbe number of scholarships. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Government that first introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: thc Commonwealth scholarship schemes. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was the Government, when the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Gorton) was Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in Charge of Commonwealth Activities in

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Research, which did most to

Speaker: NA
Text: broaden our concern for education and

Speaker: NA
Text: which first did most, to be specific, in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to scholarships, to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of scholarships and their numbers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Advanced education scholarships were

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in 1966. Secondary scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships and technical scholarships were

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in 1965. Over the years

Speaker: NA
Text: the number holding scholarships has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased from a litde under 6,500 to

Speaker: NA
Text: an estimated 56,500 in 1969, and the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of new scholarships that were available

Speaker: NA
Text: to be awarded in any one year has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased from 3,000 to 24,150. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has given a great deal of atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to these matters. Growing from

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing, the annua] bill for scholarships will

Speaker: NA
Text: in a relatively short time rise to $35m, so

Speaker: NA
Text: it cannot be said that the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: not given a great deal of attention to these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters-muc h more attention, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: than the Opposition might have believed

Speaker: NA
Text: we have in fact given. But still the criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: comes, as one would expect.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that these figures and this per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance show how unreasonable is the

Speaker: NA
Text: claim of the Leader of the Opposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: we use scholarships to restrict education

Speaker: NA
Text: to an elite. This certainly cannot be said

Speaker: NA
Text: when we look at the numbers of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are now finding places in universities. There

Speaker: NA
Text: were 100,000 last year, when the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, with five or six times our popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation, had an objective, according to one

Speaker: NA
Text: article I read, of about 225,000 university

Speaker: NA
Text: students in 1972-73. The United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: swelled its numbers of university students

Speaker: NA
Text: by signing over, at one stroke, a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of technological institutions. By signing a

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of paper it called these institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: universities. That is one of the ways in

Speaker: NA
Text: which it achieved a figure much less than

Speaker: NA
Text: ours. It is a case of Australia having per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed very much better than the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom in this regard. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition also said, I am advised, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships do not basically provide assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to those who are in need. Not only

Speaker: NA
Text: do they provide for those who are in need

Speaker: NA
Text: but also that need must be judged on

Speaker: NA
Text: ability. There is no point in providing

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships to those who have not a reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able chance and a reasonable opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: of passing through university without too

Speaker: NA
Text: great a difficulty. This is one of the bases

Speaker: NA
Text: on which the scholarships are in fact made

Speaker: NA
Text: available. The living allowance is provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for those who win scholarships and who

Speaker: NA
Text: are in fact most in need. So the scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: system does a great deal to assist people who

Speaker: NA
Text: would otherwise not find places in univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities. The days are very far gone when

Speaker: NA
Text: one's parents own finances could find one

Speaker: NA
Text: a place at a university irrespective of one's

Speaker: NA
Text: own ability and irrespective of other con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations. The able student can get to a

Speaker: NA
Text: university and, I believe, does.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should be worth noting that either

Speaker: NA
Text: the Martin Report on the Future of Ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiary Education in Australia or one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Universities Commission reports

Speaker: NA
Text: at a time when Sir Leslie Martin was Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, indicated that one of the bases of

Speaker: NA
Text: judging university entrants should be that

Speaker: NA
Text: students be able to pass through university

Speaker: NA
Text: in minimum time or in minimum time plus

Speaker: NA
Text: one year. In fact not all of those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: awarded Commonwealth scholarships

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve this performance and there are

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers in universities who after some

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty pass but do so with a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: time lag than one year. We know, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: that about one-third of those who do enter

Speaker: NA
Text: universities fail to leave with any degree

Speaker: NA
Text: This merely makes the point tbat we are

Speaker: NA
Text: not restircting entry to universities only to

Speaker: NA
Text: those who can qualify in a minimum time

Speaker: NA
Text: or only to those who can qualify at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are sufficient places to enable a great

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people to go to a university,

Speaker: NA
Text: even though their chances of passing at the

Speaker: NA
Text: bottom level of entrance to universities are

Speaker: NA
Text: not particularly high.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition again

Speaker: NA
Text: returned to the old criticism that we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt the Martin Report recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: on teacher training. Once again he ignored

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that a great many of those recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations were the particular prerogative

Speaker: NA
Text: of the States and it was for the States, hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing regard to their own administration and

Speaker: NA
Text: to their own systems, which had the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of giving effect to those

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations. One of those was that

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher training should be extended to 3

Speaker: NA
Text: years. This is something on which every

Speaker: NA
Text: State has now acted, but it was the States

Speaker: NA
Text: which had to make a decision, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: have done so. The same report suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth should spend

Speaker: NA
Text: $2.5m on capital facilities for teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: ing matched by a similar sum from the

Speaker: NA
Text: States. Tn fact, we have spent $24m on

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher training, or are in the process of

Speaker: NA
Text: spending it. and these are unmatched funds

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide an additional 5,000 teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: trainee places.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Canberra College of Advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: Education is also actively planning to intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce courses in teacher training. So it can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not by any means be said that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been ignoring this important matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher training. I thought in view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: criticisms that have been made concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of teachers that the House may

Speaker: NA
Text: be interested in the improved pupil-teacher

Speaker: NA
Text: ratios which have occurred over recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times in spite of the fact that there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been an explosive growth in the demand

Speaker: NA
Text: for education caused not so much by a

Speaker: NA
Text: higher number in a particular age group

Speaker: NA
Text: or by immigration as by a much higher

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of those in the upper years of

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary schooling in the 15 to 18 year

Speaker: NA
Text: old age group seeking to stay at school

Speaker: NA
Text: longer than was once the case. This per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage over the past 10 years bas risen

Speaker: NA
Text: from about 20% or 22% of the 15 to 18

Speaker: NA
Text: year olds to about 40% last year. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that this pressure on the top end

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e expensive end-o f secondary school-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing will continue and that the percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of the age group seeking to end

Speaker: NA
Text: their secondary school will continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite this pressure on the top end of

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary schooling the pupil-teacher ratios

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly have improved even if the improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has not been as rapid as some would

Speaker: NA
Text: like. For example, in primary schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia the overall ratios have gone from

Speaker: NA
Text: 30.2 to I in 1962 to 28.2 to I in 1967.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tn Victoria-an d as a Victorian I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see that that State leads the

Speaker: NA
Text: field-the ratios have gone from 24.8 to

Speaker: NA
Text: I to 23.7 to 1. If one looks at secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools throughout Australia the ratios bave

Speaker: NA
Text: gone from 20.9 to I to 18.7 to 1, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales even with the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Wyndham scheme and the extra pres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sure which that put on their secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: school system the ratio has improved from

Speaker: NA
Text: 21 to 1 in 1962 to 18.6 to 1 in 1967. So

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been an improvement in pupil-

Speaker: NA
Text: teacher ratios and the combined pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grammes of the Commonwealth and the

Speaker: NA
Text: States and the assistance that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: train- provided are helping to make this

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement possible. Having said that, I

Speaker: NA
Text: know it will always be possible to point to

Speaker: NA
Text: a particular school or to a particular dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipline and to indicate that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: shortages in one area or another, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: overall position is better than it once was.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think tbe Leader of the Opposition ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Whitlam) also mentioned the percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: gross national product that we spend on

Speaker: NA
Text: education and compared it with the expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture of other countries. I would only

Speaker: NA
Text: like to say that my Department has done

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal of work on these comparisons

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last 6 months and very shortly I

Speaker: NA
Text: will be making available to all honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members a very detailed paper which will

Speaker: NA
Text: analyse these figures and the considerations

Speaker: NA
Text: that need to be borne in mind when using

Speaker: NA
Text: them as comparisons. They will show that

Speaker: NA
Text: the comparisons are utterly meaningless

Speaker: NA
Text: when comparing the educational effort and

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality of education between one

Speaker: NA
Text: country and another. 1 hope that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be more than another week or two

Speaker: NA
Text: before this document will be available to

Speaker: NA
Text: all honourable members who would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: see it. The Deputy Leader of the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ( Mr Barnard) asked one or two specific

Speaker: NA
Text: questions concerning various clauses in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and asked for the difference between

Speaker: NA
Text: the wording used in clauses 11 and 12 con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning secondary and technical scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships. The clauses state that, the regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: will prescribe the funds to be used for a

Speaker: NA
Text: living allowance. It is possible to use the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms that were used in those clauses 11

Speaker: NA
Text: and 12 because for the secondary and

Speaker: NA
Text: technical scholarships the living allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: is $200 and it is the same for everyone.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no means test on these particular

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships, and the amount will, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, appear in the regulations. If tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: amount were changed the regulations would

Speaker: NA
Text: be altered. But when one comes to the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth university and advanced educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion scholarships there is a means test. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people get the full living allowance and

Speaker: NA
Text: others whose parents have greater means

Speaker: NA
Text: than others will get none. Whilst the living

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance will be awarded in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the regulations they certainly will

Speaker: NA
Text: be the same for everyone, and it is this

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between the nature of the living

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance and the way in which it is

Speaker: NA
Text: puted and paid which causes the difference

Speaker: NA
Text: in the regulations. I hope that the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition will bc able

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that explanation. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Angas ( Mr Giles) raised a

Speaker: NA
Text: query about the power of delegation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. This is necessary, and by and large it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a power of delegation to officials

Speaker: NA
Text: in my Department because it is physically

Speaker: NA
Text: quite impossible for the Minister for Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Science annually to award 25,000

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships. Except for the particular cases

Speaker: NA
Text: where discretion might need to be used or

Speaker: NA
Text: where something is brought to the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's notice this is something that the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter must delegate to his Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Wills ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Bryant) told me before he spoke that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was going to put forward a plea for a

Speaker: NA
Text: generally broader Commonwealth approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to education and to activities in a wider

Speaker: NA
Text: number of fields. I think the record of the

Speaker: NA
Text: past, as all honourable members know-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the last 4 or 5 years in particular-wil l

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the Commonwealth is spread-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing its interest and concern in a much

Speaker: NA
Text: greater variety of fields than was formerly

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, and I have no doubt that our

Speaker: NA
Text: concern and increasing involvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: education will continue. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) asked

Speaker: NA
Text: why there are only four students undertak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing study under post-graduate awards in

Speaker: NA
Text: veterinary science-whic h J agree is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important-whe n there might, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: be 17 in music. I think he put the point

Speaker: NA
Text: forward that a post-graduate award in

Speaker: NA
Text: veterinary science is more important than

Speaker: NA
Text: a post-graduate award in music. As

Speaker: NA
Text: a farmer I would find it difficult to argue

Speaker: NA
Text: with him, but these awards may in part

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect the number of people who are study-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in a course at the undergraduate level,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so therefore those numbers could affect

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of applications in a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline for a post-graduate award.

Speaker: NA
Text: By and large the greater the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: applicants the greater number there will be

Speaker: NA
Text: of sufficient quality to achieve an award.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I think the honourable member's con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern may, to some extent, be alleviated if

Speaker: NA
Text: he keeps in mind that if one looks at agri-

Speaker: NA
Text: not culture, biochemistry, chemistry, botany

Speaker: NA
Text: and other disciplines of this kind where

Speaker: NA
Text: the numbers of post-graduate awards are

Speaker: NA
Text: comreally quite great, and when one has in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind also that many of these disciplines

Speaker: NA
Text: cover subjects that are related to veterinary

Speaker: NA
Text: to science, one sees that much of the post-

Speaker: NA
Text: graduate research work in veterinary

Speaker: NA
Text: science would be done under the name of

Speaker: NA
Text: another discipline. So I think that the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is not quite as grim as the bare figures

Speaker: NA
Text: on this table might indicate. I would only

Speaker: NA
Text: like to say to the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Griffith ( Mr Donald Cameron) that the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the mature age award holders is

Speaker: NA
Text: understood. Broadly, the Commonwealth in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past made a judgment that it is better

Speaker: NA
Text: to support those in universities who go

Speaker: NA
Text: through the normal educational stream.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is recognised that this creates diffiRobinvale

Speaker: NA
Text: culties. Whether anything can be done about

Speaker: NA
Text: it or not I do not know, but I give the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member an assurance that the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of mature age award holders is

Speaker: NA
Text: being very closely examined.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: . Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for third reading to be

Speaker: NA
Text: moved forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (on motion by Mr Maicoim Fraser)

Speaker: NA
Text: read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Dried Fruits Industry-Civi l Aviation-

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services-Studen t Demonstrations-

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Erwin) proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Mallee) [10.50]-Wha t tion

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say tonight may be described as

Speaker: NA
Text: report. It is a report of my journey durthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Easter recess through the Murray

Speaker: NA
Text: Valley from Kerang to Mildura

Speaker: NA
Text: to see atfirsthand the damage inflicted on

Speaker: NA
Text: the dried fruits industry by recent heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: rains. In making the report I want to give

Speaker: NA
Text: certain statistics. I will read the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the Easter recess of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment I travelled through the Murray Valley

Speaker: NA
Text: from Kerang to west of Mildura so that I

Speaker: NA
Text: might see the damage caused by the tor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rential rain of a few weeks ago. Greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: loss was experienced by growers of dried

Speaker: NA
Text: vine fruits, their losses being estimated at

Speaker: NA
Text: from 45% to 50% of the entire crop. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the storm struck most of the fruit had been

Speaker: NA
Text: picked and was on the racks, where I saw

Speaker: NA
Text: it rotting from the effects of rain. To

Speaker: NA
Text: harvest the fruit that remained on the vine

Speaker: NA
Text: up to double rates had to be paid to pickers,

Speaker: NA
Text: the remaining crop being too light for them

Speaker: NA
Text: to make reasonable wages at normal rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: In many cases this situation increased sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially the costs of the producer.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not difficult to imagine the feelings

Speaker: NA
Text: of growers who, after their year's work,

Speaker: NA
Text: suddenly lost much of the crop on which

Speaker: NA
Text: they depended so heavily. I spoke at meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings of growers at Mildura and Woorinen

Speaker: NA
Text: and discussed the problem with others at

Speaker: NA
Text: and Nyah. I also drove, through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tresco settlement. I found that financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance was urgently needed and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of Victoria, through its rural

Speaker: NA
Text: finance office, was inviting growers to state

Speaker: NA
Text: their case to government officers who would

Speaker: NA
Text: operate from central positions to be adver-

Speaker: NA
Text: tised. It is considered that this is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: practical method of assessing the individual

Speaker: NA
Text: and collective loss.

Speaker: NA
Text: It appears that growers can be regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as being in three categories- a small per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage who will not requirefinancialassist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance; a large percentage who require a long

Speaker: NA
Text: term low interest loan if they are to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactorily in production; and a percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: still to be ascertained who urgently require a

Speaker: NA
Text: liberal grant if they are to survive as primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers. The Australian vine fruits indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try is important to those engaged in it and

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam to the economy of the nation. The average

Speaker: NA
Text: gross value of dried vine fruit production

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia for each of the 4 years up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1966-67 was $30,678,775. Of this produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: about two-thirds, valued at $20,452,516,

Speaker: NA
Text: a was produced in the Mallee electorate. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 years to which I have referred the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of fruit exported amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: in order $22,121,500 per annum.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: I thought the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member did not read his speeches.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Thi s is a report. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the value of the industry to Australia may

Speaker: NA
Text: be readily recognised. Dried vine fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: growers were not the only ones to suffer

Speaker: NA
Text: from the disaster. Growers of citrus, wine

Speaker: NA
Text: grapes and fresh grapes, producers of seed

Speaker: NA
Text: and other primary producers in the Murray

Speaker: NA
Text: Valley must be given the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: state their .case. The Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been alerted to the fact that when

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate figures of the amount of the loss

Speaker: NA
Text: are established it will be expected to give

Speaker: NA
Text: financial aid in conjunction with Victoria so

Speaker: NA
Text: as to ameliorate to some extent at least the

Speaker: NA
Text: desperate financial position of these primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers.

Speaker: Mr COPE
Text: Wil l this situation make any

Speaker: NA
Text: difference to the provision of raisins in the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary members' dining room?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I hope not because 1 do

Speaker: NA
Text: am aware that honourable members appreretained

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate the dried, fruits that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: available. Honourable members are walking

Speaker: NA
Text: and talking advertisements for tbis great

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. They know that dried fruits

Speaker: NA
Text: good for them. They notice the difference

Speaker: NA
Text: in their health after they have had one

Speaker: NA
Text: two meals of dried fruits.

Speaker: NA
Text: On quite a different subject 1 propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: quote from a report published in the member

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Sunraysia Daily' on 10th April. The report

Speaker: NA
Text: reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: Ansett Airline's of Australia ' will

Speaker: NA
Text: DC-3's for - its off-peak air services between

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne-Mildura-Broken Hill at least until

Speaker: NA
Text: August.

Speaker: NA
Text: The more popular Fokker Friendships will be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen on the Melbourne-Mildflra run only on the

Speaker: NA
Text: services ' which' have departures from Melbourne'

Speaker: NA
Text: each, evening except Saturdays, and from Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne each morning except Sunday and Monday.

Speaker: NA
Text: DC-3's will be used on the Monday morning

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne to Mildura and return service; and on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Wednesday and Friday Melbounic-Mildura-

Speaker: NA
Text: Broken Hill and return services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have now been informed that the Fokker

Speaker: NA
Text: Friendship, which is more popular than the

Speaker: NA
Text: DC3, will be withdrawn from the Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne to Mildura to Broken Hill run on

Speaker: NA
Text: 28th April. The distance from Melbourne to

Speaker: NA
Text: Mildura is 300 air miles and from Mildura

Speaker: NA
Text: to Broken Hill about 200 miles. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the areas affected do not want

Speaker: NA
Text: the Friendship to be withdrawn. I appeal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the. Minister for Civil Aviation ( Mr Swartz)

Speaker: NA
Text: to look into the matter and to use his

Speaker: NA
Text: influence to see that the Friendship is

Speaker: NA
Text: retained on this important run. Everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that Mildura is one of the great pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vincial cities of Australia. Broken Hill,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is not in the electorate of Mallee, is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very importaut city. On the run from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne to Mildura to Broken Hill and

Speaker: NA
Text: return we should have nothing less than

Speaker: NA
Text: Fokker Friendships. Honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: who in recent times have travelled from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, Sydney or other places to Canadjournment

Speaker: NA
Text: berra in Fokker Friendships have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied with the aircraft. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted better aircraft. We now have better

Speaker: NA
Text: aircraft on these runs. I have heard a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of complaints from members of Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: about the lack of room in a Friendship. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the run from Melbourne through Mildura

Speaker: NA
Text: to Broken Hill we should have aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: better than the DC3. This is no longer a

Speaker: NA
Text: popular aircraft. Surely it is not asking too

Speaker: NA
Text: much of the Minister for Civil .Aviation lo

Speaker: NA
Text: his utmost to see that the Friendship is

Speaker: NA
Text: on this run. This is surely a very

Speaker: NA
Text: made good paying service and the Friendship

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be withdrawn at. this stage. Air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft may be getting scarce in Australia but

Speaker: NA
Text: are why should the two great decentralised

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of Mildura and Broken Hill be

Speaker: NA
Text: or deprived of a service which, they should

Speaker: NA
Text: have and a service

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: for Reid will cease interjecting. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has just interjected for the third time in

Speaker: NA
Text: about 3 minutes. If he continues to interject

Speaker: NA
Text: revert to T will have tb deal with him.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: W e .know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Reid ( Mr Uren).

Speaker: NA
Text: comes from the city. He enjoys the very

Speaker: NA
Text: best of air services between Sydney and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. What does the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber care for the people who Jive in Mildura

Speaker: NA
Text: and Broken Hill? He believes in centralisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Whenever'we speak in this place -

Speaker: NA
Text: about decentralisation and the improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: of conditions in country areas so that people

Speaker: NA
Text: already living there will hot move to the

Speaker: NA
Text: cities and so that people may be attracted

Speaker: NA
Text: from the; cities to the country honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members in the ranks of .the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: deride our suggestions. Air. services play an

Speaker: NA
Text: important role in taking people from the.

Speaker: NA
Text: cities to the country and from the country

Speaker: NA
Text: to the cities. An adequate air service can

Speaker: NA
Text: make people who live in decentralised areas

Speaker: NA
Text: such as Broken Hill and :Mi)dura feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not completely isolated. I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Civil Aviation to look into this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter and to do what he. can to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: people living in the areas tb which T have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred.. T assure the Minister and all other

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members that anything done to

Speaker: NA
Text: retain the Friendships will be greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated. ', .

Speaker: Mr LUCOCK
Text: Lyne) [U.0]- 1 want to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise a matter in the House during this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate which concerns one of

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents. It relates to a matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: comes within the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Health and the Department-

Speaker: NA
Text: of Social Services. This constituent is an

Speaker: NA
Text: age pensioner. He and his wife are in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceipt of a pension. They felt that they would

Speaker: NA
Text: join a hospital benefits fund so that in rhe

Speaker: NA
Text: event of illness they could receive better

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment in hospital. In the event of sick-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness they would then be able to go into an

Speaker: NA
Text: intermediate ward. But something which

Speaker: NA
Text: they did not realise was that the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: they joined this hospital benefit fund and

Speaker: NA
Text: received the benefit of treatment in an

Speaker: NA
Text: intermediate ward tbis meant that they

Speaker: NA
Text: penalised themselves in the sense that they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not receive medical expenses on the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner medical card. I know that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are complexities in this matter and that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not an easy problem to solve because of

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances relating to the pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: medical card and medical entitlement. But

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that this is a matter which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health (Dr Forbes) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Services ( Mr Wentworth)

Speaker: NA
Text: in consultation with the State Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: could perhaps discuss and reach a solution

Speaker: NA
Text: which would enable the person concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: in these particular circumstances to receive

Speaker: NA
Text: a benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: The circumstances in this matter are that

Speaker: NA
Text: these people are prepared to help them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves, but because they are prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: do this and to make a contribution out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the money which they receive by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension towards paying for the cost of hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pital treatment, they are penalised in this

Speaker: NA
Text: way. I do not intend to comment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: charge that was made by the doctor. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that doctors do this, and it may be possible

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this particular circumstance the

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor literally made a donation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people concerned. But the position in this

Speaker: NA
Text: case is that these people were prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: help themselves, but because of that they

Speaker: NA
Text: were placed in a position in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: actually penalised themselves. As I said, I

Speaker: NA
Text: realise that there are complexities in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. At this stage when we are consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the question of health insurance, I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Ministers concerned will look into

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter and see what assistance can be

Speaker: NA
Text: given, not only in the particular case to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred, but also in many

Speaker: NA
Text: other cases of which I am aware. I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gratulate the Minister for Social Services,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Health and the two Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments on the great progress that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made towards providing assistance to these

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I am sure that if the Ministers get

Speaker: NA
Text: together they will be able to find a solution

Speaker: NA
Text: to the problem which will be beneficial to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people concerned.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Grayndler) [11.3]-- I wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to address a few remarks to the two mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters which have been raised by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mallee ( Mr Turnbull) and

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honourable member for Lyne ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lucock) and to one or two other matters

Speaker: NA
Text: which are important to the nation. Firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Mallee con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistently criticises honourable members on

Speaker: NA
Text: both sides of this Parliament for reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches, but tonight I was interested to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear him read an epistle word for word.

Speaker: NA
Text: He repeated it like a parrot in a way for

Speaker: NA
Text: which he is contantly criticising other mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of this Parliament. I congratulate him

Speaker: NA
Text: at least for learning that his read speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: are much better than those which he does

Speaker: NA
Text: not read. I only have this to say about what

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member had to say tonight:

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought it was an improvement on his

Speaker: NA
Text: usual speech. I congratulate him for seeing

Speaker: NA
Text: the light and realising that we appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: it more when he reads something which

Speaker: NA
Text: he obviously knows and understands than

Speaker: NA
Text: we do when he makes a speech off the cuff

Speaker: NA
Text: without, any knowledge or understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the subject with which he is dealing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should also like to point out that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable niember for Mallee never fails

Speaker: NA
Text: to attack the city dwellers of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: when he speaks. When all is said and done,

Speaker: NA
Text: five sixths of the Australian population live

Speaker: NA
Text: in the cities of this nation. What do mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Liberal Party think about a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Australian Country Party,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of their colleagues, who consistently

Speaker: NA
Text: attacks people in the cities because they

Speaker: NA
Text: have some of the amenities of life for

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have fought under this Liberal-

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party Government? Nothing is

Speaker: NA
Text: given to them. At the same time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable niember for Mallee gives us to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that it is only the people living

Speaker: NA
Text: in country districts who make the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: go. Where would he be as a Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: member if city dwellers did not wear suits

Speaker: NA
Text: which were produced from the wool and

Speaker: NA
Text: other products of primary producers?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Dohie-D o you wear synthetic suits?

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: No . Members of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party do not wear synthetic suits. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: left to members of the Country Party. I

Speaker: NA
Text: mention this to the honourable members in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to show that when he criticises city

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellers, let it be understood that we eat

Speaker: NA
Text: the bread and wear the suits wbich are

Speaker: NA
Text: produced from the products of primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers. Ii: every way it is the city

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellers, who are attacked by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Mallee, who provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth of tbe country, because they are

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers representatives. I do not speak

Speaker: NA
Text: tonight as a producer's representative. But

Speaker: NA
Text: let the honourable member for Mallee know

Speaker: NA
Text: that if city dwellers placed a boycott on

Speaker: NA
Text: the products which come from his area

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be a lot of very poor people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Mallee electorate. Therefore, when

Speaker: NA
Text: he makes these bitter and well read attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: on people from city electorates, let him

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that these people make his coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try district prosperous. Let him remember

Speaker: NA
Text: that these people resent these attacks. To-

Speaker: NA
Text: night when 1 refer to the well read and

Speaker: NA
Text: bitter attacks I am speaking on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the city dwellers who are represented by

Speaker: NA
Text: myself and other members opposite. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that members of tbe Country Party will dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: own the honourable member for Mallee for

Speaker: NA
Text: the unwarranted attack which he has made

Speaker: NA
Text: on these people who mean so much to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know tbat tbe honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mallee wears nylon socks. If he is not

Speaker: NA
Text: wearing them, let him prove it. Only

Speaker: NA
Text: recently we heard that wives of graziers

Speaker: NA
Text: favour synthetic materials in preference to

Speaker: NA
Text: woollen materials. I exempt other members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Country Party, but I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to examine very closely all the clothes

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honourable member for Mallee

Speaker: NA
Text: is wearing before 1 accept the fact that he

Speaker: NA
Text: is not wearing any synthetic clothing tonight.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a matter of fact, when he smiles T think

Speaker: NA
Text: his smile is synthetic, too. Although there

Speaker: NA
Text: are Shakespeare and other great writers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the past to whom one can refer when

Speaker: NA
Text: making a speech, when the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mallee speaks the only authority

Speaker: NA
Text: on which he relies for verification is the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Sunraysia Daily'. What a magnificent

Speaker: NA
Text: document to refer to. What a great organ

Speaker: NA
Text: of public opinion. I suppose it has a cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: culation of about 55 or 60 in the area in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honourable member resides.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mention these matters because for a

Speaker: NA
Text: long time in this Parliament I have resented

Speaker: NA
Text: the bitter attacks which have been made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Mallee upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the people whom I represent-th e great city

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellers who provide wealth for the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary producers. I also resent the attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: which he consistently makes on the methods

Speaker: NA
Text: which honourable members use in produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing facts and figures from a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: documented notes. Tonight 1 place on

Speaker: NA
Text: record the fact that the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber has seen the light. He has read his

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. His speeches are not much to listen

Speaker: NA
Text: to at any time, but they are much better

Speaker: NA
Text: when he reads them. Let him continue to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so. Tonight I thought that I should rise in

Speaker: NA
Text: my place and say a few words of rebuke

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honourable member whom I like as

Speaker: NA
Text: a man, but at the same time I appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: that on a lot of matters, he is a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: off the beam. I should like to see a revival

Speaker: NA
Text: of those militant days when he stood and

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised the Government for its inactivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today when I see him pandering at the

Speaker: NA
Text: feet of those who maladminister this

Speaker: NA
Text: country I think it is sad to see a retired

Speaker: NA
Text: rebel who is only consoled.by the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is another one who sits in Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: and that they have a community of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: as they think what they were, what they

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been and what they are today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Lyne raised

Speaker: NA
Text: a very important question concerning social

Speaker: NA
Text: services. I think that he has highlighted in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament one of the factors associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with this Government's administration. The

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies in the social services system are

Speaker: NA
Text: so great that many people are being most

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately and unfairly treated. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see a member of the Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party rise tonight and bring to light in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament a matter which Labor members

Speaker: NA
Text: have been raising for some time. J refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the injustices which are so inherent in the

Speaker: NA
Text: social services system, and which the

Speaker: NA
