Text: Minister for Social Services ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth) promised to do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about. The case which the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lyne raised'tonight could be

Speaker: NA
Text: multiplied one thousand times over. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government does nothing about it. Even

Speaker: NA
Text: today, in the face of the Nimmo

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's report, the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: defending a health scheme which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: laughing stock of nations which believe in

Speaker: NA
Text: social justice, particularly so far as

Speaker: NA
Text: health is concerned. Credit is due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Lyne, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker of this Parliament, for raising this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which 1 believe should be aired and

Speaker: NA
Text: given the light of day. I hope the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Health (Dr Forbes) and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Social Services will take notice of this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members on this side of the House con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinually bring forward numerous anomalies

Speaker: NA
Text: -hundred s of them-involvin g invalid

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners and others. There are amazing

Speaker: NA
Text: cases where people are living on discrimin-

Speaker: NA
Text: atory rates of pension simply because they

Speaker: NA
Text: happen to be married. Discrimination

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs right through the whole structure of

Speaker: NA
Text: social services. It is a disgrace that in this

Speaker: NA
Text: enlightened society events should occur

Speaker: NA
Text: such as those mentioned by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lyne tonight. Discrimination

Speaker: NA
Text: also exists between married and single pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners, those on permissible incomes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: poor, the very poor and the aged or the

Speaker: NA
Text: frail aged. These discriminations arc a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: grace to this Government and to Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is one of the wealthiest countries in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lyne for having thc courage to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: against thi.s Government. After all, it takes

Speaker: NA
Text: a bit of courage to do this. Ask the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Warringah ( Mr St. John)

Speaker: NA
Text: who is no longer with us-a t least

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as the Liberals are concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is because of the revolution that

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred when he exercised his right as a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Liberal Party to express his

Speaker: NA
Text: independent point of view. H is interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: to note what happened after tbe honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Warringah expressed a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view. After the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Warringah exercised his right as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal to speak in his independent way,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Parkes ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes) decided, as he did in the redistri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution, that he would move north again

Speaker: NA
Text: and that he would not sit with the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member. So he moved north in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. I wonder whether the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parkes realises thai a loi of

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members do not like sitting with

Speaker: NA
Text: him but that we cannot all get out.

Speaker: NA
Text: This brings me back to the point made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honourable member for Lyne. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that he raised his criticism of thc

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. I am delighted to see that he

Speaker: NA
Text: has exercised certain independence in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. I remind him. though, that Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Russell of his Party did not have exactly a

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleasant fate when he spoke accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly. So he joins the St. Johns and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Russells.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will refer to an honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber by the name of his electorate.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Yes , the honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Warringah. 1 would like to get back

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously lo the question of social services

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been raised tonight. I point out

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Health that these

Speaker: NA
Text: injustices are numerous and should be

Speaker: NA
Text: remedied. The Governnient has a responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility to do sc.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said so much. I express the hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that after Deceniber of this year, or a little

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier as the Liberals get frightened of

Speaker: NA
Text: impending by-elections, honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers from tbis side of the Parliament will

Speaker: NA
Text: have the opportunity to bring real social

Speaker: NA
Text: justice in health and social services to this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. A Labor Party administration

Speaker: NA
Text: realises what this country can give, what

Speaker: NA
Text: people are entitled to and what a good go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernmeni can give them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull- Mr Speaker, I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! Does the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable niember claim to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TurnlHiH-Yes , I do. You will recall

Speaker: NA
Text: that when I made my contribution tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: I said at the very start that 1 was quoting

Speaker: NA
Text: from a report 1 had written. 1 did not try

Speaker: NA
Text: to make out that I was speaking impromptu

Speaker: NA
Text: or anything like that. The honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Grayndler ( Mr Daly) never forgets

Speaker: NA
Text: that 1 thrashed him on many occasions.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The House will

Speaker: NA
Text: come to order.

Speaker: Mr JESS
Text: La Trobe) [11.14]- I havo

Speaker: NA
Text: been 9 years in this House and I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to pay a tribute to the late honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for East Sydney because since he

Speaker: NA
Text: left this House I do not think the adjourn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment debate has been worth anything,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, if a private member has a matte\

Speaker: NA
Text: ro bring up on the adjournment I think ht

Speaker: NA
Text: nesitates, wondering whether it is wor«>

Speaker: NA
Text: while doing so. There are few opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: left for private members to raise matters

Speaker: NA
Text: of importance, and 1 apologise to my con-

Speaker: NA
Text: freres and members of the Opposition for

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping them here at this time.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the last session we listened to

Speaker: NA
Text: many matters of urgency raised by Ihe

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. The subject matters have caused

Speaker: NA
Text: us to wonder why the Opposition could not

Speaker: NA
Text: think of matters of more importance to put

Speaker: NA
Text: before (he Parliament and Ihe people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The matter I wish to raise con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns a report which appeared in the Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne 'Age' of 12th April, it concerns the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent student demonstrations in Sydney. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to read certain extracts. 1 would

Speaker: NA
Text: like these extracts incorporated in Hansard

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do not think I would be given leave

Speaker: NA
Text: so I will not ask for it: The article is

Speaker: NA
Text: headed: 'Sydney students run riot, seize

Speaker: NA
Text: court'. These are very large headlines. The

Speaker: NA
Text: article is written by Robert Drewe and

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrew Clark. I can read only certain

Speaker: NA
Text: extracts from this article. It says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Students took over the Federal' Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's office and the Special Federal Court

Speaker: NA
Text: before police flushed them out.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 understand that would be a crime in most criminately

Speaker: NA
Text: societies. I am not sure tbat it is here. The

Speaker: NA
Text: article continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: The demonstration was organised

Speaker: NA
Text: the militant Students for a Democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: Society. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: In Adelaide, forty-five students were arrested.

Speaker: NA
Text: Students and police fell to the ground fighting as

Speaker: NA
Text: boots andfistsflew in the melee.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a fairly lurid report. It continues:

Speaker: NA
Text: SDS and Labor Club university leaders said

Speaker: NA
Text: last night that after yesterday's behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be no more peaceful demonstrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the ugliest Sydney incidents occurred

Speaker: NA
Text: when a police inspector reached behind Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Peter Mason (Professor of Physics and Mathematics

Speaker: NA
Text: at Macquarie University) and held him by the coat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then another policeman hit him

Speaker: NA
Text: It goes on further:

Speaker: NA
Text: In another incident, four policemen tried to'

Speaker: NA
Text: throw a male student head-first through an open

Speaker: NA
Text: paddy-wagon door. But his right shoulder hit

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the doorway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further on, it says:

Speaker: NA
Text: And two policemen dropped a student ihey

Speaker: NA
Text: been carrying face down into the paddy-wagon.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the majority of the arrests, police twisted

Speaker: NA
Text: arms, pulled hair and grabbed students by throat

Speaker: NA
Text: and neck before forcing them into the wagon.

Speaker: NA
Text: One begins to get confused as to who were forward

Speaker: NA
Text: the criminals, who were the police and who sary

Speaker: NA
Text: was on the side of law and order.

Speaker: NA
Text: report continues;

Speaker: NA
Text: The demonstration owed its violence mainly to

Speaker: NA
Text: over-enthusiastic opposition from 500 State police.

Speaker: NA
Text: They pushed, punched and kicked students,

Speaker: NA
Text: paper men, and unionists in separate fierce battles

Speaker: NA
Text: outside the Federal Court. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The point I am trying to make is that

Speaker: NA
Text: would think that in this country the

Speaker: NA
Text: are the criminals and that the students

Speaker: NA
Text: never commit any offences even if they

Speaker: NA
Text: break into the court or into the Attorneywill

Speaker: NA
Text: General's office. I know that it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: intended, but one of our major newspapers

Speaker: NA
Text: was purveying the line that in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: the police are the criminals. Two hundred

Speaker: NA
Text: broke away from tbe main march. Tben,

Speaker: NA
Text: says the report:

Speaker: NA
Text: Two motor cycle policemen and a divisional

Speaker: NA
Text: van tried to get past and stop their

Speaker: NA
Text: progress. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Six policemen vainly tried to stop the stampede

Speaker: NA
Text: by tripping, punching and kicking the

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrators.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can imagine six policemen in the path of

Speaker: NA
Text: 300 people moving down on them, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: would question to a certain extent the

Speaker: NA
Text: authenticity of this report, which goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: More students and trade unionists swelled the

Speaker: NA
Text: mob and nearly 2,000 occupied Phillip Street.

Speaker: NA
Text: A swathe of thirty fist swinging police indis-

Speaker: NA
Text: punched and kicked demonstrators.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was 30 police against 300. 1 question

Speaker: NA
Text: by the report as to 2,000. There is an old

Speaker: NA
Text: adage that if a brawl starts anybody who

Speaker: NA
Text: does not want to get involved in it should

Speaker: NA
Text: get out of it. The suggestion that a police-

Speaker: NA
Text: man confronted with such a situation has

Speaker: NA
Text: got to go up to a person and say: 'Pardon

Speaker: NA
Text: me, Sir, are you in this brawl, or are you

Speaker: NA
Text: not?' is ridiculous. I f he did this 1 think

Speaker: NA
Text: by police he would be king-hit by somebody from

Speaker: NA
Text: the side before he even knew what had

Speaker: NA
Text: happened. The question I ask. is: What is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in this country? We have this

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration in Sydney, we have a demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration on the same day in Adelaide, and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have the same thing happening through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out the capital cities of the world. Not only

Speaker: NA
Text: the do we have this, but we also have a leading

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Opposition who I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: all honourable members opposite will agree

Speaker: NA
Text: had is a potential prime minister reported in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 'Sydney Morning Herald' on the Mon-

Speaker: NA
Text: day following the incident as saying this:

Speaker: NA
Text: Doctor Cairns, who was a policeman for nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 years, said Sydney police . appeared to look

Speaker: NA
Text: to the prospects of 'bashing up' students.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said New South Wales police used unneces-

Speaker: NA
Text: and at times extreme violence in last Friday's

Speaker: NA
Text: The student demonstration.

Speaker: NA
Text: He went on:

Speaker: NA
Text: He said today that Brisbane "policemen had

Speaker: NA
Text: similar attitudes to their Sydney counterparts when

Speaker: NA
Text: newsit came to student protest demonstrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Cairns said he felt the policemen used the

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrations to vent their own personal feelings

Speaker: NA
Text: one about lhe students and the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: police He ends up by warning the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales police and Government that unless

Speaker: NA
Text: something is done about police violence they

Speaker: NA
Text: be responsible for any counter-violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not wish to quote it, but in the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist 'Tribune' one can find articles by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of the Communist Party in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland saying that Communists must

Speaker: NA
Text: suppon this Student Democratic Movement

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Radical Left Movement which cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain sections of the Labor Party appear to

Speaker: NA
Text: support. One can also find articles by Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Michael Hamel-Green about the theory and

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of thc Student New Left. What I

Speaker: NA
Text: am interested in and what I ask Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: members whether they are interested in is

Speaker: NA
Text: what is happening and whether the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: common citizen in this country knows what

Speaker: NA
Text: is happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were once a peace-loving society. Wc

Speaker: NA
Text: used to be a society that looked to the

Speaker: NA
Text: police to protect our homes and children.

Speaker: NA
Text: When there was trouble we would ring

Speaker: NA
Text: the police. Some clergymen and academics

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently have heroic outlooks when they

Speaker: NA
Text: are surrounded by a large crowd, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that if a woman knocked on their

Speaker: NA
Text: door and asked for a postage stamp and they

Speaker: NA
Text: thought they ran any risk they would ring

Speaker: NA
Text: the police post-haste. It seems as though

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a move to depreciate the police; to

Speaker: NA
Text: pull down those who are responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: upholding the law in this country. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not attacking the students. They have some

Speaker: NA
Text: grievances. But once they break the law

Speaker: NA
Text: it is beyond what we should tolerate. We

Speaker: NA
Text: all know that many of the young people

Speaker: NA
Text: who get involved in protests are first year

Speaker: NA
Text: university students. They are grasped by the

Speaker: NA
Text: older radicals who are there for a specific

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose. That is why so many fail in their

Speaker: NA
Text: first year at university. But it is clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are reaching a position where the

Speaker: NA
Text: bastions of the security of our homes and

Speaker: NA
Text: our way of life are being slowly infiltrated.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 put this question to the House: If what

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Yarra (Dr J. F.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cairns) says is true why has it not been

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by the Opposition as a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency? Why has it not been raised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party? Or is the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Yarra using it as propa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganda? I f the Government is concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about the feeling of the people for the

Speaker: NA
Text: and about the situations that the police have

Speaker: NA
Text: to face, why does it not make a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: about what has occurred? Once the bastions

Speaker: NA
Text: are broken down and once the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people in the police is taken away

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be trouble. I do not know where

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation will end and I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: that many honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: know either. I conclude by quoting from a

Speaker: NA
Text: speech made by Mr Chifley during the coal

Speaker: NA
Text: strike. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Either you forsake the law of the jungle, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Communist creed, and return to the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: and lawful arbitration authority or you ally your-

Speaker: NA
Text: self with a world-wide movement that seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: wreck the democratic way of life.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that the majority of the members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labor Party, of the unions

Speaker: NA
Text: and of the Labor movement generally do

Speaker: NA
Text: not condone this attack on thc police. There

Speaker: NA
Text: could bc abuses; probably there are. But

Speaker: NA
Text: an inquiry should be set up by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to determine who is behind these riots,

Speaker: NA
Text: which often start off as peaceful demonstra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The people of. this country demand

Speaker: NA
Text: and deserve to know. I f we wish to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: the way of life that we have enjoyed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the past it is time that these things were

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at very closely.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Melbourne) [11.24]- I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not often inconvenience the House by

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking on the motion for the adjournment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House, but I think that something

Speaker: NA
Text: should be said about the current situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. There is no doubt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Americans are pulling out. There is also no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that Australia has no intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing its military forces in Vietnam. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Gorton) and the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for the Army ( Mr Lynch) have con-

Speaker: NA
Text: firmed this. I go back to the 1966 policy

Speaker: NA
Text: speech of the late Rt Hon. Mr Harold

Speaker: NA
Text: Holt, who said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We seek a peaceful settlement of the conflict

Speaker: NA
Text: through negotiation. But think of the consequ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ences of abandoning our objectives-an d the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of South Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: South Vietnam would become a Communist

Speaker: NA
Text: state, and the lives and security of millions who

Speaker: NA
Text: have resisted Communism would be in jeopardy.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the strength of that appeal to fear the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government won the last election. But 2 i

Speaker: NA
Text: years have passed since then and the situa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has changed dramatically. I read in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Melbourne Press of Friday last that

Speaker: NA
Text: President Nixon proposes to withdraw

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 American troops before the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: this year and that that withdrawal will be

Speaker: NA
Text: police followed by the withdrawal of another

Speaker: NA
Text: 100,000, constituting more than 30% of

Speaker: NA
Text: the total American forces in Vietnam. But

Speaker: NA
Text: no final date was announced. I had not

Speaker: NA
Text: seen a final date until I read something

Speaker: NA
Text: from the pen of James Reston, which

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared in the New York 'Times' last

Speaker: NA
Text: week. He wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: The strategy of the Nixon Administration is

Speaker: NA
Text: now beginning to come clear.. The indications are

Speaker: NA
Text: that the President has decided to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of violence at once in Vietnam, begin with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing substantial forces from that conflict by

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of 1969. and negotiate a ceasefire,

Speaker: NA
Text: promise settlement and complete withdrawal of

Speaker: NA
Text: American troops from that country by the end

Speaker: NA
Text: That is about 19 months hence. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government proposing to do

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to the Australian forces in Viet-

Speaker: NA
Text: nam? ThePrime Minister has said more

Speaker: NA
Text: cautiously than the Minister for the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be no withdrawal. If 1 can

Speaker: NA
Text: express lhe views of the Australian people,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think they would like to know why, if

Speaker: NA
Text: American troops are to be withdrawn, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian troops should not be withdrawn at

Speaker: NA
Text: least proportionately. 1 accept the view of

Speaker: NA
Text: our military advisers that we cannot split

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain force which, after all, is a small

Speaker: NA
Text: force or token force of about 8,000. What

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to know is why all the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: forces cannot be withdrawn from Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately if 150,000 Americans are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn by the end of 1970. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted what our late dear friend had to

Speaker: NA
Text: say on this question. But let me tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: House what has been said in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Harriman' s view is

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted in an article in a newspaper called

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Broadside', which 1 recommend to honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members because I write a fortnightly

Speaker: NA
Text: article in it. Harriman's view is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to negotiate. Roger Hilsman, who was

Speaker: NA
Text: a lesser official in the Kennedy Administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and then in tbe Johnson Administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, said in a New York radio interview,

Speaker: NA
Text: as reported in tbe Melbourne 'Herald' on

Speaker: NA
Text: 25th March last:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Communists can suffer casualties of 10 to

Speaker: NA
Text: ] over American losses and still keep going for

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 or IS years.

Speaker: NA
Text: litis is a political situation. Only a coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government in Saigon with Communist

Speaker: NA
Text: representation can succeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is completely antipathetic to what this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government said, through its then Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, on the occasion of the 1966 elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign. I know that 66% of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia still support the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policy on conscription, if gallup polls

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be interpreted rightly, and that 68%

Speaker: NA
Text: of Anglicans interviewed and 68% of

Speaker: NA
Text: Roman Catholics interviewed support it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that all these people who believe

Speaker: NA
Text: in Christ would not want to send people out

Speaker: NA
Text: to be murdered in South Vietnam. What

Speaker: NA
Text: are they doing? Are they trying to out-

Speaker: NA
Text: a com- Herod Herod by killing off the kids in a

Speaker: NA
Text: war for which no person of military age

Speaker: NA
Text: will volunteer? The late Mr Harold Holt

Speaker: NA
Text: said that. He said: 'Our obligations are to

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia and aggression of any kind must be

Speaker: NA
Text: resisted'. He said that the Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted a policy of conscription because

Speaker: NA
Text: there were not sufficient volunteers. There

Speaker: NA
Text: would be no conscripts - in Asia today if

Speaker: NA
Text: those unfortunate people'had the opportun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ity to refuse to serve, as everybody else of

Speaker: NA
Text: military age in Australia has. What sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: a cowardly, moronic nation are we when

Speaker: NA
Text: we are prepared to take a section of our

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 year olds by drawing marbles from a

Speaker: NA
Text: barrel, which represents the lottery of

Speaker: NA
Text: death, and send them out to kill or be

Speaker: NA
Text: killed in order to . preserve a capitalist

Speaker: NA
Text: society here? This is the whole story. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Americans are getting out and we ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: be getting out. Had I become Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in 1966-an d I . do not care who

Speaker: NA
Text: has been running under my neck since or

Speaker: NA
Text: who ran under it before,- but I speak

Speaker: NA
Text: honestly about what I-intended to do- I

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to bring every Australian soldier

Speaker: NA
Text: out of Vietnam by Easter 1967, not Easter

Speaker: NA
Text: 1969, 2 years later. I hopethat I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: justified on that point as I have been justi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied on a lot of other things that I said at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time. I feel very keenly about this. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have 307 dead in Vietnam-hal f of

Speaker: NA
Text: them conscripts, people who never wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: to go at all'. And all the others that are

Speaker: NA
Text: there should never have been sent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe in Australian involvement

Speaker: NA
Text: in any Asian war. I did not want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: troops stationed in Malaysia, and we op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed that proposal at the time. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: is ridiculous to suggest now that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: not put troops into Malaysia but will put in

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force and Navy units instead. The

Speaker: NA
Text: policy that Australia should pursue is to

Speaker: NA
Text: render economic and social aid to Asia and

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep out of every filthy Asian war in

Speaker: NA
Text: future. This war is an undeclared war-

Speaker: NA
Text: an unprincipled war. It is an unwinnable

Speaker: NA
Text: civil war.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cleaver-I t is not.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I t is. Harriman said it

Speaker: NA
Text: is unwinnable and so did Roger Hilsman.

Speaker: NA
Text: President Nixon and his administration, by

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that they are preparing to evacuate

Speaker: NA
Text: American forces from Vietnam, recognise

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is unwinnable. It was President

Speaker: NA
Text: Johnson who said: 'It is a cruel, dirty war'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Worse than that, it is a filthy, bloody, rotten

Speaker: NA
Text: war and Australia should not be involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in any of these things. If we sow the

Speaker: NA
Text: dragon's teeth our children and our child-

Speaker: NA
Text: ren's children will reap the whirlwind. We

Speaker: NA
Text: are throwing sops to Cerberus. It reminds

Speaker: NA
Text: me of the story of the Russian Czar who

Speaker: NA
Text: tried to save himself by throwing child

Speaker: NA
Text: after child out to the wolves. We cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to do that and, in all honesty, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are real democrats we will leave the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Asia, whatever country they live in, to

Speaker: NA
Text: solve their own problems according to their

Speaker: NA
Text: lights. My philosophy has always been Asia

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Asians and Australia for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians.

Speaker: Dr MACKAY
Text: Evans) [11.33]-I n

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to the right honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Melbourne ( Mr Calwell), who has just

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken, one sometimes wonders whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: reads the daily Press and what his attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the hundreds of children who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been slaughtered by the Vietcong during

Speaker: NA
Text: the last few months when the. bombing of

Speaker: NA
Text: North Vietnam has been ceased and unverting

Speaker: NA
Text: protected towns and villages have been

Speaker: NA
Text: wantonly subjected to attack without whose

Speaker: NA
Text: discrimination.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I would remind ing

Speaker: NA
Text: all honourable gentlemen that interjections

Speaker: NA
Text: are out of order. It is becoming far too

Speaker: NA
Text: prevalent in this House for members who

Speaker: NA
Text: have spoken in debate to endeavour to have be attacked.

Speaker: NA
Text: a cross-fire exchange across the House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: tell honourable members that this position

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be tolerated by the Chair.

Speaker: Dr MACKAY
Text: Th e subject on which I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to speak is the same as that which

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for La Trobe ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Jess) raised. I believe it to be a most

Speaker: NA
Text: tant matter confronting tbis nation inside

Speaker: NA
Text: its own borders. I refer to the development

Speaker: NA
Text: which is taking place in and around

Speaker: NA
Text: through the protest movement. Mark you,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not attacking the protest movement

Speaker: NA
Text: itself, because the right to protest is a sacred

Speaker: NA
Text: right indeed in a democratic society. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: right that is not enjoyed in half of

Speaker: NA
Text: world today, and it is a right which carries

Speaker: NA
Text: with it a great responsibility. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is in Australia today demonstrably

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously a conspiracy to subvert our youth

Speaker: NA
Text: from allegience to the nation, its traditions

Speaker: NA
Text: and its constitutional forms of government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is being done in a way which is not majority.

Speaker: NA
Text: a genuine political movement but is the

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation of political, religious and social

Speaker: NA
Text: attitudes among youth by extremist revolu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionary forces. I believe that these forces

Speaker: NA
Text: are not concerned with the issues which are

Speaker: NA
Text: paraded as the apparent motives for the

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrations. I believe that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to do with Vietnam as such or

Speaker: NA
Text: conscription as such. Indeed, documents

Speaker: NA
Text: which can be produced and tabled emanat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from these sources show that such

Speaker: NA
Text: forces freely talk about the days after the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam struggle is over, and of how their

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation will be retained intact so that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be able to continue their activities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today amongst our student body there

Speaker: NA
Text: are those who are more, concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: their orientation, enlistment and induction

Speaker: NA
Text: into a process which has little or nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: to do with political forms and institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: which we have built up in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: than they are with their education. These

Speaker: NA
Text: forces, which are often much to the left of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Communist Party, are seducing and sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: our young people aided and abetted

Speaker: NA
Text: by misguided academics, clerics and others

Speaker: NA
Text: positions give them special privileges

Speaker: NA
Text: in the community. The method of destroy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our community includes the undermin-

Speaker: NA
Text: of natural and constituted authority. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for La Trobe has

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, the police force in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: is singled out as one of the authorities to

Speaker: NA
Text: Some little time ago in this chamber the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General ( Mr Bowen) drew atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to a very important reorganisation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the forces of the left that were to set out

Speaker: NA
Text: on this course. Immediately following the

Speaker: NA
Text: last Federal election in 1967 a conference

Speaker: NA
Text: imporwas held over the Australia Day weekend.

Speaker: NA
Text: This most important cenference laid down

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines and the beginnings of many of

Speaker: NA
Text: and the movements which have blossomed

Speaker: NA
Text: since, particularly among .the youth of the

Speaker: NA
Text: church and other bodies in the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many interesting discussions were held and

Speaker: NA
Text: a many interesting decisions were taken. For

Speaker: NA
Text: the instance, one group recommended to the

Speaker: NA
Text: general committee of the conference a split-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting up into groups to train for and discuss

Speaker: NA
Text: and civil disobedience. A move was made to

Speaker: NA
Text: recommend that acts of civil-disobedience

Speaker: NA
Text: be kept separate from mass demonstrations,

Speaker: NA
Text: but this move was defeated by a large

Speaker: NA
Text: In discussing the situation of young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the community, particular atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was paid to the schools. It was said

Speaker: NA
Text: that because of the introduction of a sixth

Speaker: NA
Text: year in high schools by the Wyndham

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, the older and more mature students

Speaker: NA
Text: offered great possibilities for organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: in the high schools and the setting up of an

Speaker: NA
Text: ami-war underground news sheet. Other

Speaker: NA
Text: methods of bringing youth into the move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment were then formulated. The conference

Speaker: NA
Text: was set up by a body known then as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam Action Commiitee. Later it

Speaker: NA
Text: changed its name to the Vietnam Action

Speaker: NA
Text: Campaign. Arising out of the conference, a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of other movements were formed.

Speaker: NA
Text: For instance, in Victoria the Vietnam Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinating Committee came into existence.

Speaker: NA
Text: After setting up its headquarters in Park-

Speaker: NA
Text: villc it set out to become the body which

Speaker: NA
Text: would, in its own words, be concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: thc role of organisation .of demonstrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Vietnam Co-ordinating Committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: an interesting list of office, bearers but I

Speaker: NA
Text: will noi weary honourable members by

Speaker: NA
Text: reading their names. However, 1 trust that

Speaker: NA
Text: all honourable members will direct their

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the kind of information which

Speaker: NA
Text: was made available.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to quote from a newsletter sent

Speaker: NA
Text: out by the Vietnam Co-ordinating Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee. It slates:

Speaker: NA
Text: The October 23 demonstration

Speaker: NA
Text: described as one of Ihe most violent demonstra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions Melbourne has ever seen. The police have

Speaker: NA
Text: accused thc organisers, the Vietnam Co-ordinating

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee, of going back on their word. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam Co-ordinating Committee, organising thc

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration, wish to present their version.

Speaker: NA
Text: It goes on lo discuss the way in which mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the organisation say that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: tried to co-operate with the police but have

Speaker: NA
Text: found that it does not work. It states:

Speaker: NA
Text: The police say one thing and do another. They

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously prefer to push us around, rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: co-operate wilh us.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are. not going to be pushed around any

Speaker: NA
Text: more. To prevent violence and disorder in future

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrations the Vietnam Co-ordinating Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee will provide ils own police force and will

Speaker: NA
Text: request Ihe regular police to keep clear of

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrators.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then the whole situation is made ludicrous

Speaker: NA
Text: because in the very same report there is

Speaker: NA
Text: another statement which completely contra-

Speaker: NA
Text: dicts the charge that the police had gone

Speaker: NA
Text: back on their undertaking to the organisers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the demonstration. I. quote another part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the report which says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The more or less spontaneous deviations from

Speaker: NA
Text: plan at the last two major marches can never bs

Speaker: NA
Text: accomplished with the same degree of success

Speaker: NA
Text: again. The police have contingency plans now

Speaker: NA
Text: and we must adjust our organisation accordingly.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the thing is taking place in our midst

Speaker: NA
Text: which is giving rise to a plethora of

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations of many names such as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Society for Democratic Action and

Speaker: NA
Text: Students for Democratic Society. But

Speaker: NA
Text: some of their decisions and some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions which have been taken at these

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings are most revealing with regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter brought up by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for La Trobe. I quote again. One

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker insisted that:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . to be worthwhile demonstrations should be

Speaker: NA
Text: made up of large numbers of people with a

Speaker: NA
Text: hard core using things like smoke bombs and

Speaker: NA
Text: rocks to attack the police. The rest should confuse

Speaker: NA
Text: and hinder the police with passive resistance

Speaker: NA
Text: tactics ancl so provoke them into violent action.

Speaker: NA
Text: This way maximum publicity was obtained, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was the prime aim of demonstrations. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: at all times the police should be goaded into

Speaker: NA
Text: taking the first violent action.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is in keeping with other material that

Speaker: NA
Text: we find even in the decisions of the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Churches at its fourth assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: in Upsala. It has given its own blessing to

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of force and use of violence iu

Speaker: NA
Text: revolution. This was, it said, morally

Speaker: NA
Text: ambiguous and something which could be

Speaker: NA
Text: employed even as soon as the forces of

Speaker: NA
Text: has been law and order began to use violence in

Speaker: NA
Text: withstanding the forces of change.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conc.ude by saying that the method of

Speaker: NA
Text: destroying our community includes the

Speaker: NA
Text: undermining of all natural and constituted

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities in the home, the parents, the

Speaker: NA
Text: law, the police force, the Government, the

Speaker: NA
Text: school or university authorities. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: not opinions. They are facts that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by publicly available informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion coming from these organisations. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that they are facts which could .be

Speaker: NA
Text: sustained before a royal commission or

Speaker: NA
Text: other inquiry. I believe thai it is encumbent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the Government to set forth before

Speaker: NA
Text: very long for the Australian people to see

Speaker: NA
Text: the pattern of what is being done to enlist

Speaker: NA
Text: our young people in the same kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: violence that is being seen right across the

Speaker: NA
Text: free world and which, when it is attempted

Speaker: NA
Text: in a demonstration in Czechoslovakia, is

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately clamped down on by the ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities there. The demonstrations are

Speaker: NA
Text: not to bc stopped, but the kind of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploitation of the adventurous spirit of youth

Speaker: NA
Text: and its desire for change which is seen on

Speaker: NA
Text: these occasions is something which is foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: and inimical to the interest of Australia.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: Reid) [11.43]-Th e honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for La Trobe ( Mr Jess) asked

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been happening in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: What has been happening to the young

Speaker: NA
Text: people in this country cannot be divorced

Speaker: NA
Text: from what the right honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Melbourne ( Mr Calwell) said, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the students and young people of this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try are disturbed about the conscripting of

Speaker: NA
Text: young men for overseas military service and

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia's involvement in the Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: war. The right honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne explained that you cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: divorce one from the other. This is why

Speaker: NA
Text: the young people of this country are dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: turbed. They are disturbed because only a

Speaker: NA
Text: few selected young men of this nation are

Speaker: NA
Text: being conscripted and then being forced by

Speaker: NA
Text: men in this Parliament who are of military

Speaker: NA
Text: age themselves and by many who are old

Speaker: NA
Text: men to go overseas to an unpopular war,

Speaker: NA
Text: a vicious war, and a cruel war that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been decried and condemned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of the nations of the world. The

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America has stood prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tically alone because it could not get other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries to join it in Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for La Trobe

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to think that there is something

Speaker: NA
Text: unhealthy about the fact that the students

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia are disturbed about and are

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrating against this war. Everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: who has studied this question knows that

Speaker: NA
Text: university students on the whole set out on

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful demonstrations. These university

Speaker: NA
Text: students march in peaceful demonstrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The speakers who address them prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: their going out on a demonstration call for

Speaker: NA
Text: a non-violent approach. The leaders of

Speaker: NA
Text: these demonstrations emphasise that they

Speaker: NA
Text: should be non-violent demonstrations.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we know that in all movements there

Speaker: NA
Text: are minorities who will try to do something

Speaker: NA
Text: unusual and who will try to make the head-

Speaker: NA
Text: lines. But surely the police should be

Speaker: NA
Text: intelligent. The police should be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand and to deal with this very small

Speaker: NA
Text: minority. If the police are not experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: by now, all I say is that if they go on with

Speaker: NA
Text: the violence and brutality with which they

Speaker: NA
Text: are going on and with which they went on

Speaker: NA
Text: last week in the demonstrations in Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be a bloody war and we will see

Speaker: NA
Text: blood running in the streets of Sydney. I

Speaker: NA
Text: make it quite clear to all honourable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers that I have always advocated the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: violent approach in demonstrations. 1 have

Speaker: NA
Text: stressed and over-stressed always the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that when we have demonstrated against

Speaker: NA
Text: the Vietnam war we have stood for negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for a peaceful settlement. That war

Speaker: NA
Text: must be settled by negotiation. This has

Speaker: NA
Text: always been the view of the great bulk of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian peace movement and the

Speaker: NA
Text: great bulk of the student movement who

Speaker: NA
Text: have demonstrated against this war. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: what is happening in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Do honourable members on the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment side know that people acting in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with theirconsciences are pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to go to gaol because of the blunder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing stupidity of the Government? Through

Speaker: NA
Text: this stupidity the Government is condemn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing them to 2 years in gaol because of their

Speaker: NA
Text: courage and their convictions against a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular war to which they have a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: scientious objection. Are the newspapers

Speaker: NA
Text: right in what they say? For instance, Ian

Speaker: NA
Text: Fitchett wrote in the 'Sydney Morning

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald' earlier this week-i f he is right-

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister for Labour and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Service ( Mr Bury) brought recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from his Department to Cabinet seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to exclude from military services those

Speaker: NA
Text: who were conscientious objectors against a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular war. That war is the Vietnam war.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal was that they would be

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded from military service and should

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake special service. But no, the hard

Speaker: NA
Text: liners, the conservatives and the stupid

Speaker: NA
Text: blunderers in this Government have con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued to say no. They say: 'We are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that, unless people go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: war in Vietnam they will be put in gaol

Speaker: NA
Text: with criminals and others for 2 years'. The

Speaker: NA
Text: men of conscience-mer i like Bill White

Speaker: NA
Text: and Simon Townsend-a s far as I am con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned will be the great men of our age.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Calwell-Joh n Zarb too.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: An d John Zarb too, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honourable member for Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: points out. These men are men of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: science and men of courage. Therefore, we

Speaker: NA
Text: must realise why these demonstrations are

Speaker: NA
Text: going on. It is all right for the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Evans (Dr Mackay), 'that holy

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman, that godly man', to talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: the students in Czechoslovakia. I applaud

Speaker: NA
Text: the students in Czechoslovakia who are

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrating against the oppression that is

Speaker: NA
Text: being suffered there. This morning's Ausand

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian newspapers told how the students

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to go to their classes. What did streets of Sydney.

Text: (Question No. 1098)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Interior, upon notice:

Text: How does the cost of electricity in Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: vincial cities in Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Nixori-Th e answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is difficult to make a direct comparison of

Speaker: NA
Text: costs because of the different forms of tariffs used

Speaker: NA
Text: by the various supply authorities. They differ not

Speaker: NA
Text: only for different consumer classes but also to

Speaker: NA
Text: suit' population habits, climatic conditions, times

Speaker: NA
Text: and even rates of usage. Tariffs are also usually

Speaker: NA
Text: promotional, that is, the more that is used, the

Speaker: NA
Text: lower the unit cost. Therefore overall comparisons,

Speaker: NA
Text: except in regard to specific instances may be

Speaker: NA
Text: misleading.

Text: Services, upon notice:

Text: faults in the computers used by the Department?

Text: view to eliminating such delays?

Text: Th e answer to the

Speaker: NA

Text: 1 and 2. No, there is no record of any delay in

Text: payment having been caused by faults in Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental computers. On the contrary, the computer

Speaker: NA
Text: installations have established a remarkable record

Speaker: NA

Text: ments to be made in the timeliness of benefit

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: have I received a copy of the agenda.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Housing Minister to attend the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing Ministers' Conference to be held in Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne on 19th March. On 23rd January I advised

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: date, at best I could be present for part only of

Speaker: NA
Text: the meeting. Early in March I wrote to the host

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister regretting that,' due to parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions commitments in Canberra on 19th March, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: be unable to make any appearance at the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference in Melbourne on that day. Although I was

Speaker: NA
Text: hopeful that an alternative date might have been

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested, this was not proposed. However, 1 fully

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate that, as this ' is a State Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers' Conference, it is for these Ministers to

Speaker: NA
Text: fix a date suitable to themselves.
